The speeches read as followsâ
WAR CRIMES AMENDMENT BILL 1999
This bill repeals section 22 of the War Crimes Act 1945.

The act was amended in 1989 prior to the fall of the "iron curtain" to enable trial in Australia with respect of conduct engaged in during World War II in Europe. Although the usual practice would have been to extradite persons accused of such crimes to the country where the crimes occurred, at the time it was considered politically unacceptable to extradite persons to countries behind the so called "iron curtain".

The "iron curtain" has fallen and many of the republics, including Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania are now independent states and have been accepted as members of the Council of Europe. Australia has, in the past, been prepared to enter into extradition arrangements with any country that is a member of the Council.

The Government is actively pursuing the possibility of establishing modern extradition arrangements with many of these newly independent States. However, even if a modern extradition relationship was in place, it would still be impossible for those countries to comply with an extradition request while section 22 of the War Crimes Act remains in force.

Effectively, section 22 of the act provides that where a person's extradition from Australia is sought for conduct covered by the act no surrender for extradition is possible unless the requesting country establishes a prima facie case. Thus, notwithstanding a modern extradition relationship with these countries, if the offence for which extradition is sought is a "war crime" then the requesting state must provide a prima facie case. Because of the differences between civil code and common law countries the practical effect is that it would be virtually impossible for a civil code jurisdiction to successfully seek the extradition of a person suspected of a war crime.

The concept of a prima facie case in determining sufficiency of evidence is one to which most common law countries are accustomed. However, those countries which operate under a civil code system (e.g., Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania) do not use this test in criminal proceedings. The practical issue is that the laws of evidence in common law systems are such as to make it very difficult for a civil code jurisdiction to supply evidence in an admissible form.
The repeal of section 22 will remove the fundamental barrier to Australia's cooperation with the international community in relation to suspected war criminals.

This is not to say that extradition of a suspected war criminal would be automatic. Any request for the extradition of a suspected war criminal would be subject to the general extradition arrangement with the requesting country. Such arrangement must include all the usual safeguards spelt out in the Extradition Act 1988. All that the amendment will do is to remove an additional onerous requirement that relates only to the extradition of war criminals. This Government sees no reason in principle why this practical impediment to the extradition of war criminals should be retained.
The amendment to the act will not have any financial impact.
CUSTOMS (TARIFF CONCESSION SYSTEM VALIDATIONS) BILL 1999
This bill is designed to remove any doubt about the validity of certain decisions made by officers of the Australian Customs Service in relation to the tariff concession system.
The tariff concession system allows goods to be imported at a concessional rate of duty essentially in circumstances where there are no local manufacturers of substitutable goods.
In November 1995, the chief executive officer of customs generally delegated his powers and functions in relation to the tariff concession system to certain officers of customs.
In July 1996, the government made changes to the tariff concession system.
Those changes resulted in amendments to the Customs Act, including the introduction of additional powers and functions.
New delegations were not sought for powers that were added to sections of the act which were already the subject of the November 1995 instrument.
It was thought that that instrument was sufficient.
The sufficiency of the delegations for the tariff concession system was questioned in a recent hearing of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
In light of this, the chief executive officer signed two instruments on 31 May 1999.
The first revoked all existing delegations for the tariff concession system.
The second issued new delegations covering all the powers and functions in relation to the tariff concession system.
Both instruments took effect on 1 June 1999.

Notwithstanding, it is possible that certain decisions and actions taken in relation to the tariff concession system subsequent to the 1996 changes to the act may not have been the subject of adequate delegations.
This bill aims to remove any doubt about the validity of these decisions and actions, to the extent that they were taken in reliance on a delegation that may not have been sufficient.

Finally, the government has decided that this bill should not apply to certain matters before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or to certain applications for refunds of customs duty, which had not been decided before 1 June 1999.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of these bills be adjourned till the first day of sitting in the spring sittings 1999, in accordance with standing order 111.
Ordered that these bills be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.

âWe have just heard one of the most infantile and vacuous contributions ever in this chamber from a manager of government business. I congratulate Senator Campbell on managing not to address the motion but to string his contribution out for at least seven of the 10 minutes that were available to him. What we have here is a proposal to confine debate to literally a couple of hours on legislation that is before this chamber for the first timeâthe environment packageâthat contains an unprecedented 906 amendments. That is what we are debatingâa proposal from the government to stymie debate on this significant environment legislation.

speech.para: There are 906 amendments to the legislation and 569 government and Democrat sponsored amendments that this chamber had not seen before late last night. More than 300 of those amendments are to be debated in just one hour. A total of 511 of those amendments were hatched in secrecy by the government and the Australian Democrats without the knowledge of the green groups or the conservation groups and without the knowledge of, or consultation with, state governments and industry groups. That is because, as Senator Lees has made quite clear, she would not trust the conservation groups. She cannot afford to let anyone understand the details of the fix that she has come to with the government.

I look at Senator Lees and know that, with the government, she is sponsoring another guillotine in the Senate. Senator Lees, you have become the Madame Defarge of the Senate. You sit there sponsoring this guillotine. All we have from you is the click of the knitting needles as the parade of tumbrels comes past. Whose head are you chopping off? You are chopping off the heads of the Wilderness Society, the Australian Conservation Foundation and Greenpeace. You are chopping off the heads of the environment constituency, industry groups and the states, and you wash your hands of it. That is the problem that we have at the moment.

Rather than acting in the way that the Democrats have traditionally, having a proper debate and a review of legislationâin the case of the environment legislation it is a legislative outrageâSenator Lees has been, and is about to be, in the final two weeks of this session, responsible for the bloody mutilation of Telstra and the bloody mutilation of the tax system, ensuring forever that we no longer have the checks and the balances that should be inherent in national environmental policy. That is the responsibility of Senator Lees, the Madame Defarge of the Senate and the Australian Democrats.

Instead of using the electoral clout, the influence that the Democrats have been blessed with, to stop this sort of carnage, what is Senator Lees doing? She is sitting in the corner of the Senate and all you hear from her is the clicking of the knitting needles as the guillotine falls. I am quite confident that Senator Lees will not be thanked for this. What she will reap is an electoral backlash.

The guillotine motion before the Senate allows virtually no debate. Literally, what the guillotine that Senator Lees and Senator Hill are sponsoring allows for is a few seconds debate in this chamber on 906 amendments. This guillotine does not apply just to the environment legislation, where it is an absolute outrage, although we acknowledge that it is less outrageous in relation to the tax legislation. We have a brand new tax system being proposed by the government. The proposal that the government went to the election on has been completely up-ended by Senator Lees and the government. Senator Campbell tells us about the longest debate in Senate history. This is a brand new debate. Again, in the GST package there are two new bills and 119 new government and Democrat sponsored amendments. Government mismanagement and Democrat interference has resulted in ANTS package mark 2, mark 3 or whatever we have before us. We have just received pages and pages of amendments from the Table Office. These are indicative that the tax system in this country is going to become utterly ramshackle at the conclusion of the Senate's debate.

We say, `Let's examine the legislation properly. Let's give the Senate an opportunity for proper scrutiny of this legislation.' That principle has applied until recently, under all former Democrat leadersâbut not under Madame Defargeâand it was accepted by the Australian Democrats. It is no wonder, Senator Lees, that already two of your number have ratted on you. Most of your party membership have ratted on you. And so they should, because you have sold them out. You have also sold out those Australians who voted for you.

Not only has she done that but she has also sold out more than 300,000 small businesses that hang on the amendments we have to the tax package before the Senate that could become law. Small businesses and members of the public would say that the Senate is abrogating its duty if these matters are not properly examined.

I have to say with some disappointment in relation to the Australia Democrats: have we ever witnessed a truer illustration of the old adage that power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely? Because this is what has happened now. The Australian Democrats have the government over a barrel. They have real political and parliamentary leverage over this government, but they are not willing to use it. They are in the closed doors fix. They are selling out constituencies that I would acknowledge over the years have been considered integral to their political interests.

They had an opportunity to say to this government, `We will give you your GST and the Democrat-government GST package, but we will give you only that package.' But they squibbed it; they sold out their own party's interest. They even sold out members of their own parliamentary party and they certainly sold out the organisational wing of their party. Senator Lees has ensured nothing other than the political demise of the Australian Democrats, as well as her own political demise. Sadly, as the Madame Defargeâas the supporter of the guillotine in the Senate on this legislationâthat is precisely what she deserves.

speech.para: Secondly, we have said from the start that we believe the tax bills should be brought to fruition before 30 June. We thought that was the government's right. We did not guarantee on which day they would come to a vote but, essentially, that is the reason we had all those extra sitting hours. But, of course, it was not the Labor Party that withdrew the tax bills. We were in committee; we were at 10 per cent the way through. It was the government that pulled the tax bills off, not us. Now they want to put a time limitation on itâwhat a terrible word; I should be saying `if there is an undemocratic guillotine'. What is this political correctness that we are starting to useâtime management and time limitation! It is sickening. I at least would have expected the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, as a political pragmatist, to approach it and say, `This is a guillotine.' But we have got into all these other phraseologies.

I would have expected that, if we are to guillotine the tax bills, given that there are such comprehensive changes to itâand if there are not comprehensive changes to it, the Democrats have been total failures as negotiatorsâthey themselves would have asserted that there have been massive changes to this tax bill proposed in the amendments and that there should be some time in which to consider them. However, there is some argument for a guillotine on the tax bills, provided the hours allotted are reasonable. We all agree in this chamberâvirtually all anyway, not everyoneâthat it is desirable to have these matters resolved by 30 June, one way or the other. We were always intending to keep our guarantee in that regard.

The one that is difficult to come to grips with is the environment bill. This is a bill that Senator Hill acknowledged in question time yesterday as having had a long gestation period. He said that it had been to committees, it is an important and critical bill, there have been consultations with the states, and the stakeholders have all been consulted. That is eminently sensible. The situation we now find is that in spite of all that consultation and consideration there are going to be massive and dramatic changes to the environment bill. The 560 amendments constitute almost a new bill. So none of the stakeholders have really been consulted about this. If they have, it has been in the last 16 hours, because these amendments were only released at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. What chance have the states had, for instance, to see and evaluate them and influence the states house here? What chance have most of the environment groups had to look at these amendments? What chance have the various foresters, miners and all those critical people had? They have had no chance to look at these amendments and comment on them.

This is a bill that could be held over until the spring sittings, because one thing we know is that it will have 45 certain votes in the spring sittings. It could be left to sit on the table. We could get on with the tax debate immediately and leave that one until the spring sittings. Why not? A lot of these people would like to have some input on it. If the numbers are thereâas they are there today for the guillotineâand if there is time wasting, as Senator Lees alleged would occur in the spring sittings, and the bill did not come to fruition, then you can guillotine your bill through. But leave three months. Leave all the amendments sitting on the table so that we have at least got a chance of reading them. How many senatorsâI say through you, Madam President, to Senator Leesâare going to get the chance to read and analyse those 569 amendments that were tabled at 4 o'clock yesterday? Some of us may not want to or some of us may not bother but, for those who are diligent, what real consideration can this parliament give those amendments?

Basically what I am saying is that, apart from the gormless way it was done, there is some justification for a guillotine on Telstra, there is some justification for a rolling guillotine on the tax bills so that people will be able to ration time, be able to concentrate on particular areas and get a chance to debate this raft of government amendments on the tax bill. But on the environment bill this is just impossible. There are two motives for the guillotine on the environment bill. There is the government motive. They would obviously always prefer to guillotine than have Senator Hill have to spend hours here trying to justify his amendments. He would much rather be back in his officeâif I were him, so would Iâdoing the things involved in the normal course of events than being subjected to a cross-examination from Senators Bolkus, Brown, Margetts, et cetera. But that is actually what he is being paid to do. However, that would have only got this resolution 37-odd votes.

Why are the seven Democrats voting for this? It is absolutely obvious. Having done the deal with the government, they do not want to be pressured. They just want it over and done with. They want the agony to end. They do not want to have to justify themselves for the next three monthsâback to their own party members, back to the constituencies that they appeal to. They do not have the intestinal fortitude, they do not have the mental strength, to go through that process.

So we are facing a debate that will conclude at 6 o'clock today in which over 900 amendments have to be considered. We are facing a debate where 569 government amendments have to be considered by then. There is no way that those amendments can have proper scrutiny. The rest of the bill can. It has been through the processes. All of the rest of the existing bill is well known, well debated. It is simply these amendments that cannot be considered.

I am going to take the government at their wordâsaying that they want a reasonable time on the tax debate. I propose to moved an amendment to their guillotine. The amendment has been circulated in the chamber. I move:
Paragraph 2(a), omit "3.30 p.m. to 6.30 pm", substitute "3.30 p.m. to 10.30 pm".

We want a little more time on the tax bill, Senator Lees. That is what we are asking for. We are asking for another four hours on the tax bills in total. I am sure that will appeal to you. You did say that there should be generous time on the tax bills.

talk.start.para: âYou have four days on it.

âWe have not really got four days, I am sorry. We have Thursdayâbut not a full day. We do not have a full day on Friday and it is not a full day on Monday. So Senator Lees apparently is not going to support another four hours. But of course the government will. The government is a generous operation. It believes in generous guillotines.

speech.para: What do they have to give up in order to get this extra four hours? What they have to give up is the valedictories on Thursday night. Oh, shock horrorâjust think, we are not going to be able to spend four hours here listening to vacuous hypocritical slimy speeches on our colleagues, when suddenly we are forgiven for all past sins. Imagine the saving in cliches. Imagine the savings in ersatz sentiment that we will make by supporting my amendment. Here is your chance. Deep down in the government, most of you want to get out of the valedictories. You can vote for my amendment. You can vote for an extra democratic four hours on the tax bills and miss all those things.

But I have more. I will not only throw in steak knives; we will allow the valedictories then to occur at 10.30 on Thursday night. Let us see who sticks around. Let us see who runs for the cars, let us see who stays to send their colleagues off in style. I have news for you, Madam President. I am going to beat you out the door that night, because I am not sticking around for the valedictories if my great amendment gets up.

talk.start.para: âIt is interesting to observe the behaviour of members in the chamber this morning. We just heard Senator Ray listened to in almost silence, but the Labor Party chooses to apply its own gag on Senator Lees as soon as she gets up to try and speak. She could not get more than three words out without being abused by Labor Party senators opposite. Did Senator Ray make the same speech when his former leader Gareth Evans moved the guillotine on 62 bills in one day? Not only was that guillotine sealed with a kiss on the floor of the parliament but Ms Kernot also chose to join Gareth afterwards on a much more permanent basis.

speech.para: Government senator interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âWe should have guessed at the time but we did not. The subject that we are really debating in this motion is whether sufficient time has been allocated to consider the proposals that have been put before this chamber. When it comes to talking about sufficient time for important pieces of legislation that have been moved by successive governments before this chamber, the Labor Party ought to look at its own record. In this particular case, the Labor Party intend to oppose these bills. They have publicly stated that they will oppose the amendments. They have publicly stated that, regardless of any debate that takes place, they are going to oppose the proposals that are brought forward by the government and the amendments that have been agreed to by the Democrats. The Greens, Senator Brown in particular, are urging people to oppose the bills regardless of the debate.

âYes, he got 50 people to attend his demonstration. But he is going to oppose the bills regardless of the debate that takes place in this chamber. The Democrats and the government have come to some agreement and they are going to support the amendments agreed to, regardless of the debate that takes place in this chamber. Let us say that, particularly in relation to the tax bills, over the period of time that these matters have been before the public record there has never been more scrutiny of proposals that have been put before the Australian public than has taken place over the tax bills that we are debating and that we are being asked to agree to in this place.

speech.para: Let us have a look at Labor's record when it comes to issues and matters of importance in regard to legislation. I seem to remember that, soon after I came into this place, the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Laurie Brereton, brought forward what were considered to be the most important changes to industrial relations that had ever taken place in the history of this federation. What time did that Labor government give us to scrutinise that industrial relations legislation? Of course, back in those days, Labor controlled the committees and so they most generously said that, in order to debate and discuss and have hearings on the most important industrial legislation to come before the parliament since Federation, they would allow three days of committee hearingsâone committee, three days; that is it, finishedâand then it was back into the chamber with a reasonably short debate and then their legislation was passed.

Compare that with Peter Reith's industrial relations legislation that came before this parliament in 1996. What happened to that industrial relations legislation, which was then considered to be the most important legislation that came before parliament at that stage? We were forced to a roadshow circus for 18 daysâ18 days of scrutiny by the committee, and then back in the chamber for something like 50 hours of debate before that legislation was passed. So the Labor Party, before it starts to criticise the Liberal party or the coalition government on its attitude to important legislation and the amount of time that is made available for scrutiny of these bills, ought to look back at their own record and see just how much time they allocated when they brought their important bills in, compared with when we brought ours forward.

The tax reform bills have had scrutiny unprecedented in the history of this parliament. They have gone to four committees. I always understood when I first came to this place that the purpose of taking legislation to committeesâand we had legislation at that timeâwas so that the public could have some input, so that we could listen to the submissions of those interested parties and then, when the bills came back into the chamber, less time would be taken for debate. I have to say that in the last three years that simply has not been the case. We have had extended committee hearings, lengthy hearingsâand then, when the bills have been heard in committee and have come back into this chamber, we find that we have another extended debate at the consideration in detail stage. So one wonders why on earth we ever send them out to committees if, when they come back, we then have 40 or 50 hours of debate on amendments in this place, when in fact the committee system was set up in order to alleviate the length of time that was taken in this place for debating bills.

talk.start.para: âYou abused it straight off.

âI would say in response to that, Senator Ray, that you know very well that, back in the time when the committee structure was set up, in fact it did alleviate lengthy debates in the chamber, because committees did the work and, when the matter came back here, it short-circuited the lengthy debates that we continue to have here. If we want that system to work, and if we do not want it to be abused, and if we want it to reach the stage where the Australian public has a chance to have some input into the legislation that is being put before them and where amendments can be brought about simply because of that input that the public has, then we ought to make sure that that committee system works.

speech.para: When we talk about the number of amendments that have been agreed to by the Democrats and the government and about the amendments that have been agreed to in relation to this environmental package, let me say that they are as a result of consultation. Senator Lees and the government have had input from all the various industry groups and bodies who actually want the original legislation changed. It is as a result of constructive negotiations with the Democrats that we have in fact reached the stage where we have those amendments in place and the Senate is ready to vote on them.

The Labor Party are not going to change their vote one iota regardless of any debate that takes place. If we thought that the extension of the debate might actually change their mind and that they would support the government's position on tax reform, I am quite sure that we would allow the debate to go longer. We know that they are intransigent. We know that regardless of what debate takes place they will not change their view on any single issue. For that reason it is only sensible we put in place strict time limits so these bills can be dealt with and so the Australian public can know with some certainty what the bills are going to contain for the next 12 months as they get themselves organised to handle the new tax system which we have proposed.

In relation to the environment, Senator Brown has been left on his own, so anything that Senator Brown might say is totally irrelevant. I understand that all of the major conservation groups in Tasmania have cast Senator Brown aside and have supported the position taken by the Australian Democrats, which is a sensible position. It is a position that we in the government have agreed with and can work for the good of Australia. Senator Brown has been cast aside. He will cut a very lone figure after June 30 when he comes up with some of the more ratbag ideas that he has been used to bringing up in this place. I am pleased that we have a sensible environmental package that can be passed today with the support of the Democrats. The people who have made representations to them have certainly been taken into account. The people whom Senator Brown thinks he represents no longer exist so he can get up and say all he likes about this package.

I conclude by saying that no matter what time we take in debate of these issues it will not make one difference to any vote that takes place here today. The arguments will not be listened to on either side, so we ought to proceed and make sure these bills can be put in place for the good of the Australian community.

talk.start.para: âThat about sums up the government's position: the arguments will not be listened to. It also sums up the position of the Liberal lap-warming Democrats, half of whom have fled the chamber already. Let me put on the record that, of the seven Democrats who signed this obsequious letter in defence of the government's appalling environment position, we do not at the moment have Senator Bourne in the chamber; Senator Woodley is not here; Senator Murray from Western Australia has fled the chamber; and Deputy Leader Natasha Stott Despoja is nowhere to be seen. That is part of the story. I note that Senator Faulkner referred to Senator Lees as Madame Defarge with the knitting needles clicking as the tumbrel rolls in.

speech.para: Let me carry that analogy further: it is the environment of Australia in that tumbrel. It is the environment of Australiaâas well as this legislationâthat is facing the guillotine. It is the great forests of Australia, the great indigenous lands of Australia, the fisheries of Australia and the plains of Australia that are facing the chop in this legislation.

I want, firstly, to correct a lie which hangs in the air in this chamber and which comes out of the press release put out by the Democrats. They said they had to have this debate, they had to cave in to the government and they had to jump into the Howard lap to crucify the environment because, if they did not, the Independents would and that is why they have to guillotine this debate today. But, Madam President, you will be aware that last night a motion was brought before this House by Senator Margetts which said, `Let this bill wait until August.' You will know that in August the numbers will be different here and the Democrats will have the complete balance of power for government legislation.

Senator Harradine voted for that motion. Senator Colston was not in the chamber. The Democrats had the numbers to get that motion through, to hold this across to August to give them total power to get through the things that they failed to get at the Howard polished table in secret this last week. But what did the Democrats do? They are so comfortable warming the Liberal lap that they sat this side and denied themselves that opportunity because they cannot take that responsibility. They sold out on the forests. Remember, they went to that table last week saying, `We have got to have global warming in this legislation,' and they could have had that had they supported that motion of Senator Margetts last night but they gave it the thumbs down. They said, `We want an environment commissioner who can independently vet what is happening hereâ

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I raise a point of order on relevance. The senator should be relevant to the debate about time allocations and talk about time allocations and not the legislation.

âWe are certainly debating a motion concerning the allocation of time for legislation for the remainder of the session. I have been very generous in allowing people to stray widely from that. I draw Senator Brown's attention to the main motion but I agree that most speakersâ
âHe has strayed that far, he has become a feral.
âOrder! If I am speaking, Senator, I do not expect to hear your voice.
âSo be quiet!
âAnd you too, Senator. Senator Brown.

âYes, there is no point of order. That is because what I am saying is that the Democrats, through the good offices of Senator Margetts, who tested them last night, had the ability to have this whole debate held over until August when there would not only be ample time to discuss all 900 amendments but there would be time to go back to the Australian people and have the transparent debate which the Democrats claim but which they have pulled the rug from under. There would be the time and the leverage then to get the things they manifestly failed to get for the environment.

speech.para: Madam President, the other lie that is in the Democrats so-called delivery of expansion of Commonwealth environment powers is that this legislation that they have obsequiously signed up to is better than the status quo.

talk.start.para: âMuch better.

âMuch better, says Senator Lees, who, we can take it, has therefore rejected advice from a far greater expert in this field than herself from her own stateâfrom the state of the absent Senator Stott Despoja. I refer to a letter sent to the Democrats today by Associate Professor Rob Fowler, Director of the Australian Centre for Environmental Law at the University of Adelaide. Here is what Professor Fowler has to say:

speech.para: First, the new requirements for bilaterally accredited management plans for the purpose of bilateral agreement simply add another procedural hoop to an already complex process, but leave open the prospect of a wide range of approval powers being delegated to the statesâ
the very thing that Senator Lees says is not going to happen. To continue:
Second, and even more importantlyâ
and this is why we should have time to discuss this matterâ
I believe it would still be possible as a matter of law for a State government to approve a Franklin Dam with this legislation or a sand-mine on Fraser Islandâ

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I rise on a point of order. I was not permitted in any way to move into the area of content of the debate. The nonsense that Senator Brown is now spouting in this chamber is debating the issue, and I ask you to draw him back to the motion before the chair.
âYou are debating the issue, Senator.

âOn the point of order, firstly, the `nonsense' I am spouting is not mine; it is Professor Fowler that I am quoting. Secondly, it is very germane for me to debate why we should not have this truncated process now but should be debating this in August with the fullness of time.
âYou are debating the issue and the substance of it, and I did draw Senator Lees's attention to that earlier. I draw your attention to it as well and remind you of the content of the motion.
âThe Democrats will need more protection than that as the day goes on, I can assure you.
âWe've got it.

âMadam President, I rise on a point of order. In Senator Brown's contribution, you might have heard him say, `The Democrats will need more protection than that as the day goes on,' and Senator Lees saidâ

interjection.para: Senator Ian Campbell interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYes, I am taking a point of order. If you'd listen, dope, you might here what it is.
âOrder! I think you should withdraw that. That is not the way to refer to another senator.

âCertainly, Madam President. Senator Lees then said, `We've got it.' I wonder what that means in terms of the independence of the chair. I wonder whether it impugns the integrity of the chair. I wonder what it means, Madam President.
âOrder! I heard Senator Brown's statement and I thought that was a threat being made to another senator. I did not hear any other statement after that.
âLet me assure you that Senator Lees, and I am sure she will confirm itâ
âAbsolutely.

âMadam President, she said `Absolutely' and `We've got it.' Does that mean that there is some arrangement between you, the chair or other officers presiding and Senator Lees in relation to protection? I want to understand what it means.
âThe standing orders are quite clear, Senator. Every senator has the protection of the standing orders and has an obligation to adhere to them.
âYes, Madam President, but I am interested in knowing what `We've got it' means.
âThe standing orders of the Senate protect all senators.
âI wish to make a personal explanation because I claim to have been misrepresented. I was not talking even vaguely about standing orders.
âYou would need leave to make a statement, Senator. Is leave granted?
âI seek leave to make a statement.
âIs leave granted?
âNo.

speech.para: Leave not granted.

talk.start.para: âSo you are refusing leave, Bob?
âNo. I said that when I have finished I will give leave. Madam President, what a precious attitude from Senator Lees.
âSenator, I draw your attention to the motion that the Senate is debating at the present time.
âWhile she is guillotining our ability to debate the amendments hereâ

speech.para: Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senators on both sides will stop shouting across the chamber.

âWhile she places her hands on the chainsaws going into the forests around this country through this legislation and while she becomes a pilot in the helicopters dropping the incendiaries on the Tasmanian forests through this legislation, she wants us to accept a management plan which says we have 20 seconds for each amendment, including the Democrat amendments.

speech.para: What has happened in this management plan that we are being asked to accept is that the Democrats have totally acceded to their desire to get to the Howard table and share a bit of power and, in so doing, to chop the head of the Australian environment offâto sell out on their own principles, to sell out on their own past history, to sell out on the groups that are left to fight for the environment now against legislation which makes that so much more difficult.

Senator Lees smiles as she clicks the needles and brings down the guillotine on this debate. This is the lowest ebb in parliamentary performance ever by the Democrats. This process of using the guillotine translates into their hands on the chainsaws when it comes to the Australian environment, and they will not be allowed to forget it.

Already, when you go to public meetings these days, where the Democrats were once welcomed they are now booed. This process is going to make them part of the villainy as far as the continuing destruction of the Australian environment is concerned, and they do not even have the guts to allow a proper debate. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âToday's debate is absolutely the biggest waste of time that this Senate could possibly look at. This is coming from an opposition that rammed through this place 221 bills in 13 years. This is coming from an opposition that is now squealing about the time that is being allocated to each bill. Yet, in 1990ânot all that long ago, if the collective memories of the mob over there could go back to that timeâ
âSenator, you should not refer to the opposition in that fashion.
âThis really forgetful group of people on the opposition benchesâ
âThe Carmen Lawrence problem.

âThat is right, Senator Abetzâthey all suffer from the Carmen Lawrence syndrome. But the problem is that they have forgotten to remember that 52 bills in 1990 were rammed through this Senate in 34 hours. That is not even an hour a bill, and they are squealing today about allocation of time.

speech.para: They rammed through the parliament in one hourânot three days but one hourâcorporations legislation that took three days to get through when they were in opposition. The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1990 took one hour, and the Commonwealth Bank's restructuring bill took three hours. And here we go with this group of people pretending that there is something extraordinary about the behaviour that is going on here. Let us just remember that the tax legislation that is currently before the parliament has had 48 hours of debate thus far in this parliament. And not only that, but it has been looked at by the committee system for the equivalent of 75 weeks. Here we have the Labor Party complaining that there is inadequate time to debate this legislation, but no-one could seriously believe that when they look at 75 weeks of committee consideration and 48 hours of debate in this chamber. Let us have a look at the environment billsâbecause they are also squealing about those. Senator Brown, who is terribly Pontius Pilate about the whole thingâ

talk.start.para: âAnd he has left the chamber now.

âYes, he has left the chamber. He cannot even be bothered staying in the chamber. Those bills have had 11 months of consideration by Senate committees and yet Senator Brown comes in here, flaps his gums and says that we are rushing it through. Fair dinkum! This is just beyond a joke. How on earth can Senator Brown, who is so irrelevant to the Australian political systemâto say nothing of how irrelevant he is in this chamberâcome in here and say that 11 months of Senate committee consideration is inadequate and that we should not now be considering the final votes on the environmental package?

speech.para: I also want to raise the hypocrisy of anyone who tries to say that these important bills are being rammed through. Many of us will remember the native title legislation brought in by the Labor government some years ago. We are talking about new legislation, we are talking about amendments, we are talking about sight unseen things: how about the 300-plus amendments that the Labor Party brought into this chamber once the committee stage had started? Their absolute inefficiency meant that this chamber continued to sit and sit, over the weekends and everything elseâ

talk.start.para: âNo question times.
âNo question times, Senator Campbellâthat is exactly right. Everything was abandoned.

âMadam President, I rise on a point of order. If Senator Knowles is so critical of the Labor Party, why did she provide the Western Australian Labor Party with questions to ask against the Liberal Party of Western Australia?
âThere is no point of order. Senator Knowles.
âThis is the absolute level of Senator Faulkner's comprehension and his gutter tactics. We have got used to that. It is like water off a duck's back. We see it every day in question time.

speech.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! There are far too many people shouting in the chamber, and it is completely disorderly.

âThank you, Madam President. As I said, it is water off a duck's back. To have someone like Senator Faulkner having a go at you is actually quite a compliment because he is just the bottom of the barrel.

speech.para: I will come back to the hypocrisy of this debate. The grizzling about the time allocation for bills is just extraordinary. We have the two masters of guillotines over hereâtwo people who were managers of government business when the Labor Party were in government: Senators Ray and Faulkner. Admittedly, Senator Faulkner was nowhere near up to the job; he was absolutely incompetent in the position. But Senator Ray, who I do believe is a competent operator, was the one who brought in the guillotine time and time again. Yet now Senator Ray is the one who is the most vocal against it. I cannot understand the logic behind that. This is important debating time that should be given to the consideration of important legislation, and yet the Labor Party and the totally irrelevant Senator Brown will not consider it.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time for this debate has concluded. I put the question that the amendment moved by Senator Ray be agreed to.

âMadam President, I rise on a point of order. Before you put the question, I think it would be useful for senators to understand what elements of the order of business today will not proceed if the motion is successful.
âThe motion overrules all other business but question time and motions to take note of answers.

debateinfo.title: ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION BILL 1998 [1999]

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 22 June.

talk.start.para: âI want to table the supplementary explanatory memorandum that you refused me tabling of last night.
âNo, I did not refuse you, Minister. I was given the advice that it would have been better during that particular bill rather than this bill. You can table it whenever you like.

âNow that both of these bills are being debated, I will table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments being moved to this bill, the Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1998 [1999] . The memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 22 June 1999.

âA few points need to be made to clarify the record. We have the Democrats claiming that this legislation is an improvement because the Minister for the Environment and Heritage now has the role of making decisions. What a joke. Anyone who has been involved in government and anyone with a day's experience in this place would understand that there is no such thing as unfettered ministerial discretion. The systems of cabinet and the systems of government are such that a minister consults with other ministers. At the end of the day, matters go to cabinet. For Senator Lees to be saying on radio this morning and here today that this is a major improvement because from now on Senator Hill will make huge decisions in respect of mining, in respect of logging and in respect of protecting the environment is basically a hoax on her supporters and on the Australian public. There is nothing further from the truth.

speech.para: What this legislation does is to actually reduce the transparency of the decision making process. At least under the existing legislation there is transparency and there is publication of decisions and recommenda tions. That will go. The system adopted by the Australian Democrats and pushed by the government will mean no transparency. It will mean less accountability. It will still mean a minister consulting and being, in a sense, influenced by cabinet, but we will not have the same degree of transparency and, consequently, accountability because of the grubby little deal that the Democrats have entered into. Why have they done this? People across Australia are actually asking this morning: why have the Democrats given up their environmental cause?

talk.start.para: âWho are these `people across Australia'?

âI reckon there is one reason, Senator Hill. You can laugh, because you have conned them. You have conned them all the way to this chamber into a situation where we have 25 minutes this morning to discuss 300 amendments.
âI was laughing at your `people across Australia'.

âThat amounts to about 10 seconds at most per amendment. It would be a joke to try to go through them all. The reason they have done this is to save their own skins. We are all asking why. I will tell you what has happened. The government has given them an assurance that they will not change the voting system for the Senate. That is what is behind this. There is no core concern for the environment, no core concern for biodiversity and no core concern for nuclear actions. There is no core concern for anything that they have pretended to be concerned about for such a long time. When it came to the crunch, when they sat down with the government across the table, maybe over a cup of tea, the assurance was given to the Democrats that the government would not change the voting procedures.

speech.para: To save their own skins, they are prepared to jeopardise the skins of so many of their constituents. This is what this is all about. For what other reason would they be rejecting the sorts of amendments that we are putting up this morning? These are the sorts of amendments that will ensure that a federal minister cannot write off any scrutiny or any assessment through the mechanisms of bilateral agreements, declarations or conservation agreements.

These are the things that Senator Allison has railed against for so long, yet these are the things that she now embraces. These are mechanisms to avoid national scrutiny. She said, `We've got six matters of national environmental significance,' but she knows, and Senator Lees should knowâif she does not know, she is incompetent; if she does know, then she is guilty of misleading the public, who do knowâthat these matters of national environmental significance can also be cascaded through to the states. They also know that there is no degree of public accountability and participation that is adequate enough, because they are the sorts of amendments that they are rejecting this morning.

They are rejecting amendments that would introduce a pretty wide range, as opposed to their limited range, of criminal offences. They are rejecting amendments about the protection of critical habitat. They are rejecting amendments that would protect against expansion of the nuclear industry. They say, `We've got an amendment,' but the amendment they have does very little to protect against new generations of industry development in the nuclear industry in Australia.

They are rejecting these amendments either through incompetence or deliberate action. They are rejecting in this batch of amendments a trigger for greenhouse actions. We have circulated one; we are moving one. It is a trigger that has been on the table with the minister for quite some time now. Greenhouse actions are defined in our amendmentâthe trigger is there. Let us spend some time looking at it. We do not maintain that it is perfect. We do maintain, however, that it is within the capacity of this parliamentâand we have had some time to do itâto actually define a greenhouse trigger. But no, this trigger has been rejected by the Australian Democrats as part of the deal to save their own skins. Indigenous people have also been sacrificed in that respect. The Democrats are embracing a concept where, by declaration, a Commonwealth minister can basically exempt Commonwealth land or Commonwealth agencies from the operations of environmental assessment and scrutiny. They are adopting a system where, through bilaterals, this same thing can happen. They say that the bilateral arrangement has been refined. I will get to that in a minute.

They are rejecting proposals for public participation. As I said earlier, they are rejecting proposals to extend nuclear actions to include the establishment or significant modification of nuclear fuel fabrication plants, nuclear reactors and power plants, nuclear storage facilities and enrichment plants. They are rejecting proposals that would ensure that only on the grounds of the security of the Commonwealth, as opposed to this broad, ever-blossoming exemption clause of commercial-in-confidence, will public accountability be excluded. They are rejecting amendments that would ensure that ESD principles are firmly entrenched. They are rejecting amendments to protect world heritage properties. In respect of the Northern Territory there is an agreement, and there is an agreement with respect to bilaterals, but this legislation is nowhere near the benchmark provided for in the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act in so many matters. There are some incremental improvements, but this is not as good.

This deal adopted by the Australian Democrats lets the cause of the environment down enormously. One only has to look at the leading lawyers in this country and their views to come to that conclusion. Associate Professor Rob Fowler, the Director of the Australian Centre for Environmental Law at the Adelaide University, had to work overnight like the rest of us to examine over 500 government amendments. His view is that the Democrats are wrong and misleading on key provisions of this legislation. He is right. It does not take a Rhodes scholar to work out that they have sold out. This is what he says:
The government-Democrat deal on national environment laws expected to be guillotined through the Senate today is fundamentally flawedâ

talk.start.para: âHe is fundamentally wrong.

âHe is a person who gave evidence, Senator Hill, to the parliamentary inquiry, and Senator Allison embraced his evidence and thought he was a great witness. You say he is wrong, but unfortunately for you I think the jury is against you on this one. It is fundamentally flawed, according to one of Australia's leading environmental lawyers. To continue, this is what he says:

speech.para: On the crucial issue of handing Commonwealth responsibilities to the states the amendments added procedural hoops but still allowed delegation of these responsibilities, and comments to the contrary by Senator Lyn Allison are wrong and misleading.

Senator Allison, do you know and are you misleading, or don't you know and should you not be here? The benchmark on this is one that you yourself have created. You are also on the record of that parliamentary committee as saying that Professor Fowler's evidence was amongst the best that we had. Here is the press statement. I am sure it will be an advance on the debate.

Senator Hill says Professor Fowler is wrong. We are talking about a person who has had 25 years of teaching environmental law. Senator Hill, you put your experience up against his; you put your talents and qualities up against his. He is the co-editor of the environment law chapter of the Laws of Australia Compendium of the Law Book of Australia.

talk.start.para: âHaven't you ever come across an academic who is wrong?

âSenator Hill, I have come across more politicians who are wrong than academics who are wrong. I have come across more ministers who have been misled by their departments. What are they adopting? They are adopting a system that is flawed, a system that will give us duplication and a system that will basically accredit not just state laws but laws made under state laws. It will accredit local government authorities. We are moving to a system whereby national responsibility can be divested to the Shire Council of Hervey Bay. If sand mining on Fraser Island is allowed under a management plan accepted in this place, warm and fuzzy as it might appear, then this parliament writes off its powers to intervene and protect against that.

speech.para: I could talk all day about this, but I know Senator Brown and Senator Margetts want to say something as well so I will stop here. I will just say to the Democrats that you are fundamentally flawed, and you will be remembered for this.

Unless you, Madam Temporary Chairman, can suggest a better course of action that may be open to us, it would seem to me that within a limited time frame it would be better to deal with the batch of amendments which have to be voted on at 11.30 a.m.

I also want to respond to a few of the points made by Senator Bolkus in what seemed to be a slightly abbreviated rerun of his second reading debate speech. In actual fact he is quite wrong. This is a major reform of Australia's environmental laws that has been recognised by academics, including the one to which he referred, as long overdue. I do not think I have come across anyone who has objectively and carefully looked at Australia's environmental laws at the Commonwealth level and not found that they are significantly wanting. They are really outdated. They are not in fact immediately triggered by environmental issues at all; they are triggered by actions that might be taken by the Commonwealth government that have no direct relationship to environmental matters at all.

This is the point that I was seeking to make last night: it makes no difference to environmental consequence if the funding of a particular project is funding from overseas that requires a FIRB approval, as opposed to funding internally. It is a nonsense to now say that the Commonwealth should have a responsibility only where it related to the overseas funding and not where it related to the domestic funding. The test, of course, for the Commonwealthâand for Commonwealth interventionâshould be whether it concerns a matter of national environmental significance. It seemed to the governmentâand it actually seemed to others before we came to governmentâthat that was the logical way in which to progress a reform of environment laws in this country. This is bearing in mind that, in the federal system in which we operate, what makes sense is to define what should be the Commonwealth responsibility and, as a consequence of that, to make it clear what remains a state responsibilityâfrom an assessment point of view and also from the point of view of responsibilityâand then to put in place procedures that allow for an interrelationship of the two to achieve a better national outcome.

The Labor Party was awareâas I know when I came to governmentâof these issues and of these representations from the type of academic to which Senator Bolkus has referred. But in their 13 years in government unfortunately they found it too hard, like so many other things, such as the new taxation system that we are going to be debating for the remainder of this week. It remained in the too-hard basket, therefore it did not ever get to the chamber. We acknowledged that the reform was long overdue and that we should tackle it, even though it was complex and politically difficult. We are well aware that there are a range of stakeholders in these debatesâindustry being one, obviously the states being another, conservation groups another, indigenous groups yet anotherâand often it is not easy to find a formula that can meet the satisfaction of all.

Notwithstanding that political difficulty, we decided the time had come and that we should tackle it. We said that the logical starting point was to seek to negotiate with the states on where that dividing line should be between Commonwealth responsibility and state responsibility so that it is much more meaningful to the community than what currently exists. Thus we sought to defineâand I mention this in particular because this is part of the clauses that we are debating, between chapters 2 and 4âmatters of national environmental significance, and there has been considerable debate as to where that line should have been drawn.

We have heard, in the early parts of this debate, the Labor Party list a whole range of other issues that they say should have been included as primary Commonwealth responsibilityâfor example, land clearing. But land clearing was not included because in our view the primary responsibility on issues of natural resource management, such as land clearing, does and should remain with the states. That does not mean that there is not a national interest, and that does not mean that the Commonwealth will not take an active interest in the matter. In fact, as you would know, Madam Temporary Chairman, this government is investing substantial sums of taxpayers' money to revegetate Australia and to protect remnant bushland. This is pursuant to agreements that have been reached between the Commonwealth and the states whereby the states have agreed that they will ensure that action is not taken within their jurisdiction that threatens endangered species or ecological communities and also that they will work towards a reduction of overall land clearing in this country.

The fact that there is still too much land clearing and that overclearing has caused very significant environmental damageâin particular its linkage to dryland salinity and the likeâis not in dispute, and the response must therefore be partnership between the Commonwealth government, the state government and the community. But the primary responsibility in terms of the regulatory response for land clearing must be that of the states: some states have introduced appropriate regulations as a safety net, and some states are still yet to do that. We did not see that the Commonwealth should, in effect, take over that primary role of the states in that regard; the pressure should remain on the states to make sound decisions and the role of Commonwealth should be to support the states and, through them, the community to achieve better outcomes in that very important environmental area.

So that is an example of an issue that is of national importance, but we have not defined it as a matter of national environmental significance in terms of a Commonwealth trigger. By a `trigger', I mean where the Commonwealth is primarily responsible for assessment and approval of an action that might have a detrimental consequence upon that matter of national environmental significance. Our definitions at this stage are more limited than that but they are very significant. I think the most significant one of all is in fact that of endangered species, because it demonstrates a change of attitude by the Australian community. There was a time when endangered species were seen as primarily the responsibility of the states. There is a species in South Australia on the verge of extinction and there is no doubt in my mind at all now that all Australians regard that as a matter of concern to them; a matter in which they expect the involvement of their Commonwealth or national government. We have listed matters of endangered species as a matter of national environmental significance, so an action that might have a detrimental effect upon such a species would require assessment and approval at the Commonwealth level.

That takes us to the other important part of these chapters. Whilst we acknowledge that the Commonwealth should take primary responsibility for these areas of national environmental significance, such as endangered species, world heritage, Ramsar internationally listed wetlands and the like, it is also not always appropriate for the Commonwealth to carry out the assessment process itself. This is because the states are physically closer to the action for which the consent is being sought. They have the bureaucracies on the ground that are often better able to carry out this work than the Commonwealth. Therefore, it seems to us, again in a system where we have a cooperative relationship between the different tiers of government, that there will be circumstances when it will be better for the state to carry out an assessment process for the Commonwealth. It might surprise some in the chamber to learn that that actually occurs now, but it occurs on an ad hoc basis.

What we are more interested in is putting in a process that can give the public confidence that, when the state is carrying out that assessment process for the Commonwealth, it is carrying it out according to best contemporary practice. So we have developed this concept of bilateral agreements between the Commonwealth and the states that will allow the states, in certain circumstances, to assess for the Commonwealth the consequences of a particular action and, in even more limited circumstancesâbut there is no surprise in that because we have said it to the states all alongâto even make an approval for the Commonwealth, pursuant to bilateral agreements.

There was concernâand I concede that concernâby some that this might mean, in practice, a passing of responsibility from the Commonwealth to the states. A number of the amendments that we have before us in these parts that we are debating today are to ensure that the responsibility of the Commonwealth is not passed while we pass the administrative role. It was never our intention that that responsibility pass but, nevertheless, we accepted that the community has a right to be confident beyond our assertions to that fact. We are building in with these amendments a number of processes of public participation, greater transparency and, in certain limited instances, even the capacity to disallow by this body.

On the issue which is more likely to happen in practiceâthe state carrying out an assessment for the Commonwealthâit may not be that that bilateral agreement will be through regulation that will set out the benchmarks, although that will be our goal and we will be heading down that path forthwith upon the passage of this bill. But if it is impossible for us to get the agreement of the chamber to that bilateral agreementâin other words, if it were disallowedâwe would still be able to proceed. We are confident that we can get an agreement of best practice in relation to assessments that can be put in the form of regulation and that will not be disallowed. But we have the two fall backs, and I think this is important to industry. Those fall backs are that we can proceed under the state agreement, if we have made our best efforts, and we always have the alternative of being able to carry out the assessment ourselves.

In relation to approvals, which are of even greater concern to some conservation groups, as I said, there are further restrictions. That is not surprising, because when the responsibility is passed to the Commonwealth by legislation it would be an unusual experience indeed for a Commonwealth minister to say that the state minister can make the decisionâthat is, the decision rather than the processâfor the Commonwealth minister. We have demonstrated, particularly in relation to Shark Bay, that it is possible under management agreements that have been approved by the Commonwealth minister, that meet the best contemporary standards, that within such limited circumstances that responsibility can be passed. But we have said, as an extra safeguard, that that will be disallowable in this place. Of course, if it is disallowed, although I do not think it will be, it will revert to the Commonwealth responsibility. So industry does not miss out in that it is not delayed, and also the system will work.

Why do I say that this will be unnecessary? It is really because what we are planning in the development of the bilateral agreements is a transparent process. We want the involvement of the community in that process; we want the involvement of parliamentary parties. That is why we sought to negotiate these amendments with the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Greens, but neither were interested. If after the passage of this bill they do want to be involvedâI hope the Australian Democrats will also be involved in the development of these bilateralsâto ensure that we are adopting best international practice, we would be very pleased to engage their participation. (Time expired)

para.inline: 33 Making declaration that actions do not need approval under Part 9
Declaration of actions not needing approval

interjection.para: (1) The Minister may declare in writing that actions in a class of actions specified in the declaration wholly or partly by reference to the fact that their taking has been approved by the Commonwealth or a specified Commonwealth agency, in accordance with a management plan that is an accredited management plan for the purposes of the declaration, do not require approval under Part 9 for the purposes of a specified provision of Part 3.
Note 1: Subdivisions C and D set out rules about prerequisites for making a declaration and limits on making a declaration.
Note 2: Section 35 provides for revocation of a declaration.
What is an accredited management plan ?

(2) A management plan is an accredited management plan for the purposes of a declaration that certain actions do not require approval under Part 9 for the purposes of a specified provision of Part 3 if and only if the management plan:
(a) is in force under a law of the Commonwealth identified in or under the declaration; and
(b) has been accredited in writing by the Minister in accordance with this section for the purposes of the declaration.

(3) For the purposes of subsection (2), the Minister may accredit by written instrument a management plan for the purposes of a declaration. However, the Minister may do so only if the Minister is satisfied that:
(a) the management plan and the law under which it is in force (or is to be in force) meet the criteria prescribed by the regulations; and
(b) there has been or will be adequate assessment of the impacts that actions approved in accordance with the plan:
(i) have or will have; or
(ii) are likely to have;
on each matter protected by a provision of Part 3 to which the declaration relates; and

(c) actions approved or taken in accordance with the management plan will not have unacceptable or unsustainable impacts on a matter protected by a provision of Part 3 to which the declaration relates.
The Minister must publish in accordance with the regulations (if any) the instrument accrediting the management plan.
Note: Subdivision C sets out more prerequisites for accrediting a plan.

talk.start.para: âCan the minister please explain what that amendment does?

âI am quite happy to talk for some time on the subject of forestry, because it is an important issue and it should be clarified. The government has taken the view that the process of regional forest agreements is outside of this legislation because they have been in themselves a most comprehensive processâI think one can fairly say the most comprehensive assessment of Australian forests in our national history. The government chose to take that course of actionâwhich, I concede, was to adopt a national strategy that had been negotiated between the previous Labor government and the statesâbecause it, for the first time, set out a framework within which there could be some certainty for forest industries but with a background of protecting a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system and also to ensure that the forestry that was to take place in relation to native forests, on the balanceâthat is, that which is outside the comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve systemâhad to be conducted in both an ecologically and economically sustainable way.

speech.para: The precedent of that structure is regarded as world best practice. I can recall two years ago, for example, attending a CSD meeting in New York when WWF International held up the Australian precedent as the example that they would like to be achieved globally, because the reserve system was of course of a higher composition than the recommendations that they were putting down internationally. Also just as important is to ensure that the forest that is to be harvested is harvested, as I said, not only in an economic wayâwhich is what has been considered in the pastâbut also in an ecologically sustainable way.

We went about the task of conducting those assessments. I would be the first to acknowledge just how difficult that process has been. Nevertheless, those RFAs that have been agreedâthe RFA for Tasmania, the RFA in Western Australia and two RFAs in Victoria, in Central Highlands and East GippslandâI think have achieved the goals that Labor actually had set down for us in the National Forest Strategy. I am pleased to say that we are very close to completion of the agreement for the Eden region in New South Wales. We are close to another agreement in Victoria. We are finally making some progress on the balance of regions in New South Wales and with regard to the Queensland proposal. Whilst it has been politically difficult and it has been difficult in practice to implement, we are achieving those goals.

After such a comprehensive assessment as that it makes no sense, to the government in any event, to then come back through this legislation and seek to achieve another path for assessment. That is why we have chosen to take the course of action of leaving the RFAs outside of the bill as such. I can see that there are others in the chamber who would argue that that is not the best course of action to have taken. We have a difference of view in this particular matter, but that is the basis on which we have taken this action.

I make the point because I want to demonstrate, in case it is misrepresented by some, such as Senator Brown, as an attempt to avoid the responsibility for assessment and for making proper decisions in relation to natural forests, that it is quite the contrary. It is in recognition that there has been a parallel process of a comprehensive nature to carry out those assessments and to achieve the best possible outcomes both environmentally and economically. That is the reason we have moved in this direction.

talk.start.para: âHere we get to the heart of this terrible business. The minister has just tried to say that the forests are outside of this legislation. speech.para: I read earlier from a letter from world noted scientist Dr Aila Keto of the Australian Rainforest Conservation Society, who is also representing another dozen conservation groups in Queensland. This legislation would not be going throughâthis imprimatur of the Democrats on the regional forest agreements, as laid out in this legislationâexcept for their going to the Howard table last week to gain a little bit of power and, in the process, as entry to that table, dropping all of their past principles. Let me read from section 39 on page 40:
The purpose of this Subdivisionâ
Chair, you will understand if I interpret this now by saying that it is the purpose of this now Democrat approved subdivisionâ
is to ensure that an approvalâ
that is, a ministerial approval before something dastardly is done to the environmentâ
under Part 9 is not required for forestry operations in a region for whichâ

a regional forest agreement is in place. What we have here, with the approval of the Democrats, is the minister washing his hands, for 20 years at a national level, of responsibility for the great forests of Western Australia; the wild forests and their wildlife in Victoria and New South Wales; the forests of south-east Queensland; and the forests of world heritage value in such places as the Sticks, Huon, Weld and Picton valleys in Tasmania, the Great Western Tiers, the Tarkine, the North-East and the Tasman Peninsula, just to name some of them.

Democrat approved chainsaws are now moving in on these forests, these ecosystems and this wildlife. When the Democrat approved chainsaws have gone in and felled the forests which the woodchippers want to takeâand they are taking 90 per cent of the trees; Senator Murphy might have something to say about what an economic and resource abuse that isâand have sent those trees through the paper mills of Kyoto and Tokyo to the rubbish dumps of the Northern Hemisphere, now approved by the Democrats, the next thing is that the incendiaries will move in.

We have before this Senate at the moment a change in civil aviation regulations to reduce the qualifications required for those pilots who take helicopters or light planes over these ancient forestsâonce they have been felled and the woodchippers have taken out what they wantâand drop thousands of incendiaries to create a firestorm. This is happening at the end of every season in Tasmania. Thousands of hectares of these ancient forests have been felledârainforests included. Indeed, the Democrat purpose here has become, through those incendiaries, to kill the cotyledonsâthe little growth opportunities for new rainforest treesâthe root systems and any living fur, feather or flower left in this recently ancient ecosystem so that genetically manipulated eucalypts, fast growing for the woodchippers' purposes, will replace them. That is what the Democrats are giving their approval to.

The Democrats have now, through their imprimatur on this legislation, approved the bringing in of 1080 to these wild forests to be sprinkled through the fire holocaust area. Any marsupialsâwallabies, potoroos or possumsâwhich hop in from adjacent forests to forage on these genetically manipulated little eucalypt seedlings will be poisonedâmurdered by this Democrat action. Senator Bartlett from Queensland, who has been something of an advocate for Animal Liberation but is now a 1080 poisoner, is going to get up here in a minute and tell us that the Democrats have an amendment which they expect the Labor Party and the Greens to join with them in putting through here that will overturn this particular part of the legislation. Let me explain. They went to the table and said to the government, `We want different provisions for the forests. This legislation removes all federal powers to stop it. But the government said no. These Democrat puppies, these poodles of Liberal politics, put their tails between their legs and accepted that. What the Democrats are doing here is giving their stamp of approval to the destruction of the forests for the next 20 years. I cannot accept this pathetic little effort to try to cover up their tracks and deceive their membership, conservationists or anybody else out thereâand 87 per cent of people, according to recent West Australian polls, do not want this Democrat destruction of the forests. I cannot accept their little effort to try to deceive people into thinking that they really do care.

Every tree in those forests that dies, every owl's nesting place, every possum, every endangered speciesâlike the great Tasmanian wedgetail, which is bigger than the mainland species, or the white goshawk, which is down to 200 breeding pairs, as I told the Senate two days agoâis now pushed closer to extinction because of Senator Allison, who laughs over there in her seat; because of Senator Bartlett; because of Senator Stott Despoja, who stayed absent from this debate but put her signature on the bottom of this death warrant for forests; because of Senator Lees; because of Senator Murray from Western Australia; and because of Senator Woodley from Queensland. These are the environmental sell-out people.
Senator Bartlett interjectingâ
Senator Allison interjectingâ
