talk.start.para: âA number of times during that last contributionâif you can call it thatâthere were frequent comments as to the laughter coming from the Democrats benches. I guess it is a bit hard not to laugh at such a joke, and it is a bit of a shame that someone that did have such credibility on environmental issues in the past has allowed himself to be reduced to that. As I said yesterday, it seems that it can happen occasionally in politicsâpeople have been in it for so long that they forget what they are in it for. I guess that, as Senator Brown has been a politician for around 18 years or so, obviously he now sees his role as a politician as trying to out-compete people like Senator Faulkner and Senator Ray with vitriol, abuse and gross distortions. If that is the way that he wants to perform his role, that is fine. But it is a bit of a shame that someone who does have the opportunity toâand is seen as someone who previously was able toâput forward arguments on behalf of the environment is willing to sacrifice credibility for the sake of what he obviously sees as nothing more than a political opportunity to bash the Democrats.

speech.para: That, I suppose, demonstrates how much, sadly, he has just simply become a politician that is interested in nothing else but ignoring what he was originally there forâto try and protect the environmentâand has simply turned into someone that is willing to seize a political opportunity to attack other political parties that he sees as his opponents. In doing so of courseâas highlighted throughout his previous contributionâhe is quite willing to misrepresent the facts, distort the facts and completely ignore the facts for the basis of what he sees as his own political campaign. He has obviously chosen to take on that role, and that is a shame, from my point of view, because I would rather see as many credible voices as possible in the parliament promoting and trying to save the environment. It is a bit of an unfortunate situation that he has chosen to ignore that role.

I would make a plea to the conservation groups who work so hard for so little recognition in such a dedicated manner throughout the country to think carefully about this issue. There are clearly differences of opinion amongst conservation groups at the moment. Some of them are still reacting to the significant concerns that the Democrats identified, in conjunction with them during the committee process, with the original bill and have not yet been able to recognise that what the Democrats have achieved here is a major advance for the environment. If they wish to simply take a role of attacking the legislation as a whole and trying to knock off those advances, whether they like to or not they will be associating themselves with the sort of nonsense that Senator Brown is willing to go on withâthat, somehow or other, the Democrats are responsible for clear-felling Tasmanian forests.

Of course, for every mention of the word `Democrats' in his previous contributionâhow we have now got our hands on the chainsaw and all of that sort of nonsenseâyou could go through that speech, cross out `Democrats' and put in `Tasmanian Conservation Trust', who have approved the amendments that the Democrats have managed to gain to this legislation as a significant advance for the environment. So he may as well be criticising the Tasmanian Conservation Trustâand all of those people in the environment movement who have praised this agreementâas equally having their hands on the chainsaws and as equally gleefully staffing the bulldozers.

If he wants to try and divide the environment movement that he as a person has done so much to build up in the past, it is a bit sad. He has now got to a stage where he is willing to use his position as a politician to try and divide and weaken the environment movement that previously he has contributed so much to. That is a shame, but the real problem is in relation to an issue for the environment groups, and I would urge them to consider that. Certainly, as Democrats we have no problem with them calling it as they see it. I know that some of those who have concerns with this amended legislation are doing so. They are going through it and are willing to call it as they see itâas they understand itâas they try to avoid some of the absurd statements that Senator Brown makes. But they do need to be careful that their credibility as environmental advocates is not tarnished if they allow themselves to be associated with such nonsense. It is a shame that for political purposes that sort of risk and that sort of threat is being put to the environment movement.

The issue that we are debating at the moment concerns forests. It is one of the areas where the Democrats, as much as anybody else, have highlighted that there is a failing in this bill. It is an issue on which the Democrats, as much as anybody else, have pledged to continue to fight to protect our forests. But the obvious fact, which has been confirmed by Senator Brown's speech, is that the destruction to the forests is happening nowâit is happening now under existing lawsâand this parliament is powerless to do anything about it. What we are doing in this legislation in many areas is providing opportunities, for the first time, for the parliament to do something about it. Senator Brown wants to prevent that opportunity and that extra avenue of activity from being able to occur. The Democrats will not ignore the advances that have been achieved in so many areas in protecting the environment through this overall set of amendments simply because we will not be able to ensure that the forests are protected. But we will continue to try and do that. As indicated, we will be moving amendments to put forests back into the bill and to include forests as a trigger.

One of the useful aspects of this debate has been that it has served to rekindle the interests of the Australian Labor Party in the environment. Many Labor Party members who were in the chamber earlier todayânot so many are in here nowâwere suddenly playing the role of being major supporters of the environment. Given that there has been such a lack of any policy position from the Labor Party on the environment since the last election, hopefully this will serve as an opportunity for them to develop a policy on the environment and to put forward indications about what they would do if they were in government. This debate gives them a chance to indicate their policy and to give public statements on how they would protect the environment if they were in government. They have spoken previously about greenhouse. This debate gives them a chance to get their state Labor colleagues in Queensland to come out and say, `We will support greenhouse being put in place as an environment trigger.' The Democrats would welcome them on board because it would give us an opportunity to put that into the legislation, adding to the other gains that have already been made in this area.

As I have said previously, the Democrats do not say that the bill is perfect. As amended, we see it as a significant advance. It is equally important that we highlight the gaps that still exist. The issue of forests is one of those gaps that still exist and where improvements desperately need to be made. Attempts are being made to put around a big fabrication that the inability to address that issue some how leads us to a situation where the forests have even less protection than they have now. That is false. There are any number of indications and explanations that you could give to outline why so many aspects of this legislation are an improvement, but this was probably summarised quite well by Stephen Lunn in today's Australian with the simple headline, `New laws an improvement, but major concerns remain'. That would just about be an assessment of the Democrats' view: this legislation is a significant improvement, but we still have major concerns that we will continue to work on.

The initial comment by Stephen Lunn, leading into his article, was, `The system was broke and needed fixing.' There is still some fixing work to be done, but at least we have a vehicle that will provide us with a better opportunity to make further advances in those areas where there are still significant concerns. This aspect of the legislation that we are debating at the moment deals with the issue of forests. It is an area where the Democrats will be moving amendments to take out the exemption clauses for forests in the bill. I have not seen any amendments put forward by the Labor Party in that regard but, given their new-found concern for the environment, I am sure they will be supporting us in our amendments.

It is equally important, when looking at the whole issue of how we address the legislation and the issue of forests in future, to look at how we can best ensure that mechanisms are in place and that we have a legislative vehicle to make further improvements. This forests section that we are dealing with is a significant problem and it needs to be removed from the bill, because our forests are being destroyed. That is something that is recognised by all conservation groups, including all of those that have supported the amendments and the improvements that the Democrats have managed to achieve.

We have had a lot of involvement through the committee process with conservation groups in the process of developing our amendments. Again, we have heard a lot today about the lack of ability to examine issues because of the need to ensure that these achievements are passed by the parliament before it rises. However, this bill has been subject to a significant number of committee hearings over a long period and the concerns addressed in the amendments that the Democrats have gained support for are based on all of the input from conservation and indigenous groups during the inquiry.

Despite all the noise from Senator Brown, when we look at what he does in his role as a parliamentarian to try to advance the environment, and when we ask how many times he turned up to any of the committee hearings on the environment legislation to hear what the concerns of environment groups were, to ask questions and to try to put the government on the spot about what it was doing, the answer is zero. Senator Brown is quite able to come in here, be the politician and see how he can compete with Senator Faulkner and Senator Ray in the abuse stakes but, when it comes to doing anything other than abusing the Democrats and significant proportions of the environment movement throughout Australia, there is nothing else there; there is nothing else to fall back on.

Let us actually look at what has been achieved by Senator Brown in his role in the Senate on environment issues and at how many amendments he has actually had passed in respect of environment legislation in his time here. Having examined his record on improving things for the environment, I can say that he has had one amendment passed in respect of environment legislation, back in 1997. All seven disallowance motions he has moved have been negatived, the urgency motion has been negatived, and the two references to committees have been negatived. His sole contribution, in terms of a concrete outcome, has been one amendment. Obviously, he makes frequent contributions in terms of hurling abuse at the Democrats, trying to attack the Democrats for political purposes and trying to now split the environment movement to get them onside as an attack weapon against the Democrats for his own political purpose.

I guess we can look at how successful he has been in that regard as well. The other day he was calling on myself and Senator Stott Despojaâas everybody knows, we have indicated our unwillingness to support the tax legislationâand saying, `You disagree with this legislation; you should quit the party if you are serious.' I suppose that shows the obvious consequence of that: if every time you disagreed with other people and your colleagues you split the party, you would end up with a pretty small party pretty quickly. Perhaps that is why Senator Brown is in a party of one, and perhaps why he has achieved only one amendment in his time here.

We are quite willing to work through our differences, and I hope the conservation movement are willing and able to work through their differences constructively. We certainly look forward to working with them in an ongoing fashion constructively in lots of the opportunities that have been gained through passing this legislation as amended. We are quite happy to hear their concerns and to take their criticisms about the areas that still need work, and we will do that constructively. If we have concerns or disagreements about their assessments, we will discuss that with them. That is the measure of the Democrats' work and the approach we are going to take, and we are going to keep doing that because we are here to get gains for the environment.

talk.start.para: âThe issue that we are dealing with here is in relation to forests. The reason that we are dealing with it is because it is one of the triggers that do not exist under this new legislation. The quite clear information that was provided in the report that was signed by the Greens and the Democrats in relation to this bill indicated that the original bill was abysmal in terms of how it was to be a vehicle to wind back the Commonwealth's responsibilities. That was clear, and there was a solid bank of opinion.

speech.para: The government and Democrat amendments barely change this abysmal situation. The only changes are those at the margin in terms of ensuring adequate and effective Commonwealth roles. The bill remains a major step backwards. There is no way of getting around this. To borrow the words of Senator Stott Despoja regarding the Reith-Kernot agreement in relation to industrial relations, it is draconian legislation only marginally improved. That goes for this legislation as well. Quantity should not be confused with quality. Maybe 20 per cent of those are what is needed for good environmental legislation and have been achieved, not the 80 per cent that has been claimed. The numbers do not actually relate to the quality of the concerns that people have.

Make no mistake: the government still have a number of triggersâthat is, a mere sixâand it will not be hard to give them exemptions for every one of these. When we are talking about endangered species, if the issue focuses on the clearance of their habitat, the government will weasel out of it if they can.

There is an urgent need, as many people have said, for a greenhouse trigger. Where are the commitments by the government to do other than consult with the states? I have not seen a single promise from the government about doing anything other than consult. With respect to land clearance and water, what do the Democrats claim? I cannot find a single amendment that relates to land clearing, water or the stating of the obvious situationâthat something may be regulated if it affects the NES matter about which they are claiming to have achieved a partial result, even if the probability of significant land clearance being stopped is minuscule.

As for the forests, which is what this bunch of amendments is about, the Democrats have not achieved anything. They have not even consulted with the Greens on the matter, despite knowing how concerned we are about the exemption of forests from the bill. This lack of consultation is now par for the course. Just consulting with a few select groups, when it should have been possible to consult all in the process, illustrates the tactics that the Democrats have learnt from the governmentâthat is, pick off the groups that you think may be easily scared. If we are talking about threats, the major threat, as has been mentioned, comes out in this Democrat release, which says:

It was clear to the Democrats that the ALP-Greens strategy was an extremely risky one. If Senators Harradine and Colston supported the bill, the Democrats would have had to start to argue for the very substantial amendments required on the floor of the chamber.
Shock, horror! The release continues:
Clearly, this would have exposed the environment to unacceptable risk. There was much to lose and the potential for real gains was ignored.

The government said their priority in this section of the parliamentary program was the tax package. The government said that again and again and again. For public credibility, the agreement should have been that, if the government's priority was the tax package, the time priority should also have been for the tax package.

We are not in a situation where this Senate has been debating the committee stage of this bill for days on end, even though it is important enough to have done so and the number of amendments and the complexity would warrant that happening. We are not in that situation. The gag was imposed before we even started on the committee stage of an environment bill. So, here we are dealing with, in my understanding, an unprecedented situation where a minor party in this case is using a gag in a situation where they themselves have argued in the opposite direction in the past. Where is the logic? I have thought and thought to see where that logic is. The only answer I can get is about as unkind as I can be at this stage, which is that in the recent past there has been a situation where the Democrats wanted to regain a seat in Western Australia. Of course, they have won thatâto my loss, to the green network's loss and, I believe, now obviously to the wider network's loss because we know what they will do with that power. They have already signed up to it. With that loss of competition, temporarily, from Western Australiaâhey, there is no need to be put down as the true green party and no need to appeal to that electorate because they think they have got it sewn up.

I do not usually make statements like this but this is all I can think of that must have been in the minds of the Australian Democrats in reaching this decision. We saw yesterday quite clearly that they did not have to be pushed at this time. We saw they had a golden opportunity to say, `Let's listen to what Aboriginal groups, peak conservation groups and the wider community are saying and let's leave this committee stage until the August sittings. Let's make sure that the new bill'âwhich it isâ`is then given a chance for consultation.' No, not good enough. The opportunity was here. It was not taken. So, it was a nonsense to suggestâand I believe it was an unfair threat to the environment movement in Australia to do soâthat they had to make a decision then because otherwise something worse would happen. Unfortunately, the worse thing that is going to happen is that after the end of June we are not even going to have a say. I am certainly not going to have a say on these issues. There won't even be this concern by the Democrats that there might be someone else around from Western Australia at least to show where they are wrong in their statements and where they are not representing their electorates, which they promised to do. All of the statements, all of those leaflets, about protection of the forest are now clearly shown to be false because they have let down that community, let down that electorate, unnecessarily.

The Democrats assert that the disallowable nature of the management plans will ensure stringency. I can only foreshadow that exactly the same thing could happen with any disastrous plans of management as is happening with this bill. We do not know now that the Democrats will not be thrown some crumbs in order to pass it because, when nobody that I know of can understand why this decision is being made now and rushed on and pushed on without debate and gagged, I cannot guaranteeâand I do not think anyone can guaranteeâwhat would happen if those disallowances come to the Senate. Since the plans of management can only be disallowed and not amended, those crumbs will be in some totally different area and the Australian people will be left with bilateral agreements that give the Commonwealth power.

Note that the Democrats and government did not support the Greens' amendment to retain even a Commonwealth reserve power so that the Commonwealth can intervene in, say, a development project if state processes are totally inadequate. Madam Chair, as I say, the reasons behind this deal originally escaped me, but I do recall that Senator Lees went through a `pick me, pick me' stage in relation to the consultation and sell-out in relation to tax. The only thing that I can suggest is that after the `pick me, pick me' it became very hard to move away from the table. There are also people, I admit, from the environment movement who were attracted to that feeling of power at the table. It is very difficult for people in that situation not to see how badly they are being done overâand unfortunately they were.

The environment movement, yes, has been divided in this process. It has not been the Greens dividing that movement. The movement was very clear and has put in hours of work. And I know because I have seen people in my office from environmental defenders and we have put in many hours. I have had a volunteer worker working with me day in, day out for months on this issue. You cannot talk to me about the work that has been done, because I know that that work has now been betrayed for the sake of the Democrats and some people from the environment movement who thought it would be good to be at the table, despite the fact there was no need for them to be forced to be there.

If Senator Harradine or Senator Colston had considered that they wanted to pass this bill, the indications were not here yesterday. But even if they had, if I were in that situation I would not want my name on that bill. The government are laughing all the way to the bank. They cannot believe that the Democrats have put themselves in this situation of taking the heat for what in fact is the government's abysmal bill; and that is what has happened. The government cannot believe their luck. If this deal had been made, carried on and debated after the 30 June, there would be no clearer indication that it was a Democrat deal. At the moment the Democrats can pretend that they had to do it because something worse might happen if they had not. After 30 June there would have been no excuse and that is the reason why we are being forced to vote on this now; that is the reason why our forests will get no further protection and that is the reason why we are being restricted to six matters in a very narrow way that is worse than what exists now.

The minister and other ministers in this government have clearly said they do not want people asking about wider issues if there was an export power involved. They do not want people, for legitimate reasons, questioning very bad decisions by state governments. The federal government do not want to deal with it and this is what has been achieved in this bill. It is no wonder it is being rushed through now. It is no wonder that the amendments by non-government parties have not even been allowed to be put. I have been here six years and I have never seen that situation in the Senate before. Okay, lots of things happen in the House of Representatives, but this is supposed to be the states' house. This is supposed to be the people's house. I have never seen a situation like this where cross benchers, in a party that is supposed to be about the environment, have denied the right of minor parties to put their amendments.

Was this part of the original agreement and, if it was not, I believe the Democrats would have had the right to say to the government, `All bets are off unless you give other people the chance to put their amendments. This is not part of our agreement and all bets are off.' There is still the opportunity for the Democrats to say that all bets are off unless we have a proper debate; that all bets are off unless we have the chance to scrutinise these bills in a democratic way so that people can see what we have agreed to.

But no, I have not seen this. Even if we voted on them all at the end of the time, all in a lump, how meaningless that process has become. I believe that the people from my own state of Western Australia will be feeling very betrayed as a result of what has gone on in the last couple of days. Some people thought there would be some deals associated, but I do not think very many people realised how bad this would be in relation to the forests, which is what these amendments are. In my state I know that people have very, very long memories.

talk.start.para: âI just wanted to respond in relation to the forests and point out that the Greens have had so many opportunities in this place to make a difference on matters of forest protection and have taken up none of them. What I find so extraordinary is that, when the government brings forward environmental reform legislation which is designed to achieve better national environmental outcomes, it gets damned by the Greens without any willingness to contribute to developing a process to achieve a better outcome.

speech.para: We offered the Greens, as we offered the Australian Labor Party, the opportunity to work with us towards better environmental outcomes. I know that as a matter of principle Senator Bob Brown will not work with the government, no matter what the consequence. No matter what benefit he could get for the environment, he still will not work with the government to achieve that benefit. I do not understand it. I presume it is just something to do with his past when he made his name as a confrontationist and became a hero to the green movement as it then was. He is concerned that by now moving on and being prepared to negotiate better environmental outcomes would in some way put him at risk with his very small remaining constituency. I can only assume that that is what this is all about. I regret that. When we look back at the opportunities that Senator Brown has had over the past few years to achieve better environmental outcomes in this place we see that he has wasted the whole lot. I just cannot understand why the remainder of his green constituency stands by him.

When I look at the advantagesâand I see nothing wrong with this at allâthat Senator Harradine, for example, has been able to achieve for Tasmania, I would have thought that Senator Brown, also being a Tasmanian senator and one who claims to be here representing an environment constituency, would have recognised that he had the opportunity to win some real gains for the environment. But has he ever come to our door and said, `I want a better green outcome and this is my proposition'? Of course not. When we come to him and say, `Do you want to participate in a process to achieve a better green outcome?', he washes his hands of us. In other words, to preserve his political stature with what remains of his constituency, he sacrifices the opportunity to achieve a better environmental outcome.

I know that is Senator Brown and there is nothing much we can do about it, but I would have thought Senator Margetts, who I know has a genuine interest in the forests of Western Australia, would have approached this matter differently. I would have thought she would say, `If the government is going to embark upon a major environmental reform, this is a wonderful opportunity for the green parties to become involved in the process to seek to achieve some of our aspirations.' Is that not logical? Is there some major flaw in my logic? But of course they will not do so. In other words, she has been wedded to the Bob Brown style of politics which is not to work with governments to achieve better outcomes but to go out there and run the old battles of the past and to try to achieve what? Notoriety, personal notoriety. That is the aspiration of Senator Bob Brown and it is very much a regret to me that Senator Margetts is prepared to lock herself into the same political mentality and sacrifice the opportunities that she has had to achieve better green outcomes.

How could negotiating with the government to achieve a better green outcome be described as selling out her principle? How does Senator Margetts know if she has never tried, if she refuses to participate in a process? How can she assume that the outcome would not have achieved any of her goals? That is the fundamental flaw in the position of both the green members of this Senate, and I think it is very much a matter of regret, not for me of course but for the environment, because there are people out there that have elected Senator Brown and Senator Margetts because they actually thought that they would make a difference. But as has been demonstrated today, they have not made a difference at all. They have wasted their time in this place. They certainly have looked for political notoriety, particularly in the case of Senator Brown, but they have achieved no outcomes for their constituency.

They can stand up and say `We've fought the good fight, we belt the government every day', but that does not get a better environmental outcome. Why don't they join with the 4,000-odd Landcare groups and conservation groups and get out there into the forest and do something worth while for the forests.

I wanted to make a few comments on this chapter of the bill because it is the first conservation of biodiversity law at a federal level in Australia's history. We have had a situation where Australia is a party to the International Convention on the Protection of Biodiversity, and some years ago there was in fact a strategy for the conservation of biodiversity negotiated between the Commonwealth and the states. Regrettably, the last Labor government did not take the one extra step and set up a legal framework at the Commonwealth level to implement its commitments under that strategy. We are very pleased that the Howard government has been prepared to take the initiative and provide for Australia its first law for the conservation of biodiversity.

The amendments to the chapter improve the provisions for management of species and ecological communities and of protected areas, and also they continue the statutory office of the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service, which I will come back to in a minute. The amendments provide for increased recognition of the important role of indigenous peoples in conserving biodiversity and managing jointly managed Commonwealth reserves. In particular, representatives of the traditional owners will have the power to withhold consent, within reason, to the appointment to the joint management board of a person nominated by the Northern Territory. The amendments provide increased transparency for listing species and ecological communities and for decisions about permits relating to them. Strict liability is applied to some offences or elements of offences. It will now be possible to list key threatening processes purely on the basis of scientific criteria. Whilst I mention key threatening processes, it also overcomes the technical deficiency in the previous legislation which meant that a process could not be listed if it crossed the boundary between state and Commonwealth jurisdictions. So some of those matters that were not listed on a technical basis could be reconsidered in the future.

I would also take the opportunity to thank the volunteers, really, within the scientific community who have given us advice, and so much sound advice, in endangered species areas. In fact, the men and women on the advisory bodies that we have in this areaâthe biodiversity advisory body, our threatened species scientific body and threatened species advisory bodyâdo play a very important part in the conservation of our biodiversity through the assistance that they give to government and in the community leadership that they provide. It is not sufficiently or often enough recognised, and I am pleased to do so today. Also, the capacity to proclaim conservation zones to afford interim protection to the areas while their values are assessed will be retained.

I said I wanted to come back to the matter of the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service. Although there has been much comment about the number of amendments before the chamber, in fact many of those amendments simply relate to reinstatement of that position. It is no secret that we in the government believe that there was opportunity within this legislation to streamline administrative structures in relation to environmental protection and as such to remove what some would say is simply another tier in the structureâthat is, the position of the director as a statutory officerâand then have a more clearly defined line of command and responsibility between government and the decision making process in relation to national parks.

That policy preference was consistent with the stand this government has taken across portfoliosâthat where possible separate statutory authorities should be removed. Regrettably, in the past so many have been created really as a cushion for government, and in particular for ministers, to avoid having to take direct responsibility. That is not the view of this government. This government believes that ministers should take responsibility for decisions that are made and not pass that responsibility off to third parties in the form of statutory authorities. Having said that, and still believing that it would be sound administrative restructuring, it was strongly objected to by the joint boards, to which we are a party, for, in particular, Kakadu National Park and Uluru.

After sitting down with the traditional owners on a number of occasionsâit is interesting, because I have heard in this debate those on the other side asserting that there was no consultation on this issue with indigenous peopleâI have not been able to convince them that the removal of the position would not be seen as some symbolic downgrading of the relationship. Of course, it was the director who signed the leases. Out of respect to the traditional owners, I therefore took the decision to not proceed with that proposed reform. Of course, to reinstate the position of director has meant that many clauses have had to be re-amended, and that makes up a large block of the amendments that are before us today. That is why we revised our opinion on this matter. It does in fact demonstrate that consultation does work and that this government is prepared to listen. Where a decision is going to cause distress, even though we might think it is sound administrative practice, we will vote to avoid distress.

In relation to the Northern Territory representative, we are not moving from our strong commitment that the administration of both parks would be enhanced by a Northern Territory representative. But I would like to stress, contrary to what was asserted in the Senate yesterday, that we are talking about one person, one representative, on boards that have a majority of traditional owners. Furthermore, what we are providing through these amendments is that the nominated representative must be approved by the traditional ownersâin other words, it will be with the consent of the traditional owners. We have provided that that consent will not be unreasonably withheld, because unfortunately in my experience third parties, including the ALP, put considerable pressure upon traditional owners in these matters. I listened to the ALP's presentation yesterday in relation to the Northern Territory, and it was a totally unjustified and unreasonable condemnation of the Northern Territory government. I have to say that, based on my dealings with the new Chief Minister in the Northern Territory, he is somebody who wants to build a good working relationship with indigenous Territorians, as they were called in the debate yesterday. I say that that is something that should be recognised and applauded.
Progress reported.

subdebateinfo.title: Member for Leichhardt: East Trinity Development

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. When did Mr Entsch raise with the minister the issue of acid sulphate soils at East Trinity near Cairns? In what context did he raise this? Was the minister aware at the time Mr Entsch raised these issues with him that Mr Entsch had a substantial stake in the development at East Trinity going ahead? Was he aware that the proposed development would boost the value of Mr Entsch's nearby land holdings by up to 1,000 per cent?

âIn many ways, yesterday was a sad day in Australian politics. The Australian Labor Party again tried to drag an individual through the gutter in circumstances where it seems that what he, a parliamentary representative, was doing was trying to enhance the environmental outlook of his home city, or near home city, of Cairns. It is true that Mr Entsch has taken an interest in the acid sulphate issue in the Trinity Inlet and I commend him for doing so. I would have thought that that would be the minimum that one would expect of a local representative. As I tried to indicate on radio this morning, the difference between Mr Entsch and some other representativesâI hasten to say, on the other side of the chamberâis that he actually gets out there and seeks to get done what he is complaining about. In other words, rather than just saying that there is an acid sulphate problem in Trinity Inlet, he was interested in helping to take remedial action. Again, I would have thought that he should be applauded for that.

answer.para: He has mentioned an acid sulphate problem to me on a couple of occasionsâthe occasions that I can recall were of an informal nature; I am not saying that there may not have been others. On the last occasion that I can recall, I was actually doing a joint press conference with Mr Entsch in Cairns, at a venue which coincidently overlooked the port area. I might say that the press conference was on a different subject matter. It was on marine conservation, which is a matter of great interest to the Howard government, but was of little interest to the previous Labor government. And I can recall Mr Entsch on that occasion waving his hands and talking about the acid sulphate problem. As well, I can remember him on a previous occasion, when we were walking to a party meeting in this building, talking about acid sulphate problems in the Trinity Inlet. As I said after question time yesterday, he in fact asked my department in the first instance whether we would support CSIRO officers attending a community based meeting on the subject in the Cairns area, and we were prepared to do so.

I have not seen anything that would cause me to do anything other than commend Mr Entsch for his interest in a significant environmental issue and his willingness to get out there and seek to do something about it. If we can solve the issues of acid sulphate along the Queensland coast, we will be making a significant difference towards achieving a better environmental outcome. Those people, such as Mr Entsch, who are prepared to contribute to achieving that better environmental outcome, I commend for doing so and I only wish a few others would join them in that task.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you failed to address the question: did you know, when the issue was raised with you by Mr Entsch, that he had a substantial stake in the development at East Trinity going ahead? Secondly, do you believe it is appropriate and in accordance with the Prime Minister's code of ministerial conduct that a government frontbencher should involve himself actively and publicly, including using the facilities of his public office, in promoting a development from which he will derive substantial financial gain?

âI still do not know that he has a substantial interest in this development going ahead. I did not know it yesterday and I do not know it at all. In relation to Mr Entsch working to achieve a better environmental outcome in Cairns by addressing the acid sulphate problem, I commend him for doing so, as I said a few minutes ago.

âMy question is directed to Senator Ian Macdonald, the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. With the passage through the Senate of the bill to allow a further 16 per cent tranche of Telstra to be privatised, will the minister outline some of the particular benefits that honouring this commitment will bring to people living in rural and regional Australia?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âSenator Parer raises a couple of very important issues: one, of course, is honouring commitments and the other is helping people who live in country Australia. People who lived in country Australia were in decline for 13 years under the Labor government. The Labor government had no interest whatsoever in rural and regional Australiaâservices declined and people's businesses went down. But in that time, the Labor Party did sell some Australian icon assets. They sold the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas, and good luck to them for doing it. But when they sold things, they used the proceeds for recurrent expenditure. They did not reinvest it at all.

answer.para: I am pleased to say, as Senator Parer has raised, that we have sold a further 16 per cent of Telstra and that money is going back into Australia. First of all, we are paying off the huge debt that Labor ran up in government. That debt did more than anything to increase interest rates and make life unbearable for people in the bush. So that is the first thing we are doing with it. But, in addition to that, we are spending about a billion dollars on tangible, positive assets, on positive things for people in rural and regional Australia.

I am saddened that some of the media in my state and, particularly, the Premier, Mr Beattieâeither he is lazy or not competent to understandâhave not been able to comprehend just what this deal, the sale of a further 16 per cent of Telstra, will do for Queensland. On top of the original benefits from the social bonus, a new sum of $36 million will be available to Queenslanders as a result of the sale of Telstra. That will include some specifically identified initiatives, such as a further $20 million for the private sector incubators under the Building on IT Strengths programâsomething that will be great news for Queenslanders; a further $10 million for an enhanced telecommunications network under the Building Additional Rural Networks program; and, in my own area, a further $6 million to Queensland councils for the Local Government Online program. As well, Queensland communities will bid for some of the funds in the national programs, like the additional $250 million going to the Natural Heritage Trust, the $25 million that will extend mobile phone coverage along the national highwaysâand there are a lot of them in Queenslandâand the $70 million for the Rural Transactions Centre program, which I am proud to be involved in.

In relation to that RTC program, I am pleased to say that that is up and running with the sale of a further 16 per cent of Telstra. The members on the advisory panel met in Canberra this week in fact and actually saw the historic vote, when additional moneys were provided for that program. That will be great news for country people; it delivers basic banking and telecommunications services. The benefits that we have initiated will also provide for SBS coverage in areas of Queensland, and Australia as a whole, which currently do not get it. They will be doing a lot of things. I cannot understand why Queensland senators actually oppose that, while Mrs Kernot, a Queenslander, said that `it was not good news' for Queenslanders to share another billion dollars worth of effort. Mrs Kernot said that it was not good news that Queenslanders could participate in that 500-branch rural transaction network. I cannot understand why that has happened. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. On what basis did the Prime Minister's office state, as reported on the news programs of the TV networks last night, that Mr Entsch's activities in relation to the proposed NatWest development at East Trinity in Cairns were a response to the concerns of Mr Entsch's constituents rather than an attempt to further his own interests? How can such an assertion be made with any confidence? Isn't this precisely the problem which the Prime Minister's code of conduct is meant to addressâthat is, to provide absolute assurance to the electorate that office holders are not pursuing private interests under the guise of their public responsibilities? Isn't that why the Prime Minister must demand Mr Entsch's resignation immediately?
âAnyone would think, from what they have heard from the Labor Party in the last 24 hours, that Mr Entsch did not disclose these properties. In actual fact, he did.
âOh, it was the directorships he did not disclose?

âNo, you have moved on from the directorships, Senator. I am sorry; you are a week out of date. You have failed on that, so you have tried to dig up a bit more dirt. I must say that I have not trawled through his statements but it would seem, although it wasn't stated in a premise to the questions that were asked by Labor yesterday, that he did in fact disclose his interests in these properties. What is the purpose of disclosure at a parliamentary level? It is so that any apparent conflict of interest is obvious and political pressure can be applied, and similarly at an executive level. So it would seem that in fact Mr Entsch did what he was supposed to do.

answer.para: What has happened is that the Labor Party, in their attempts to drag him down, have noted the properties, have seen that he has been working with the community to try to reduce the consequences of acid sulphate in the region and they have said, `If the community benefits, Mr Entsch must benefit and therefore he should resign.' What a nonsense! But the failure to mention that he had disclosed the properties was not the only misrepresentation that we heard from the Labor Party yesterday. Implied in the question was that he had bought the property cheapâyou know, a secret deal. I heard this morning that in fact he bought the property at a public auction. So where is the secret deal? Was that said? Furthermore, yesterday we were told the value of the property, a fairly substantial sum of money, and we were told the price of his purchase, and the implication wasâand there was a huge disparity between the twoâthat there was some wrongdoing. In actual fact, I understand that he bought the leasehold, for which I am told he pays $10,000 a year, but the valuation that was referred to by Labor was for the freehold. All of this was not to disclose the truth; it was to muddy the truth. And they succeeded of course. What did they get on the television last night? They got what they wantedâsuggestions that there must be something improper, because the journalists did not ask the Labor Party the full story.

The Labor Party would obviously know all these things, because they have been into it in such depth. But did they put the full picture on the table when they made their accusations? Of course not, because that would spoil the story. It is time the Labor Party got out of the gutter and started developing a better policy, started trying to turn themselves into a real opposition, started trying to look just a touch like an alternative government. I know that in the first term you are frustrated and you go through these things, but it is now the second term in opposition. Sooner or later the Labor Party have to start looking at themselves. What do they want to be in the future? Oh, they are silent now, aren't they! Do they want to spend all their time in the gutter trawling for muck? Is that all the once great Australian Labor Party want to be? That is all they are demonstrating at the moment. (Time expired)

âOrder! Senator Hill has the call to answer the supplementary question. Senator Faulkner, you should not be interjecting continuously.

âThis Labor Party does not worry about the facts. It does not worry about the truth. For the first time, Senator Faulkner talks today about a development in which Mr Entsch has a substantial interest.
âIt is true.

âSenator Faulkner, you are out of order behaving as you are at present.

âWhen Senator Faulkner has a weak argument he shouts. And the weaker his argument, the louder he shouts. Today he is shouting louder than ever. I know that Mr Entsch worked with a community group to address the issue of acid sulphate. That is what I know. And for that I commend him. (Time expired)

âMy question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. The coalition government has demonstrated a considerable commitment to support for families and relationship support. Will the minister inform the Senate of the latest initiative of the government to assist Australian families?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Coonan for the question, because this morning I had the pleasure, with the Prime Minister, of jointly launching the government's response to a parliamentary report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled To have and to hold . The committee looked at government funded family relationship services and talked to a variety of experts and stakeholders about how to improve them.

answer.para: What was unique about the report's recommendations was their attention to education and prevention strategiesâthat is, how can we help families stay together rather than just provide assistance after the families break up? Putting fences at the top of the cliff rather than only ambulances at the bottom is the way I would describe it. That focus on prevention rather than cure is one that we have endorsed wholeheartedly for some time, and we have been moving in that direction in a number of policy areas.

The pilot voucher scheme which the Prime Minister announced today will enable couples who have notified of their intention to marry with a marriage celebrant to access pre-marriage education services. The pilot program will be for vouchers in a couple of areas of Australia, I think. In addition, a relationship kit will be developed which will assist people, particularly those in rural and regional areas, where they may not have ready access to pre-marriage education services. This initiative builds on the $15 million announced in the budget for marriage and relationship education services and also for the men in relationship education services.

The administrative arrangements the Prime Minister has put together have brought the major policy areas for families and the programs into one portfolio, the Department of Family and Community Services. So the government is in the best possible position to develop a comprehensive response such as we have seen today in the government's announcements. Of course we believe that all families and strong families are crucial in maintaining a stable, cohesive and compassionate society. But, as the Prime Minister said today, we cannot legislate to make people be nice to each other. It would be really nice if he could legislate thatâwe might get a bit of better behaviour from the people sitting opposite us in the Senate, but the relationships there seem to be permanently fractured. Our challenge as a nationânot just as governments but as communities, families and individualsâis to try as much as possible to prevent family breakdown happening. We have a very important obligation to help families nurture, enrich and enjoy their relationships.

Since we came to office, our government has delivered on its promises and increased significantly funding and services designed to strengthen and support families. That includes a mix of financial help through the tax and social security systems for around two million families with children. Our tax reforms will provide $11.9 billion in personal income tax cuts and $2.5 billion in additional family assistance. But government is not just about dollars and statistics; it is also about providing substantial support services to help families when they reach critical times in their lives, such as: marriageâgetting used to living together and supporting each other; the birth of childrenâcertainly the first child; young people going through adolescence, which is often a difficult time for families; finding a job. The services are for crucial times in families' lives.

The education and prevention approach is not new to us. We are already moving in that direction by introducing programs in preven tion of youth homelessness, of youth suicide and of domestic violence. It is now supported across the political spectrum and accepted by most experts as a sound investment in the future of any country. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Member for Leichhardt: East Trinity Development

âThat is what is known as leading the witness, I thinkâparticularly when the witness is not the Prime Minister. Anyway, to try to read the Prime Minister's mind, the Prime Minister has accepted that it was an inadvertent mistake. There is lots of evidence to support that. Is the Labor Party even suggesting that it was a deliberate omission designed to mislead?
âHe is no Rhodes scholar: that is what he said.

âThat is right: he said that he is no Rhodes scholar. He is not lucky like you, Senator Carrâjust because you are so smart! Or perhaps not so smart, now that I think about it: I will withdraw that, Madam President. I would not even embarrass Senator Carr in that way.

âMadam President, my question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Customs. In view of recent media discussion and the government's continued promotion of the proposed national DNA database, could the minister explain the privacy safeguards and the guarantees that will accompany this proposal? I am wondering whether the government has studied the implications of the widespread collection of personal genetic information in our society.

âI thank Senator Stott Despoja for her question. It is true that the government does promote the benefits of a national DNA database as a part of its election commitment, which has subsequently been confirmed in the budget, to establish a system called CrimTrac. It is a system which will, by computer, link the databases of police forces around Australia and will therefore enable police, in pretty close to real time, to access the information they need to fight crime. One aspect of thatâ
âThe Democrats are asking dorothys now, are they?

âNo, Senator Mackay; it is not a dorothy. I have a passionate interest in this matter. It is my policy area. I have a great interest in CrimTrac and I welcome your former government's support of it. It is important to note that the opposition has welcomed the development of CrimTrac and have been supportive of it. Part of CrimTrac is the national DNA database about which Senator Stott Despoja asks. She asked about the privacy safeguards in relation to that. The safeguards in place at the moment would be those in the forensic procedures bill which was passed just before the last election.

answer.para: Senator Stott Despoja may be aware that there is a Model Criminal Code Officers Committee report dealing with these matters and trying to shift towards a uniform approach around Australia for dealing with this. That report will be referred to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. Anybodyâand that, of course, includes the Democratsâis welcome to participate in discussions on that final report. The report deals with a range of things: the types or categories of persons from whom DNA should be able to be collected; the mechanisms for protection, and the appropriate mechanisms for disposal once the DNA has been used for the purpose for which it was collected; and the restriction of it to the use for which it was collected. I am happy to send Senator Stott Despoja some copies of that report if she does not already have them.

The last thing that I want to point out in relation to this is that the DNA that the Commonwealth is looking at collecting will come from 10 sites. One of those sites will identify the gender of the person from whom the DNA comes. The other sites are, I am told, referred to as `junk' sitesâthat is, they tell you nothing about the person from whom the DNA comes. They do not tell you their hair colour, eye colour, height, weight or anything. In that sense they are far more impersonal than a description that might be distributed over the radio: `Watch out for someone six feet five and weighing this much, with blond hair and brown eyes.' They do not tell you that kind of information.

What these sites will tell you is that it is a particular person. If you can then match that DNA with another piece of DNA all you can say is that this DNA is from the same person. In a sense, it is a very up-market fingerprint that gives the police much wider opportunities than fingerprints do to access information as to who was at the scene of a crime. It will be particularly useful for local police in fighting crime. In the case of, for example, burglaries, the United Kingdom have more than doubled their clear-up rate of home burglaries. That is because, instead of having five police stations investigating a burglary in which the same person was involved, they suddenly know the same person was involved and those investigations can be put together. Of course, when you put all of the resources together, you often find you are much more efficient. Of particular interest to women is that the DNA database will be particularly useful in sexual offences. That will be of interest to men as well because there are numerous examples where men have been improperly charged with rape or accused of rape or a sexual offence and DNA has proven they were not the perpetratorâ(Time expired)

âMy question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. Minister, what action is the government taking to reduce the overrepresentation of indigenous people in custody and incarceration?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Crane for his question and for his continued interest in my portfolio. This is a very serious issue for which vigilant approach is necessary to overcome the potential tragic consequences highlighted by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I have read in today's media the reported comments of ATSIC commissioner Colin Dillon, the commissioner with portfolio responsibilities for the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. Madam President, you will recall that I appointed Commissioner Dillon, then Inspector Dillon, to the ATSIC board in 1996 because of his background as a Queensland police officer and the valuable experience he could bring to the job as ATSIC commissioner. I share his reported concern. He said:

answer.para: So much was spent in financial resources to set up the royal commission and we have very little to show for it today.

It is now 10 years after the royal commission. It was established under the then Labor government, which spent $400 million implementing the recommendations. More than three-quarters of this funding went to ATSIC. The rest went to the states and territories and other agencies to implement strategies and programs which would overcome deaths in custody. Tragically, despite this expenditure, deaths in custody continued to rise, from nine in 1992 to 21 in 1995. The coalition government has taken a different approach in working with states, territories and indigenous communities to overcome the problems which lead to deaths in custody.

Any death in custody is a tragedy. No-one likes to talk about statistics when they represent people's lives and the effect on their extended families. However, it is interesting to note that in the past three years the figures have started to decline. While it is too early to be conclusive, the figures are certainly encouraging. It is also worth noting that in 1997-98 the rate of deaths among indigenous prisoners per 1,000 was 3.72, which was lower than the rate of non-indigenous prisoners, at 4.59 per 1,000.

The issue of indigenous overrepresentation in the criminal justice system was a focus of the 1997 Ministerial Summit on Indigenous Deaths in Custody convened by the Commonwealth government. The summit involved the states and territories, which are responsible for the administration of the criminal justice system. Initiatives agreed to by the states, territories and indigenous organisations arising out of the summit included the development of targets in each jurisdiction for reducing this overrepresentation. These initiatives will be revisited at the next Ministerial Council for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs meeting, scheduled to be held in September this year.

While the state and territory governments are primarily responsible for the criminal justice system, the federal government is committed to addressing the underlying causes of incarceration because that, after all, is the basic reason for this occurrence. The royal commission found that the underlying cause of indigenous overrepresentation in the criminal justice system is the social and economically disadvantaged position of indigenous people.

The Australian government remains committed to addressing this disadvantage and enabling indigenous people to participate fully in Australian social and economic life. The Australian government funding of indigenous specific programs is now the highest on record, with $2.2 billion programmed to be spent in 1999-2000. The government's policy focuses on improving basic services such as housing and infrastructure, access to education, training and employment opportunities, health care and economic empowerment. We believe, by doing this over the next few years, we will enable indigenous Australians to share in the economic opportunities that this government has presented for every Australian.

âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is the minister aware of recent DETYA figures which reveal that more than a third of undergraduates enrolled in 1992 had dropped out by 1997âone of the highest non-completion rates in the world? Is he also aware of similar findings that reveal postgraduate students are not completing their studies, with as many as 90 per cent of postgraduates dropping out? Is he also aware of a study this week that argues that the failure rates in Australia's higher education institutions may indicate that some students need greater support services and structures? If so, why is the government persisting with its voluntary student unionism legislation, which will result in a dramatic decline in student support infrastructure?

âI can say that the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs did conduct a survey in relation to 1992 students and found that the overall drop-out rate was 33.9 per cent. This is a problem which has been around for some time and is of concern to the government. There are a number of reasons why tertiary students are not completing their courses. I might say at the outset that the federal government is working with state governments at the MCEETYA level to investigate what is being done in relation to careers informationâbecause that is the first thing to look at: are students embarking on the right courses? That is a very important thing indeed.

answer.para: One of the steps forward in this regard has been in the vocational education and training sector, where we now have a record number of students involvedâI think somewhere in the region of 114,000 students.

talk.start.para: âA regular drop-out rate as well.

âWhat that is doingâand Senator Carr might want to listen to thisâis addressing students into the areas where they are best suited. One thing that the study did find was that the top 10 per cent of the TER students had a higher completion rate than the lowest 10 per cent. I think that could well tell us something.

answer.para: There is also the question of the overall job market, I would suggest, where we have the lowest unemployment in this country since 1990 and greater opportunities for those young people who are studying to enter the work force; and they might well make the decision that they will switch to work rather than complete their studies.

As to the student support services, the experience in my state has been that voluntary student union fees have not seen any diminution in the sorts of services that Senator Stott Despoja is talking about. Just this year I was at the orientation day for the University of Western Australia and saw there services provided by the Guild of Undergraduates offering counselling and support services, which has been referred to by Senator Stott Despoja. It does not necessarily follow that voluntary student union fees will see a diminution in these sorts of services. In fact, some of the guilds in Western Australia are doing quite well with the membership because they are offering their students tangible benefits for being a member rather than compelling them to join.

The non-completion rate is of concern to the government, and it is one that the federal government is reviewing and working with the state and territory governments to address. There are a number of issues that impact on non-completion. I think the prime cause of that is perhaps students leaving school and going into the wrong sorts of courses, and we have to look particularly at the careers guidance that is offered to younger students. That study did find that younger students are more likely to complete their courses than older students, and I think we alsoânot to forget themâhave to address our attention to older students and the sort of guidance they get before they embark on the relevant course.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Is the minister aware that careers counselling is one of the services provided by student organisations which the legislation will completely emasculate? Is the government, or particularly the minister, also aware of the Dobson and Sharma report that actually talks about what a lack of support structures means for students? Is the minister also aware that these very institutions to which he referred in Western Australia are the very institutions that provided evidence to the Senate committee looking at this legislation that concluded that there was a diminution in the services that are provided as a result of VSU? When will the government and the minister ensure that real equity and access are in our higher institu tions by restoring sustainable funding and allowing student representation and services to continue?

âThe careers guidance counselling that Senator Stott Despoja refers to is that offered on the campuses. I think it is very important to look at that sort of counselling taking place before people go to universityâbefore they are enrolled. Whilst I acknowledge that careers guidance counselling has a role on the campus, it is a bit like closing the gate after the horse has bolted. My experience in Western Australia is not one of seeing any decline in student support and services, and that relates to career guidance counselling.

answer.para: I think that what we have to look at in that particular area is what is being done in the schools, because that is where you really do have to give the concrete guidance that is needed to young people, and that of course also includes the vocational education sector. We have seen that growing. Some 30 per cent go on to tertiary education; 70 per cent do not. We have to make sure that we do not have an inordinate percentage going on to higher education who are not suited for it.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. Can the minister confirm that amongst the very few duties that the Prime Minister has seen fit to allocate to the Parliamentary Secretary to Cabinet, Senator Heffernan, is that he `approves legislation prior to introduction into parliament'? Can the minister assure the Senate that there is no instance of a conflict of interest between Senator Heffernan's approval of any piece of legislation in his role as Parliamentary Secretary to Cabinet and any of Senator Heffernan's private financial interests, either those which he has disclosed or those that he may have failed to disclose to the parliament?
âMadam President, I am sorry; I was distracted by the press release from the Mayor of the Cairns City Council in relation to Mr Entsch. He said:

answer.para: As a life member of the Labor Party, I find it refreshing that a man from the other side of the political fence is prepared to put everything else aside and work in the best interests of the people he serves.
That is the answer to yesterday's attack on Mr Entsch, and I suspect tomorrowâ

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I raise a point of order. If, in effect, it is an answer to one of yesterday's questions, so be it. There is an opportunity, as you know, for the minister to provide, in accordance with standing orders, any further information he would like to provide, which may or may not be interesting. But I did not ask a question about any local government official in Cairns or even about Mr Entsch; I asked a question about the duties of Senator Heffernan. I think you would agree, Madam President, that the minister ought to answer it.
âI draw your attention to the question, Senator Hill.

âMadam President, I was making the point that yesterday's muckraking has failed, and I was demonstrating that through the evidence of the Mayor of Cairns, who, I might add, also says that Mr Entsch's property is more than 10 kilometres from the NatWest site and is aâ

âMadam President, I raise a point of order. I would think, Madam President, that you would agree that the Leader of the Government in the Senate is treating the chair with contempt. You have directed him to answer the question. He is flagrantly ignoring your ruling. I think you ought to direct him to answer the question. If he cannot answer it, he has an opportunity to take the question on notice and seek an answer from someone who can provide it.
âSenator Hill, there are other matters that you may deal with at the end of question time, but this particular question is the one that you should have before you at present.

âI am sorry, Madam President. I was just attempting to point out that the muckraking of yesterday did not work and I am equally confident that the muckraking in relation to Senator Heffernan today will not work either.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the minister is unwilling or unable to answer the question, I would ask him to take the question on notice and provide an answer. I would particularly like the minister to draw his attention to informing the Senate as to whether Senator Heffernan approved pieces of legislation prior to their introduction into parliament like A New Tax System (Closely Held Trusts) Bill 1999 , A New Tax System (Ultimate Beneficiary Non-disclosure Tax) Bill (No. 1) 1999 , A New Tax System (Ultimate Beneficiary Non-disclosure Tax) Bill (No. 2) 1999 and Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1999 . I would like the minister to specifically assure the Senate that any approvalâif there was an approval by Senator Heffernanâof those bills does not constitute any conflict of interest affecting Senator Heffernan's substantial business affairs or his myriad of family trusts. That is the assurance I am seeking.

âI thought that I had already indicated my confidence in Senator Heffernan. I am sure that, if he were in the position to ask questions, he would not ask them on the basis of half-truths. I do not think today has been a day that the Labor Party would want to reflect on for long. With pleasure, I will put them out of their misery. Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

âEarlier today, Senator West made a ruling on the requirement under standing order 142(4) that government amendments be put at the expiration of allotted time and the discretion of the chair under standing order 84(3) to divide a question. She undertook to refer that ruling to me. I have considered the ruling and I uphold it. The chair has indicated in the past that the chair's discretion to divide a question will be exercised for the purpose of allowing senators to vote differently on different parts of a question. The chair may decline to exercise that discretion unless satisfied that it is necessary to protect that right of senators.

Senator IAN MACDONALD

talk.start.para: âMadam President, yesterday I gave an answer to a question and I promised Senator Woodley that if there was more I could add I would. Yesterday in question time Senator Woodley asked me a number of questions about the Albury-Wodonga Freeway. The answers are in the same order as the questions were asked yesterday.
