speech.para: In relation to question (2), the answer is yes. The economic analysis carried out during the EIS process took account of the social and health costs and impacts. In relation to question (3), in conjunction with the refining of costs of the internal route, a review of the external route costings is being undertaken. The results of this review are being finalised now and the New South Wales government is to provide the Commonwealth with a report on this.

In relation to questions (4) and (5), Senator Woodley, I think I dealt with them yesterday. However, I can add that, while you were suggesting that the majority of your Albury residents are opposed to the internal route, with respect there is also very strong evidence to support the opposite claim. I note two articles in the Border Mail dated 18 and 19 June in which a couple of independent community groups and the state member for Benambra, Mr Tony Plowman MLA, whom I omitted yesterday in my list of the elected representatives who support the internal route, are indicated as strongly supporting the internal route.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of answers given by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Hill), to questions without notice asked by Senators Ray, Faulkner and Cook today, relating to the financial interests of the Parliamentary Secretary to Cabinet (Senator Heffernan).

We had Senator Hill really squealing in question time today because the opposition thought it appropriate to scrutinise the executive. Senator Hill finds it very offensive when the opposition exercises its responsibility to hold the government accountable and to scrutinise the executive. I must say, to be fair to Senator Hill, that he is not as bad as Senator Heffernan who, true to form today, has scurried from the chamber, not willing to respond to the serious issues that have been raised.

This is the way Senator Heffernan operates in politics. I respect most senators in this chamber for at least having a go. Nearly all of the 76 senators in this chamber have a go; they are willing to defend themselves, they are willing to argue their case and they are willing to put up and argue matters of public policy that they believe in or that their party believes in. There is one very noticeable exception to that: Senator Heffernan.

What the opposition were doing today was asking questions. We were asking questions about whether Senator Heffernan failed to disclose his 50 per cent shareholding in Sestial Pty Ltd, which of course is a beneficial interest according to the Prime Minister's criteria. We were asking whether Senator Heffernan's shareholding in Cooba Pastoral Company Pty Ltd was disclosed. That is a beneficial interest according to the Prime Minister's criteria. We were asking if Senator Heffernan failed to disclose his directorship in Cooba Pastoral Company Pty Ltd. We want answers to those questions. We want to know whether Senator Heffernan has also failed to disclose 1,972 hectares of land under perpetual lease in the Balranald area, the title of which is in Senator Heffernan's own name. Of course, this is all contrary to the Senate's disclosure requirements, and it is contrary to the Prime Minister's code of conduct.

We also want to know whether Senator Heffernan, as a parliamentary secretary, has been lobbying for changes to the current government policy on taxing trusts the same as companies, which would substantially disadvantage persons with trust structures, like Senator Heffernan, who would obviously much prefer to return to the present treatment. It does appear from Senator Heffernan's disclosure of his pecuniary interests that he has a beneficial interest in some seven family trusts. Again, this behaviour is, at a minimum, contrary to the spirit of the Prime Minister's much devalued code of conduct.

We want to know whether Senator Heffernan's public lobbying in relation to the capital gains tax proposals at the last election, which would have affected Senator Heffernan's extensive pre-1985 purchased properties, worth millions of dollars, was driven by that position of self-interest. Again, it is, at a minimum, contrary to the spirit of the code of conduct. We want to know about Senator Heffernan's responsibilities as a parliamentary secretary. If he is responsible for giving final approval to the introduction of legislation into parliament, as we have been told, has he signed off on bills that are relevant to issues such as taxation relating to trusts or any other issue that might conflict with his own private interests?

These are fair questions to ask. This is what question time is about. It is reasonable to hold a government accountable. It is reasonable to apply that level of scrutiny to a government, and the opposition is entitled to answers, not the sort of response we received today from Senator Hill. I make this absolutely clear: if Senator Heffernan does have a shareholding and a directorship in the Cooba Pastoral Company Pty Ltd then the same basis on which Mr Howard let Mr Entsch off the hook serves to completely ensnare Senator Heffernan. Senator Heffernan must go. The Senate is entitled to answers on these questions. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThis motion is the No. 2 motion for the opposition today. It is not their preferred motion; their preferred motion was to do yet another character assassination on Mr Entsch. Unfortunately for the opposition, all the questions, slime and sleaze that they have worked themselves into over Mr Entsch failed today. It failed the moment that Senator Faulkner asked in this place whether it was the case that Mr Entsch had a substantial financial interest in a development on the eastern side of Trinity Inlet in Cairns. The reason it failed was that he did not have an interest in that development. That development was in fact many miles from the land which Mr Entsch has. They could not get their facts right.

speech.para: Having worked themselves up and having worked up everybody in the press gallery and told them that they were going to make a major attack on the government and all this sort of nonsense, they then had to look around for another victim. The first victim was proved to be innocent of the charges laid by the opposition so they had to find another victim. At the end of question time, after all that grubbing around about Mr Entsch, they suddenly decided to have an attack on Senator Heffernan this time.

Have they proved anything against Senator Heffernan? No. I was listening very carefully to the contribution, meagre though it was, from Senator Faulkner. It was a very meagre contribution which basically ran along the lines of, `We want to know this, we want to know that. We want to know if this is the case, we want to know if that is the case.' But for the benefit of the media it ended with, `We believe Senator Heffernan should stand aside.' He has not even got the facts, yet he believes Senator Heffernan should stand aside. That is how paltry this case from the opposition is. It is a really feeble, brain numbing caseâ

talk.start.para: âA brain dead case.

âIt is a brain dead case from the opposition because they cannot even prove an allegation. Notwithstanding the fact that they have not proved one single thing in this chamberâall they have done is come up with a litany of questions, with no basis for even asking the questions, as is apparent from Senator Faulkner's contributionâthey end up with the statement, `Senator Heffernan should resign.' If anyone should resign, it should be Senator Faulkner who should resign out of embarrassment over how pathetic this day has been for the opposition in question time.
âThe real leader should resign, too. The real leader on the backbench.

interjection.para: Senator Robert Ray interjectingâ
Senator Boswell interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Ray and Senator Boswell, interjections are unruly and even more so when you are not in your seat, Senator Boswell.

âAs Senator Boswell says, the person who should also resign is the dark hand behind the throneâthe person over there who worked Senator Faulkner up into asking all these stupid questionsâSenator Ray, the great tactical genius of the opposition. He failed as well because he did not even know the answers to the questions that were asked. As Senator Ray well knows, there is a golden rule in politics and that is that you never ask a question unless you know the answer. If Senator Faulkner knew the answer he would not need to ask all these questions, would he? It is clear proof of the fact that Senator Faulkner and Senator Ray are just grubbing about in the dark. That is all it is.

speech.para: What is the essence of this? Can we find anything in the speech that Senator Faulkner made against Senator Heffernan? The essence of Senator Faulkner's contribution was this: Senator Heffernan is a farmer and therefore they attacked him because they believedâsurprise, surpriseâthat he might have an interest in some land. Of course you cannot be a farmer unless you have some land, by definition. You need to farm something, you need to plough something, you need to put the sheep or the cattle on something. You cannot be a farmer in a suburban backyard, although I am sure that some of the financial geniuses of the Labor Party tried that in their tax avoidance days. We know all about their tax avoidance and their involvement in farming. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âToday at question time we saw Senator Hill knock down a lot of straw men. Let me deal with them. First of all, Senator Hill said the Labor Party somehow conspired to say that Mr Entsch achieved his property secretly.
âYou told half the story.

âIn my speech here yesterday I mentioned the auction, Senator Macdonaldâthrough you, Madam Deputy President. I said that this land went at auctionâstraw man number one gone. Second straw man: Senator Hill says we distorted where Mr Entsch's property is in relation to where the NatWest thing is going to go ahead. We released to the press a scale map showing where it is! There was no attempt by us to distort the relationship between where Mr Entsch's property is and where the major development is going to occur. But the relevant point of course is: the major development can only go ahead if the environmental matters are dealt with. Once they are dealt with, the bridge gets builtâand the bridge not only serves NatWest but also serves Mr Entsch's property. There is the conflict of interest, and it is unassailably a conflict of interest. It is Mr Entsch that takes the CSIRO report, distorts it and says the only solution to this area is development, when the report clearly shows there are other options. Therein lies the conflict of interest.

speech.para: In terms of Senator Heffernan, Senator O'Chee runs a defence that Senator Heffernan is entitled to own land because he is a farmer. Of course he is. Senator Heffernan has declared his directorship of a number of companies. Senator Heffernan has declared his beneficial interest in a number of companies. Senator Heffernan has declared his beneficial interest, in addition, to six family trusts and one unit trust. Senator Heffernan has declared property and house ownership, but what he failed to declare was his directorship in Sestial Pty Ltd. When he gets around to correcting the record after two yearsâremembering that it is a matter of privilege in this place if you do not adjust your pecuniary interest form within 28 days, and it takes him almost a year and a half to get that directorship rightâhe then does not declare his shares in that particular company. We are entitled to ask why. Senator O'Chee says we do not know the answers. Of course we have done the company searches, of course we have done the land title searches and of course we know the answers; what we want to know is whether there was knowledge in the government about this or not.

That was a reasonably serious matter, but I have to say Sestial Pty Ltd equals the Entsch position in reverse. Mr Entsch declares a beneficial interest but not a directorship; Senator Heffernan declares a directorship but not a beneficial interest. So, if we were to try to convict Senator Heffernan on the Prime Minister's interpretation, then he would get off on the Prime Minister's interpretation. But when you come to Cooba then Senator Heffernan actually gets hung on the Prime Minister's interpretation because he neither declares his directorship nor his beneficial interest.

talk.start.para: âIt doesn't exist, that's why.

âI see, it does not exist. You say that it does not exist, Senator. Why haven't the records been corrected if it has been wound up? It is always possible that these things have been wound up or disposed of or otherwise, but you wonder why the director has not corrected the record. So for the moment we have to go on the assumption that it continues to exist and it has not gone into another entity or otherwise. But Senator Heffernan has a form there. You wonder why he cannot fill out a form properlyâand this comes from the individual that gets to sight all cabinet documents. This comes from the individual that is running around at the moment trying to stir up the National Party and others to oppose the proper tax reform of trusts. Why? Because he has six trusts himself plus one; he has a beneficial interest in these particular matters.

speech.para: How many trusts, incidentally, do you need as a farmer? The usual argument is you need one or two to protect your interests and your succession. Why do you need six? But there are six plus a unit trust. So it comes down to this: these matters are more properly resolved by Senator Heffernan having the courage to come in here and explain himself. He broke the world 100-metres record to get out of here at 3 o'clock, like he always does. The typical modus operandi of Senator Heffernan is to sit here, snipe at individuals, sleaze around the press gallery and blackguard them but never get to his feetâ(Time expired)

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âForgive me, Madam Deputy President, I am just trying to look at yesterday's Hansard where Senator Ray says that he mentioned that Mr Entsch bought the land at auction. I see he says:

speech.para: . . . he got it cheapâmost people know. Most people know what the auction process was on this occasion.
But I do not see where he says that they acknowledged that he bought it at auction.
Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI only raise that to say that this is yet another example of some of the mud being thrown in the hope that the press, without proper scrutinyâas regrettably seems to be the case more often than not these daysâwill simply pick up what Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner say and run the mud. That is what this is all about: make a little bit of mud, scatter it around as widely as you can and be completely oblivious to whether it is truthful or not. Regrettably, that is what the Labor Party has come down to these days. I am at least pleased to alert any listeners there might be to the fact that most of the Labor senators will not have a bar of this muckraking. There are now two Labor senators in the whole chamber and no Democratsâand I have to say that there are only three of us on this side because we cannot get away. Nobody is interested in this muckraking, and most of the Labor senators are as embarrassed as hell about it. You only have to look behind Senator Faulkner at question time to see that the decent Labor senators are embarrassed about this and do not want this sort of thing to happen.

speech.para: Who could say that more clearly than a genuine, honest, dinky-di good blokeânot a Rhodes scholar that Senator Carr would sneer at, as he did with Mr Entschâthat is, the mayor of Cairns? He is a lifelong and life member of the Labor Partyâa good, decent man who is one of the Labor people of the old school, a fighter for his own areas. This is what he said in the first paragraph of a press release he issued:
Cairns mayor Cr Tom Pyne has slated some Federal politicians who have attempted to drag the city's name through the contaminated mud of the NatWest projectâ
He was talking obviously about the Labor senators, Mr Crean and the Labor apparatchiks over the other side. Councillor Pyne went on to have another serve at his Labor Senate colleagues when he said:
`But for those in far away Canberra who are unfamiliar with Cairns's geography, this site is only one parcel of a large area of land across the inlet which is known as East Trinity . . .
`Mr Entsch's property is more than 10 km away from NatWest's site and is a restrained parcel bounded by national parks and with no identified urban potential under that DCPâ
that is, the development control planâ
`We will continue to work with Mr Entsch in the best interests of all residents across the inlet . . .

I raise this only to show that the Labor Party, a party bereft of any policy whatsoever, simply has to get down to these tactics to make itself relevant. I expect this from Senator Carr and I expect it from Senator Faulkner. Madam Deputy President, you know what a bullyboy Senator Faulkner was from the way he treated you with contempt this morning. I just mention that as an aside.

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Macdonald, would you please not reflect upon any members here.
âI do not want to embarrass you.
âYou are not embarrassing me. Just do not reflect upon other members.

âI did feel for you, that Senator Faulkner could adopt with you in your official role the sorts of bullyboy tactics that he uses in the union movement. But I expect that from Senator Faulkner and Senator Carr. It is of regret that Senator Ray stoops to these levels. I wanted to say today what a great member Mr Entsch is for his constituency. He is not a Rhodes scholar. He is not terribly formally well-educated but he is an intelligent, caring and very active representative of his constitu entsâsomething the Labor senators would not understand. Senator Carr, you would not understand about getting out there and supporting the area you come from.

speech.para: What Labor senators have tried to do with Mr Entsch has failed and they now try with Senator Heffernan. I know nothing about Senator Heffernan's interestsâI am not very interestedâbut I can be sure that, as they are wrong about Mr Entsch, as they throw the mud and hope that a little bit sticks, that is what they will be with Senator Heffernan. Senator Heffernan, again, is a man who is concerned about his community. He wants to promote his community, as Mr Entsch does, and it is a pity that the Labor Party does notâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt was Mr Entsch's claim himself, as Senator Macdonald has indicated to us today, that he was not `a bloody Rhodes scholar, not a lawyer'. His defence for his failure to fill in his pecuniary interests form was that, essentially, he was too thick; he was not capable of filling in a very simple form.
âPlease do not reflect upon a member of the other house.

âWe see yet another member of this government, another parliamentary secretary, presumably claiming the `not a Rhodes scholar, not a lawyer' defence. I might add that one of the very few members of the government who are not lawyers has been able to argue again today, presumably, that this is yet another oversight, another mistake. What we have been able to establish after just a casual perusal of the public record is that, in this government, not being a Rhodes scholar is a matter of pride. The use of complex business trusts, the use of quite extensive legal frameworks, to avoid one's responsibilities in regard to taxation and a range of other matters is a hallmark of this government and something in which most of its frontbench are currently involved.

speech.para: Senator Heffernan, in his role as cabinet secretary, has undertaken to set upon a review of the impact of the proposed business taxation treatments on the use of discretionary trusts. This might be humorous in normal circumstances, until we appreciate that he is the holder of six family trusts.

talk.start.para: âHow many?

âSix family trusts, Senator Bolkus, and one unit trust. We also read about his intervention in the last federal election campaign and some of his activities in Queanbeyan. He was described in the Australian of 1 October 1998 as involving himself in a `chest-poking showdown with Mr Beazley'. The article stated:

speech.para: Rangy NSW Senator Bill Heffernan wasn't quite the sinister sharpshooter of heroic secret service dreams, but the chest-poking stoushâ

which of course began with his ambush of Mr Beazley. He shouted at the top of his voice that he felt Mr Beazley was about a `great tax robbery' of farm owners. He would know, of course. He would have a great interest in farm owners, being the controller of six family trusts and one unit trust. He went on to say:

Again, he would know a great deal about property values since he is the owner of such an extensive range of properties in New South Wales. Unfortunately, you would not know that from an examination of his pecuniary interests, because he finds it difficultânot being a Rhodes scholarâto fill in a simple form. He finds it difficult to follow the advice that is contained in the standing orders of this parliament and to follow the instructions involved in filling in a form on pecuniary interests. Yet he has the responsibility for checking legislation that goes before the cabinet of this country.

Senator Heffernan is to instigate a review of these business taxation treatments and the use of discretionary family trusts. I can only presume that the Prime Minister, putting him in that position, knows all the details of his affairs, given that he now has in place new arrangements that ensure that Max Moore-Wilton checks the public statements, the pecuniary interest statements, put before this parliament against the various records of ASIC and so on to ensure that they are accurate. I can only presume from the public record, after solicitors Cleary and Horneâ

talk.start.para: âIt is Hoare: H-o-a-r-e.

âHoare, is it? That might be appropriate. This is a case where the parliamentary secretary, on behalf of 200 farmers, has taken it upon himself to lobby behind closed doors the various measures that are needed to protect the interests of those holders of family trusts.

debateinfo.title: ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION BILL 1998 [1999]

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed.

talk.start.para: âThe committee is considering government amendment 175 on sheet FDT218 moved by Senator Hill. The question is that that amendment be agreed to.

âI want to speak about indigenous issues because during the course of the day we have not as yet had a chance to address what is another important area of debate and concern in the community in respect of this legislation. One group of people who have been misled and done over by the final compromise between the Democrats and the Greens are indigenous Australians. This is an environment bill and a lot of people would be misled into thinking that maybe there are not enormous indigenous issues in respect of this legislation. The truth of the matter is that there are. Whether it is in respect of diversity, hunting and gathering rights, native title rights or the management of some pretty important national parks in Australia, indigenous Australians have a role by law and by social policy.

speech.para: Probably the most fundamental role is that if we as a parliament were to take more than token recognition of the concept of self-determination, we should involve indigenous Australians in decision making, particularly as it affects them directly, as is does in this legislation. In the last few hours there have been a number of press statements issued by indigenous organisations, including the Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park Board of Management, the Kakadu Board of Management and the Central Land Council. The issue of self-determination is best summed up by the media release from the Central Land Council, where Tracker Tilmouth not only condemns the deal but makes the point that:
The debate has been deliberately limited and has excluded many Aboriginal people who are still not fully across the issues.
He goes on to say:
Until there is a political process which is inclusive of Indigenous interests the question of our very basic right to self determination remains a myth.

He calls his press statement, `Political process sends us back to the mission'. Later on, I will go to the press release from the Kakadu Board of Management, but it is also worth noting at the outset one of the comments that Mick Alderson, the Chairperson of the Kakadu Board of Management, makes in respect of the way they have been treated. He speaks on behalf of not only Aboriginal members but also the tourism representative of the Kakadu Board of Management. They express their concern and he says:
We are tired of being treated like jacky-jackys, sitting on the sideline watching non-Aboriginal people making decisions about our land.

These people raise these sorts of concerns because they have been misled, not just by the government but also by the Australian Democrats. It was this minister who wrote to the boards of management saying that there would not be a change in the management arrangements without the consent of the boards. The next thing they knew was that legislation had been introduced to change the structure of the boards of management. There was no consultation in between and no consent sought. The minister just comes in here and introduces legislation, and not only does he not consult but he breaks a commitment and a promise. Further down the track, this felony is compounded by the Australian Democrats, who not only sell them out but try to portray their sell out as a great win for indigenous Australians. That is adding insult to injury, Senator Allison.

When you look at yesterday's press statement from the Australian Democrats, you see that they claim to have acted in the interests of indigenous Australians; they claim to have acted to stop the appointment of Northern Territory government representatives on the boards of the two Territory national parksâUlura-Kata Tjuta and Kakadu. Big achievement! But if you read on in the documentation, you find that that achievement is not what it appears to be. Basically, they chose a deliberate course of deception and deceit, not just of indigenous Australians but of the broader Australian public. This is the mob who claimed victory on the environment legislation when the most eminent constitutional lawyers in the country told them that they had failed. So we should not be surprised about what they have done.

They have told indigenous Australians, `Look, we have taken measures to ensure that there will not be a Territory rep on the board of management,' but when you go into the documentation, that is further redefined to mean that the appointment of a Northern Territory rep on the boards of Kakadu and Uluru-Kata Tjuta national parks is now subject to the consent of traditional owners, with the rider `which may not be withheld unreasonably'. If you go further into the documentation to try to work out what that means, you find that if they resistâif the boards of management do not like a Northern Territory rep on the board of managementâthe decision will be taken out of their hands and given to the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

This is defence protection Australian Democrats style. This is the new wave of Australian Democrats social conscious and social policy: `Sell them out and try to make them feel good on the way through.' Senator Allison, this is the depths of deceit and you ought to be ashamed of yourself in respect of it. I have been with you when you have looked traditional owners, the elders of these communi ties, straight in the face and said, `I will not let you down.' Not only have you let them down but you have tried to con them on the way through. Your voice is worthless in that community from now on and that is depicted by the press statements, releases and letters from these boards of management.

They write to Senator Meg Lees of their concerns about the proposed bill. They call on the Democrats to stall the debate. They want to have time to look at the amendments. These are not unreasonable things, given the fact that the sorts of people we are talking about and the sorts of management structures we are talking about are very successful examples of management by indigenous Australians. Kakadu was the first place in Australia to set up a joint management model. It has been internationally recognised and other parks, not just in Australia but around the world, have learned from us and have made stronger laws for joint management. That is the view of the Chair of the Kakadu Board of Management, Mick Alderson.

But what do we do here? We have put poison in the well. We have put a Northern Territory government representative on the board of Kakadu, and of Uluru. Maybe not on day 1, but give it three months and it happens. Three months is not a long time to wait for the Northern Territory government; they have waited a long time. They are on record in their most recent statements on this matter as saying that they want to take over control of these national parks. These are things that you cannot avoid, that you cannot run away from, Senator Allison, because they were told to you directly. You were there in Darwin at the meetings, and I was sitting next to you, when the Northern Territory government representatives made it very clear that they wanted to take over. They still want to take over. There is distrust there.

You have a great board of management structure that is working. So what do you do? You bow to the government again. Why? People have to ask themselves why you are doing this. These are the most fundamental rights. You know they are fundamental rights because, not only are they social rights, rights of decency and rights of recognition enshrined in international covenants, they are also rights enshrined in leases under our law.

Those leases provideâand you yourself know full well they provide because, once again, we have had copies presented to usâthat in circumstances such as this, even if legislation is introduced to disrupt or overturn the established management structures of those boards, whether it is Kakadu, Uluru or Wreck Bay, the traditional owners have a right to revoke those leases. It is a legal right of theirs. But, in total disregard for thisâand we expect it from the government because the minister made his position clear from the startâyou have traded away these legal and social rights in secret, without consultation, pretending to represent all these people.

talk.start.para: âOutrageous!

âIt is outrageous, Senator Crossin. No wonder these people reckon that they are seen by the political process of Australia as `Jacky Jackys, sitting on the sideline'. As I said, there are major concerns. They have been spelt out in the two letters to Senator Lees and the press statement. The concerns as stated in the Central Land Council media release are that:

speech.para: The Bill

. severely restricts traditional and subsistence use of wildlife by limiting use for traditional purposes as laid out in the Native Title Act 1994 and removes existing protection in the National Parks and Wildlife Act 1974

We do not know to what extent this government is going to reinstate the role of the National Parks and Wildlife Director. But we do know that the independence of that position has been marginalised enormously over the last 12 to 18 months. I sat next to Senator Allison, hand-wringing and expressing concern about what had been happening, about how a public servant under the direction of the minister was now in that position. That concern does not filter through in terms of any outcome of the compromise in the agreement between the Democrats and the government. The next point in the press release expresses concern that the bill:
. ignores native title and cultural heritage protection laws

Your protection of existing native title rights, as agreed with the government, is not good enough; it is not adequate enough. You cannot hide behind incompetence on that one because you knew, and you continue to know, that that was an issue. But did you seek consultation with those who have actually defended Aboriginal Australians in respect of native title? Did you become aware of it? Did you let them come to the table as you were sitting there, cozy with the Prime Minister, Senator Hill and others from the government? There was no room for black people at the table of negotiation on this particular bill when it came to even their most fundamental rights. The deal does not protect the Native Title Act, which passed this place after a long debate less than a year ago. How do you reconcile that? How will you go back to your supporters in Victoria and explain to them that you have actually sold out on the protection of that Native Title Act? You are going to have to. The press release further states that the bill:
. does not provide an effective framework for negotiation of indigenous land use agreements . . .
That is another area in contradiction to the Native Title Act 1993. The next point states that the bill:
. allows the Commonwealth to transfer responsibility to the States and Territories without sufficient accountability

To some extent, you have protected against bilaterals, but you have not protected against that list of myriad mechanisms that are available under legislation for this minister, this government, to basically flick-off responsibilities in that area. The second last point is that:
. there is no requirement for consultation with indigenous stakeholders

You would not want that, because you have not had it. You have not allowed them at the table, so it is no wonder that that does not find itself in the legislation. The last point states that this bill:
. gives the Commonwealth Minister wide discretion in key areas

That is right; that is something that your minority report expressed concern about. So we do have here a sell-out of the Kakadu, UluruâKata Tjuta and Wreck Bay national parks and the destruction of their boards of management. But I suppose the most offensive thing about all this is that it has been done with absolutely no participation of indigenous Australians. Their view, as last expressed to us, is that they want more time. They do not want the Northern Territory rep. They reckonânot only do they reckon but the international bodies reckonâthat they have a good board of management structure. You have sold out on that; you have done it in the dark and you have done it trying to mislead the people most directly affected.

So I say to you: any time you put your head up, Senator Allison, and any time the Democrats put their heads up in the future pretending to be defenders of indigenous Australians, we will remind you of two thingsâthe fact that you have sold out their rights and the fact that you have sold them out without even warning them and trying to deceive them.

talk.start.para: âSince Senator Bolkus quotes so freely from press releases, I will do so as well. I quote from a press release put out yesterday by the Chairman of ATSIC, Gatjil Djerrkura. He said:

speech.para: The Federal Government and the Australian Democrats have negotiated a number of important concessions for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in negotiations over proposed amendments to the Environment Protection Biodiversity Conservation Bill.

Federal Environment Minister, Senator Robert Hill and Australian Democrats Leader, Senator Meg Lees and Democrats Environment spokesperson, Senator Lyn Allison, have clearly listened and taken on board key Indigenous concerns about the proposed Bill in a series of meetings with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups, including ATSIC.
This is reflected in a number of key changes they have negotiated to the proposed legislation before the Senate.

We acknowledge that there are a number of Aboriginal groups who would like more time. Indeed, Mr Djerrkura says that he would too; that he would like to see another round of consultations with their constituents before the bill passes into law. We would like that too, but the fact of the matter is that this legisla tion has been around for 18 months; we have had a very extensive inquiry; and I have had meetings with Aboriginal groups both as part of that inquiry and outside there. What remains is that, once Aboriginal people are across the detail, they areâATSIC tell usânot uncomfortable. I will just run through some of those indigenous benefits.

The objects of the amended bill recognise the role and the knowledge of indigenous peoples in relation to the conservation and sustainable use of Australia's biodiversity. Senator Bolkus cannot claim that any of his legislation has done that. The amended bill explicitly states that it does not affect the operation of native title or Aboriginal land rights legislation. In spite of all of the scaremongering, this bill does not affect native title or Aboriginal land rights legislation.

talk.start.para: âYou don't know what you've agreed to.

âThat has been written into the bill, Senator Bolkus, and you should have a look and acquaint yourself with that fact. In entering into a conservation agreement the minister must take into account obligations under biodiversity convention and the national biodiversity strategy relating to indigenous people's customary use of biodiversity and indigenous knowledge of biodiversity. Again, this is something Labor did not do. The minister must also have regard for the role and interest of indigenous peoples in the conservation of Australia's biodiversity in developing bilateral agreements, recovery plans and threat abatement plans.

speech.para: Existing provisions relating to indigenous people's rights to use Commonwealth reserves for hunting, food gathering or ceremonial and religious purposes have been reinstated. The Biological Diversity Advisory Committee will now include indigenous representation. So all that Jacky Jacky stuff is nonsense. Our amendments make sure that the voices of indigenous people are heard and that they will have representation on that advisory committee. An indigenous advisory committee will be established to advise the minister on the operation of the act, taking into account the significance of indigenous people's knowledge of the management of land, and the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity.

The appointment of a Northern Territory representative, as you have already indicated, on the boards of Kakadu and Uluru national parks is subject to the consent of traditional owners. Furthermore, there is an opportunity for them to review that appointment and for them to, if necessary, replace that member on the board. So we are not talking here about the Northern Territory taking over control of those two boards of managementânobody has ever suggested that. In fact, as I recall, Senator Bolkusâand I think you were there at the timeâa suggestion was put forward by the Kakadu Board of Management that they could live with a Northern Territory member on the board, provided that that statutory role of the National Parks and Wildlife position remained intact.

talk.start.para: âAnd an expansion of the board? What have you done about that? Nothing.

âIndeed, Senator Bolkus, but it is the judgment of indigenous people that they can live with a member of the board. We are not talking about a majority of Northern Territory members; we are talking about somebody who can demonstrate their ability to be cooperative with indigenous peopleâand that certainly would be my hope. I am persuaded by the government's arguments that, in terms of the future for relations between the boards and the Northern Territory government, there may well be some strong argument for there to be a Northern Territory rep on that board. We have judged, based on what we were told by the Kakadu Board of Management, that this is not the end of the world and that if it is one member it is not going to mean that indigenous people lose control of the board or anything of that sort.
âThis is outrageous.

âSo your criticisms, Senator Bolkus are really unfounded and, again, I draw your attention to what Mr Gatjil Djerrkura has said. He has indicated that we have clearly listenedânot just slightly listenedâand taken on board indigenous concerns. I think for the first time we are going to see legislation which really reflects the important role that indigenous people in this country have in biodiversity.

speech.para: On the general subject of biodiversity, we have negotiated a range of amendments under this section. I am very proud to say that this country now has the first national biodiversity legislation. We have upgraded the number of categories of threatened species and increased the types of communities listed. We have specified time lines for all the steps of the listing process. We have uncoupled the decision about listing a threatened species from the decision about the feasibility of a threat abatement plan. So that will stop a lot of existing problems where political decisions were used to stop listing threatened species. That listing will be made solely on the basis of scientific criteria. Recovery plans at present are required for only listed species occurring entirely or partly on Commonwealth areas. Now they are required for all listed species and ecological communities as well.

We have registers of critical habitat, deeper safeguards for migratory species than ever before, strict liability in relation to threatened species, and we are banning the capture of dolphins for live display. Anyone who thinks that wild dolphins should be caught and put in a swimming pool for their life is obviously barbaric. Commonwealth fisheries will now be subject to strategic environmental assessment during the next five years. And there has neverâI repeat neverâbeen an environmental impact assessment on a Commonwealth fishery. The Democrats see this as a major positive step, with so many fisheries vulnerable to collapse from overexploitation. There will now be conservation agreements entered into for the protection and conservation of biodiversity anywhere in Australia. There will be identification and monitoring of biodiversity and preparation of bioregional plans.

One of the most important agreements we have made with Senator Hill is that there will be a public inquiry into the use of and access to biological resources. Indigenous people will be specifically funded to make submissions and to participate. That will be an open and public inquiry, and it will feed into the regulation making process under this bill. Senator Bolkus will recall that indigenous people have been calling for this kind of inquiry for some long time.

Another important measure is that all wildlife on Commonwealth land will be protected unless it is specifically exempted in a schedule. There will be a regulation making power to list invasive speciesâagain, a first. It is a pity that Senator Bolkus and the Labor Party never thought of this while they were in government. Invasive species, as the Democrats knowâSenator Brown probably does not know thisâare a major ecological threat, and there are no provisions to deal with them in existing Commonwealth legislation. There is nothing here at present.

This is yet another area in which the Democrats have made a difference and have made sure that this legislation is not only greatly amended from the original version but also a great improvement on the status quo. There are very many other ways in which biodiversity is protected as a result of this bill, and I am proud to say that the Democrats will be part of introducing the very first Commonwealth biodiversity act.

talk.start.para: âI want to build upon the comments I was making before lunch on the indigenous issue. I noted that Senator Bolkus, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, repeated much of what Senator Crossin had said yesterday. It really is the politics of division, I am sad to say. It is an attempt to gain a short-term political advantage through dividing indigenous Australia from non-indigenous Australia, an attempt on Senator Crossin's part to bring the politics of the Northern Territory down here to Canberra to gain, I presume she believes, some short-term political benefit at home. It is a matter of great regret in relation to an issue of such consequence.

speech.para: I say that because Senator Crossin's contribution yesterday was principally an attack on the Northern Territory government. She cannot win an election in the Northern Territory and so she comes down here with her complaints when rather what she should be doing is addressing the indigenous issues as they relate to the bill. They are very important. The message I wanted to bring and the point I wanted to makeâand it really is necessary because unfortunately, in relation to indigenous affairs as in other areas, the Labor Party wants to dwell in the past rather than move forwardâ
Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI am proud of the joint management. I have said that many times publicly and, if we are talking about the Northern Territory parks, in relation to both Kakadu and Uluru.
âThen why change it?

âSenator Crossin said yesterday that the Northern Territory wants to get rid of the indigenous representation on the board. That is wrong. Those they want to get rid of are us: they want to get Canberra out. That is an aspiration I understand from a territory that wishes to be a state. They wish their parks service to play the same role as parks services in the states, and they cannot really see why the Commonwealth still needs to be involved. But they are not against joint management between themselves and indigenous people. Senator Crossin would be aware of the Nitmiluk National Park and of Gurig. There are instances of joint management between indigenous people and the Northern Territory government. When I have visited those parks, particularly Nitmiluk, the indigenous people have told me that it works well.

speech.para: Be that as it may, we as a Commonwealth government are not going to walk away from either Kakadu or Uluru. We are pleased to be there, playing our part as one of the partners in joint management. We are pleased to bring the best practices in relation to park management and we also recognise the symbolism of those parks in relation to the aspirations of indigenous Australians. But we, in contrast to the Labor Party, also believe that you need to put the wars, battles and disappointments of the past behind and move forward. This idea that one representative of the Northern Territory governmentâone representative on a board on which it is prescribed that the indigenous people must be a majorityâwill in some way be a negative is simply a reflection of the disappointments of the past. It is obvious to meâand, I would have thought, to anybody who looked at this issue objectivelyâthat, provided the Northern Territory representative was prepared to contribute in a constructive way, it must be an asset.

talk.start.para: âIs that guaranteed in this legislation?

âIf Senator Crossin has that assurance, does that mean that she will then support a Northern Territory representative? Of course she will not, because she wants to relive the battles of the past in the Northern Territory. It is a sensible progression in the interests of the parks and of the indigenous people that there be a Northern Territory representativeânot, as she asserted yesterday, to give Northern Territory control but to have one Northern Territory representative who can bring the perspective of the Northern Territory government and the Northern Territory parks service. It can help in relation to transfers of staff and the building-up of employment opportunitiesâall of those things that cooperative relations can achieve.

speech.para: Senator Crossin says that, because they were not cooperative in the past, they cannot be so in the future. That is a negative, disappointing approach to this issue. What we needâand I would say this to Senator Crossin and to Senator Bolkus, who also seeks to win political points out of these issuesâis to move forward. And a Northern Territory representative contributing constructively can be a significant step forwardâwithout any threat, because it is only one representative. I accept that it should be somebody who is satisfactory to the indigenous people.

That is a safeguard but, as we know, traditional owners are influenced by third parties and by people such as Senator Crossin who are much more interested in fighting the political battles than in the advancement of indigenous people. So they are influenced and decisions are not always made on the basis of what is the best outcome, but they get dragged into the political process of the Northern Territory. That is why we have put the provision in that consent will not be unreasonably withheld. Obviously, the person who would be found for these positions would be a person who is sensitive to indigenous issues. This provision will not come into effect for a 12-month period, and there will be no difficulty at all in finding a representative of the Northern Territory government who is sensitive to indigenous issues and can actually work to the betterment and improvement of the parks and of indigenous people who live in those parks. As I have said so many times, they are not just simply parks; they are also communities.

On the same subject, I heard it said yesterday that the government has not consulted. The government has consulted. I have consulted on these issues since this process started in 1996. As I said this morning, I listened to the consultations and I abandoned what I thought would be a good administrative reform by reinstating the position of the director of national parks because that was the request of the indigenous people and of the traditional owners of those two parks. I have watered down the provision and added extra safeguards in relation to the position of a Northern Territory representative so that there can be no threatâand there was never anyâor perceived threat. But will the Labor Party acknowledge that? Will Tracker Tilmouth acknowledge that? Of course not. If the Labor Party took Tracker Tilmouth seriously, they would have preselected him. They will not preselect him as a candidate but they come here and want to use his words to support their case.

There are so many other aspects that have been built into this package to ensure a full contribution by indigenous Australia. I want to make particular mention of that which we agreed with ATSIC, that is, to establish an indigenous advisory body. We recognise that indigenous Australians bring to the table a different perspective, a unique perspective, in relation to biodiversity. It is important that that perspective is part of the debate.

talk.start.para: âWhere is the funding coming from?
âWhat do you mean `where is the funding coming from'? We will fund it. The government will fund it.
âEnvironment or ATSIC?
âEnvironment will fund it.
âGood.

âAt least I got some acknowledgment from Senator Bolkus. That committee will ensure at the highest levels at the table an indigenous contribution to this broader environment debate, a contribution that has never been facilitated by such a structure in the past. I would have thought that that would be acknowledged by even the Labor Party. But no: because it would spoil a political point.

speech.para: There was not within the bill, and I have to acknowledge it was inadvertent, a specific place dedicated on the BDAC committee for an indigenous representative. That has been pointed out and it is now corrected, and it ought to be acknowledged. When I met with the board in Kakadu there were some misgivings about the quorum provisions imposed in the bill. Although I thought they were misconceived, I know they were repeated in submissions made by the Kakadu board and traditional owners to the Senate committee. We have taken steps to amend that so there can be no doubtâin other words, we listened to the indigenous representatives and we acted on their concerns.

Within this bill we have protection for traditional use of land and water in Commonwealth reserves, something that ought to be acknowledged and recognised. We provide for conservation agreements to be entered into with indigenous communities, which is a positive step in the right direction. As was mentioned in the last contribution, there will be a special place for indigenous Australia within the proposed study of access to biological resources because, again, as I said, there is a unique indigenous perspective of these issues and it is important that that perspective is part of the debate.

Consultation requirements have been expanded to address indigenous interests in relation to bilaterals and the recovery plans. That ought to be recognised and it certainly has been by those who take indigenous issues seriously. The objects of the bill have been expanded, also to address indigenous issues. Bilateral agreements will not apply to actions in relation to Kakadu, Uluru and Booderee, contrary, again, to what I recall Senator Crossin saying yesterday. A provision confirms that the bill does not affect the land rights act and the Native Title Act, contrary to what Tracker Tilmouth says in the document to which Senator Bolkus refers. All he has got to do is read the amendments and he would find that what he is asserting in that document is incorrect.

So if you package all of that up, you must concede there have been real steps to ensure that indigenous Australia has a vital place in the whole perspective of how our country manages its natural assets and conserves them to the benefit of future generations. It is in fact an unprecedented opportunity from which all Australians will benefit. Getting full benefit from the Aboriginal perspective is not just to the benefit of Aboriginal Australians but to the benefit of all Australians, and that has been our philosophical approach to this particular act. I hope, as such, that in this year it will be recognised and recalled as a significant contribution to reconciliation as well.

talk.start.para: âIt is remarkable, is it not, that the patronising can be so glib? The ultimate decision about who is on the boards of these great natural areas, which are indigenous people's areas and which, through their generosity of spirit, they have opened up to all Australians, is now being movedâby sleight of hand endorsed by the Democratsâinto the hands of a non-Aboriginal officer appointed by the government. That is where this process has ended up.

speech.para: I want to briefly talk about biodiversityâbecause I know Senator Crossin wants to speak on the indigenous issuesâand to follow up on what Senator Allison had to say about what a great deal the Democrats have got for biodiversity. Let me start by informing the Senate that half of the biodiversity in Australiaâthat is, half of the spectrum of wildlife and plant lifeâis in Australia's forests. We know that wildlife is concentrated in the forests of the world and, because of deforestation primarily, some 50 to 100 species of our fellow creatures on this planet are going to extinction every day.

Here in Australia the count is not kept. For example, in the Tasmanian forests, which are very much affected by this Democrat endorsed bill, there are some 10,000 forest insects. We do not know their role in the forests. We do know by rule of thumb that at least some of these creatures with their ancient lineage will be very important to human health and survival further down the line. But they are not listed, they are not studied and they are not protected.

The Democrats' process today involves endorsing what the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Robert Hillâwith his reputation as the worst minister for the environment in this nation's historyâhas done in the Regional Forest Agreement process, which says that all the unprotected forests of Western Australia, Victoria, Tasmania, New South Wales and Queensland will in future be out of reach of any federal minister. With that goes the wildlife and the plant life, and now with that comes the Democrats' endorsement. Senator Allison gets up and speaks glibly about what she is doing to protect things, but she is selling out half the wildlife species range in Australia in this one fell move.

Not only is she selling it out with her fellow Democratsâin the lap of the government, because they put their place at the Howard table ahead of Australia's biodiversityâbut she is saying, `We are going to pass this legislation'âthey will vote later today for the third readingâwhich means that for the next 20 years half the biodiversity of Australia is going to be unprotectable by the minister for the environment, because there is a bilateral agreement in place, unless a state government wants to come to the party. The states will have the control.

What we do know is that in Tasmania the governments are far from taking up that role. In the north-east highlands, beyond Ben Lomond and towards Weldboroughâif you can imagine the heart-shaped island of Tasmania, it is in the north-east cornerâa forest is being pulverised by the big woodchip companies, with the authority of the Howard government and now with the authority of the Democrats.

There has been turmoil in those forests, with people risking arrest not least because in the damper, more rainforested part of these highlands there are two species listed as endangered. The Simson stag beetle is a huge, magnificent, glistening forest floor forager. The north-east forest snail, Anoglypta Launcestonensis, is larger than the introduced garden snail with which most Australians are familiar. It is brilliant orange, and it has a magnificent carapace on its back. It is listed as endangered, but the loggers want its territory.

So what has been happening while the minister for the environment and the Democrats bind their hands? Forestry Tasmania has got in a consultant. The consultant said, `Well, yes, this has been listed as vulnerable, endangered and on its way to extinction, but we guess'âbecause they cannot do better than thatâ`that if we leave some remnants of this to-be-pulverised forest along rivers and roadsides, which we were going to leave anyway, and we let the bulldozers, chainsaws and firebombers drop incendiaries at the end of the season to burn to death everything in the logged areas, including the north-east forest snail on the endangered list, that's okay.'

Because this snail was getting in the way of logging, they have now gone so far as to move into a process of de-listing, Senator Allison. You do not know about this because you are not aware of the impact on the wellbeing of the biodiversityâthe spectrum of wildlife in this countryâof handing back power to state governments. We already know from the Regional Forest Agreementâhonoured now by the Democratsâthat when you hand Commonwealth responsibility for the nation's wildlife, its creatures and its diversity back to state governments, who are under pressure from corporate extractors, the corporate extractors win the day.

So, very early, one creature on the list of threatened and endangered species will simply be removed from the list. It is no longer going to be on the list as endangered because it is no longer going to be allowed to get in the way of the bulldozers, the chainsaws and those people who, at the end of the wrecking of these forest ecosystems in the highlands of north-east Tasmania, come with the firebombers and the 1080âand the same for the rest of this country and the diversity in those forests.

The Democrats today are endorsing the Robert Hill dictum that this embarrassing problem should be handed back to the loggers and the woodchippers. That is what this process is about, and that is why this is such a shameful dayâas the Democrats turn their backs on all those years of tub-thumping and saying that they stood for the environment. Today they stand for the chainsaws and the diminution of this nation's environment. The things that Senator Allison read out ought to be part of any decent piece of legislationâbut a minor part of it.

What is notable here is how much Senator Allison, when she went to that polished Howard table, failed to get. What is also notable is that Senator Allisonâso recently able to march the streets of Melbourne with conservationists for the protection of the forests of East Gippslandâis now endorsing the Regional Forest Agreement which is going to lead to the pulverisation of forests in East Gippsland and the threatening of species in East Gippsland. If you cross the border, breeding koala habitats are marked for destruction under the Regional Forest Agreement endorsed by this bill and about to be endorsed by Senator Allison, Senator Stott Despoja, Senator Woodley, Senator Bartlett, Senator Lees, Senator Murray and Senator Bourneâthese new friends of the government environmental wreckersâwhen they vote yes for this bill on the third reading later today. Let them live with it.

talk.start.para: âBefore I make some comments further to my speech yesterday, I want to say how terrific it is to see some young kids up in the public galleryâand young babies, at that. It is probably one of the very few places in this Parliament House where young children can go, and some of us live in hope for the day we have a child-care centre here that is as large as a gymnasium.
âA bit of relevance to the bill would be helpful, thank you, Senator Crossin.

âWe cannot just let these opportunities go by, Madam Chairman. I want to take some arguments through about one particular aspect of this bill, and that is the proposal to change the arrangements for the management of the national parks at Kakadu and at Uluru. I do not want to raise my voice and get angry, but I must say that I am surprised, Senator Allison. Last week we sat together at an inquiry to look at Jabiluka and we met the traditional owners from that area. One of the things that you must not have failed to grasp when we talked to those people is that all of these arrangementsâthe lease arrangements and the idea of us passing laws in Canberra to change their lifestyleâare very complex issues for them. I have met with these people time and time again, and they have not ruled out having a Northern Territory representative on the board; in fact, they have said they would welcome further discussions and thinking about it. But at this point in time they have said no to that.

speech.para: One of the things that must have impressed you, as it has impressed me, is that they talk about Aboriginal law being constant. It does not change; it has been with them for many, many years. So if you are going to put changes and suggestions to these people, they need time to think about them and synthesise them. When I put it to them that a Northern Territory government representative on the board may be the way to go, they talked about it and said, `Maybe, but we would want an increase in our Aboriginal representation if that were the case.'

In a letter from the Kakadu Board of Management which was sent on 18 June, they talk about perhaps being serious about having a Northern Territory representative on the board if the Kakadu Board of Management were to have statutory powers to run Kakadu National Park. So those are two suggestions that I have heard traditional owners in this area come forward with. In other words, they are prepared to negotiate and think about changes, but they are not prepared to tolerate people making decisions about the manage ment of the park without their being consultedâand by that I mean consulted in the last five, seven or 10 daysâabout these amendments. If there is one thing I would urge, Senator Allison, it is that this amendment be withdrawn while you take it back to Aboriginal people, get them to have a look at it, and bring it back in August. If nothing else is achieved today, perhaps this section of the bill could go away for further discussion with the people who matter.

What we are talking about here is an arrangement between people who own the land being leased to the Commonwealth. They have an arrangement as to who is going to control the park. They know who sits on the board of management and they have agreed to that, but it does change. They have not agreed to a change in composition of the board. They have not even had a chance to discuss your amendment or your proposal. The worse thing is that nobody even bothered to make two phone calls to the chairperson at Uluru and the chairperson at Kakadu. When you talk about a Northern Territory representative being on the board unless their consent is unreasonably withheld, what does that mean? Have you taken the time to explain to these traditional owners what those words mean? Even for the sake of this parliament, what does that mean?

Time and time again there have been a number of things that both this government and the Northern Territory government have done, things which Aboriginal people have not agreed with, but they have gone ahead anyway. The government has persisted. So I think at the end of the day the words `unreasonably withheld' will be shown to be meaningless.

Senator Allison quoted a letter from ATSIC. The other thing she should have learnt from talking to Aboriginal people is that they respect the words of the traditional owners. Gatjil Djerrkura and ATSIC do not speak for the traditional owners of Uluru and Kakadu. If you asked Gatjil Djerrkura, he would verify that. He is a traditional owner from north-east Arnhem Land. He cannot make and would not make decisions about Uluru and Kakudu, and I am sure he would support the traditional owners of Uluru and Kakadu in this stance.

Last week, in relation to the Jabiluka approval process, when we asked the traditional owners whether they had been consulted by this government and by this company, Yvonne Margarula said to all of us who were present, `They talked to the traditional owners in this area, but we are the ones who count; we own the land. Other traditional owners disagree with us, but they do agree in our right to say what we want to happen with our land.' If you ask Gatjil Djerrkura whether in fact he upheld the views of the boards of management at Uluru and Kakuda, and ask Mick Alderson and Joanne Willmot for their views, they would support the boards of management. I have no doubt on that. I think this view goes more to a general statement about the bill, as opposed to these specific areas. We have received a couple of letters from Kakadu in only the last 24 hours which talk about either stopping or slowing the process of this legislation. They go on to say:
When the current government came to power, the way of doing business changed in Kakadu and joint management from the inside is now not so good.
From Uluru, in a letter to Meg Lees, those people say:
The traditional owners are asking you and other senators not to agree to amendments to do with their land but to delay the passage of the bill.

They are not saying, `Don't pass it.' What they are saying is, `Delay it.' On behalf of the constituents whom I represent, who have control over these two parks, perhaps what I am saying to you is that this is one area that should just be set aside while you go back and ask them if this is what they want or whether there could be a compromise in order to achieve this. The letter from Uluru goes on to say:
The minister has misled us by initially declaring that the proposed Bill would not affect the joint management arrangements at all.

Senator Hill will say, `There is no change.' In the minds of the traditional owners there is a significant change. First of all, they have not been consulted about these changes in the last week. Secondly, they have an arrangement with the Commonwealth that does not involve a state or territory government representative on the board, and they do not understand the words `unreasonably withheld'. You need time to sit down and talk to the traditional owners about that. They go on further to say:
The bill was then tabled in the House of Representatives before we were aware of its grave implications to existing arrangements.
They also say:
The Minister has not agreed to repeated requests for sufficient time to consult properly and negotiate what amounts to the future of joint management.

I think in this case they are right. They have also raised the fact that they believe there are legal requirements which have not been fulfilled in the process of preparing these new bills. That is not a road which I want to go down, but I do want to impress on people here, particularly on the Democrats and on Senator Hill, that out of the blue we had amendments tabled on Monday nightâit does not come as a surpriseâwhere the traditional owners at Kakadu and Uluru know you have been thinking about expanding the membership of the board. They have not ruled it out. They have already put a couple of compromises to you about them having statutory powers to run the park or perhaps increasing their number of representatives. Those compromises are certainly in correspondence that I have received and they are certainly in correspondence that Meg Lees has receivedâboth letters are in front of me.

These people do not want to shut the gate; neither do these people want to be dictated to and told what the new arrangements are. It is not the way they operate, it is not the way they want to operate and it is not the way they should have to operate because they own that land. That area has been disregarded in all of this. It would be like you leasing your house to some person and a third party coming in to sit on your board of management to help you control that lease arrangement. Unless you had been consulted about that, I would have thought you would be pretty annoyed about it.

I am trying to impress on you that there is no urgency about this section of the bill. There is no requirement to get this part of the bill through by midnight tonight. The tradi tional owners of these national parks have put their trust in the Commonwealth and have undertaken a lease with the government to run that park. They are now saying, simply, `You want to change our best practice arrangements and you want to change the way in which the park is managed. You want an additional person on that board, but we have not said yes to that.' Mind you, they have not said no outright either. As well, you have not offered them a complementary person, so you are not going to increase the numbersâ

talk.start.para: âI did. They rejected it.
âMaybe you need to go back and now put this proposal.
âI did. It went back and back again.

âHave you been back to them, Minister, since these amendments have been tabled? I would say that the answer to that is no. You could not possibly have done that since Monday when these amendments were tabled, or else these letters would reflect otherwise.
