subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 10 December 1998, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThere are enormous concerns about this Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1998 [1999] as well as the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998 [1999] . One of the main concerns emanates from the title. We are asked as a Senate to consider the Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1998 [1999] , but that title is something which does not satisfactorily reflect the legislation. Once again we have a bodgying up of the process, once again we have an abuse of the rules and once again we have the government trying to conceal something in this legislation that they should really be more up-front about. Once again we have the Australian Democrats as the conspiratorial joint party to this particular deception.

speech.para: Let me read what the Parliamentary Library say about this legislation. They make some comments about the legislation and about how this bill is described as a `consequential amendment' bill. They say on page 22 of their report:

The Office of Parliamentary Counsel has advised that although there is no formal limitation on the content or scope of a `consequential amendments' Bill, such a Bill would usually contain provisions required to implement a new legislative scheme and would not normally contain provisions (technical or otherwise) that were unrelated to the scheme's establishment.

This Bill implements a range of necessary amendments that are consequential to the implementation of the EP&BC Bill. However the Bill also makes a range of other amendments which can be interpreted as substantial new proposals which supplement, rather than arise from, the EP&BC Bill. This raises issues as to the adequacy of consultation and scrutiny of these substantive measures by all relevant stakeholders. On that point, it is notable that the current Bill was not included in the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee's inquiry into the EP&BC Bill 1998 until 24 March 1999. The Committee reported on 27 April 1999.

They are the two primary concerns. First of all, you have misdescription. You have this legislation described as `consequential' when in essence it is more than consequential. In essence it raises other measures that are of enormous relevance and importance to stakeholders but about which those stakeholders have not had the normal advance notice. More importantly, this bill was sent to the committee late in the processâonly three or four weeks before the committee reported.

These are not minor amendments. They are also reflective of how this legislation has been handled by this government and this parliament. We have had amendments introduced to the major bill and amendments to the consequential bill. Those amendments have been discussed in secret but, in respect of this bill as well as the other, we have not had engagement with industry or with the states, I must sayâand the states have an enormous stake in the management of operations under these two billsâand, extremely importantly in respect of this particular consequential provisions bill, we have had no engagement with indigenous Australians. We are not talking about inconsequential amendments; we are talking about consequential amendments. Yesterday Senator Hill said that, if we were serious, we would have given him notice in respect of certain matters before we came in here yesterday.

Well, if he were serious in respect of this legislation, he would have given usâthis parliamentânotice as to his amendments before we came in yesterday. So, once again, this legislation is in the same category as the major piece of legislationâthat is, there are amendments to it; amendments which have avoided public scrutiny and which have not had sufficient parliamentary scrutiny as well. When you are looking at the process, something like 20 seconds per amendment is totally inadequate parliamentary scrutiny.

The best assessment of this legislation also comes from the library's Bills Digest. What does this legislation do? It does exactly the sorts of things that we have been talking about for some little while in this place. It affects indigenous people's interest in, stake in and rights on the boards of management of the Kakadu National Park, the Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park and the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community council. It appears that, although these issues were raised in the 1998 consultation paper, it was not indicated in the central aspects of the act that changes would be made. So you had indigenous Australians having to take last-minute mercy dashes to appear before the committee to try and defend their positions as to joint management and their concern in respect of the abolition of the position of the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service. That is something that we are told has been wound back, but we have not been told the details of that. There were concerns in respect of what they thought would be a compulsory transfer of the lease from the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service to the Commonwealth.

These matters in themselves are important matters, not consequential on the other legislation, but they were thrown in here primarily, I suppose, because the government was thinking that we would believe it was an after-thought, but they were thrown in here in a way that did not give stakeholders sufficient notice. The concept of the addition of a Northern Territory board member also arises in this consequential legislation. This legislation also affects the traditional use of land and water by Aboriginals. Section 70 provides, in essence, a limitation of rights to those appearing in the current legislation, so we do have some concerns in respect of indigenous Australians.

We also have concerns as to what this particular legislation does to the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. Not having done enough damage in their primary legislation, the government then seeks to amend the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. The Council of Australian Governments' 1997 heads of agreement provides the policy basis for the proposed EPBC act. It states that the Commonwealth and state heritage ministers would develop a cooperative national heritage protection strategy. The government's environment reform 1998 consultation paper proposed the introduction of a new heritage protection law at a date following the debate on the primary legislation.

This new heritage legislation has not been introduced in the parliament. Given this, we would deem it inappropriate to remove the links between the Commonwealth environ ment minister and the Australian Heritage Commission in relation to actions that may impact on heritage areas. In order to avoid the creation of a regulatory vacuum on these issues, it may beâand we will be moving amendments to this effectâadvisable to continue the operation of the EP(IP) Act in relation to heritage matters until a new heritage regime is introduced.

We should save the operation of the Heritage Commission Actâour amendments will go to that. But, given the conduct of proceedings in the last 24 hours or so, there is absolutely no way that those substantive amendments will get up. We might get some mealy-mouthed alternative from the Democrats, we may get some promise of a committee or an inquiry down the trackâall those sorts of thingsâbut the substantive operation of the Australian Heritage Commission will be affected by this legislation, as will the operation of the world heritage protection act itself. We have in the government's legislation some incremental improvement in respect of the protection of world heritage areas but we also have some monumental wind-back from the currently prevailing law, and we are also seeking to protect those provisions that are about to be affected.

There are other aspects. There are amendments to the Lands Acquisition Act and there is the repeal of the Biological Control Act 1984, all under the guise of consequential amendments. So we say the government stands condemned because this is not a consequential amendments bill; this does much more than that. We say the government and the Democrats stand condemned because they have entered into an arrangement which does over some substantive rights and some pretty substantial protections in terms of indigenous Australians, world heritage and the AHC. We also say they stand condemned because no-one in here, let alone anyone outside of here, has had enough opportunity to give this legislation adequate scrutiny.

talk.start.para: âThe previous speaker in this debate on the Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1998 [1999] was absolutely right. Not only are we in the position where we are dealing with a bill which claims to be consequential on the major environment bill that has been debated for much of the day, but also we have been asked by the government to deal with this bill before that environment bill has gone through and before we even know how it is going to be amended. That is an extraordinary situation for the Senate to find itself in. It shows that the government and the Democrats are in a complete mess as far as the handling of this environment legislation is concerned. They do not know what their strategy is. They did bring in the guillotine. They thought that was the end of it and that all this stuff would be finished by half past five this evening, but now they are in a complete mess because people on this side of the house who think differently from the Democrats and the government about the environment have wanted the debate to go on.

speech.para: Let me just take up what Senator Bolkus said a moment ago about the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. The Australian Heritage Commission was established in the wake of the flooding of Lake Pedder in 1972. There was a national parliamentary inquiry into that disaster by the then Whitlam government in 1974. That inquiry found that never again should the Commonwealth be in the position of not intervening on the loss of heritage of national significance, that such places ought to be listed and that there ought to be a facility for warning the federal government when such heritage, be it natural heritage or cultural heritage, was at risk. As a result of that, the Australian Heritage Commission was established in 1975.

The commission has had a major role in the defence of Australia's environment since then, even though in the last decade successive governments have tried to wind down its influence and power. I am very well aware that the Heritage Commission was central to the saving of the Franklin River. The Australian Democrats claim a role in that but their role pales into insignificance when compared with the active role of the Australian Heritage Commission at the time. In fact, the Australian Heritage Commission was so active at that stage in alerting politicians and the public to the threats to the Franklin River that no doubt in the collective political memory that was a reason for it being put under strangulating political repression in the years that have followed.

The legislation that the Democrats and the government are railroading through the chamber todayâwe will get back onto that later at the committee stageâeffectively gets rid of the Australian Heritage Commission and its relevance. But the agreement between the states and the Commonwealth has been that, instead of having the Heritage Commission, there be a joint arrangement. Let me outline how that arrangement would go. Following the meeting of the Council of Australian Government heads in 1997âthat is, the state and federal headsâthere was an agreement for the Commonwealth and state heritage ministers to develop a cooperative national heritage strategy. Let me interpret that. The arrangement was to get rid of the functions of the Australian Heritage Commission and replace it with ecowaffleâa passing of the buck between Commonwealth and state heritage ministersâwhich was going to do nothing in particular to protect heritage in the way the 1975 establishment of the Australian Heritage Commission was meant to do.

The government's environment reform 1998 consultation paper proposed the introduction of a new heritage protection law following the environment bill which the Democrats are pushing through this place today at the behest of the government. This new heritage bill would be the replacement, essentially, for the Australian Heritage Commission and its past good works. But we do not have such a bill. Here we have legislation effectively getting rid of the Australian Heritage Commission on the promise that there will be a Commonwealth-state arrangement to replace it, but there is no replacement. We have a vacuum of that function. It has been abolished. We are back to the flooding of Lake Pedder, thanks to the Democrats supporting the government on this matter.

We are being asked to support what is called a consequential bill which is nothing of the sort. It is a bill to abolish the Australian Heritage Commission's powers and replace them with nothing at all. I will not be part of that. The Democrats, of course, will be, because they do not even understand what is in this consequential bill. They are more interested in their moment of power at the Howard table of power. They are more interested in selling out any environmental principle that will get in the way of them keeping that seat at the table. They are more interested in trying to put a gloss on the environmental disaster that they are delivering through this parliament to the people of Australia in these terrible days for the environment. If an arrangement has been made between the states and the Commonwealth to look after matters of national heritage importanceâif this cooperative national strategy has been establishedâI ask Senator Woodley, who is the only Democrat in the chamber, to get up and explain what it is.

talk.start.para: âYou are the only Green.

âSenator Abetz intervenes from the other side of the chamber, but he does not know either. We could ask him to get up and explain this alternative that we are supposed to accept as coming into place which is not mentioned anywhere in the bill. It is a wing and a prayer, or at least a promise that we are supposed to accept coming from the chainsaw driven offices of the minister for the environment or, as we now have it, the subservient hand on the chainsaw gang of Democrat senators who have sold out so comprehensively on the environment these last few days. I know that no Democrat will explain to the Senate what they are doing, for the simple reason that they do not know. They have abrogated their policies; they have dumped their policies. In the vacuum that that leaves, they are simply reliant on Howard government environmental policies. That is the measure of their strength of commitment to the environment these days.

speech.para: The Democrats are prepared to guillotine this bill but they do not have the foggiest about how to explain why we should be voting for a situation where the Australian Heritage Commission goes west and the promised replacement is nowhere to be seen. We are in this extraordinary situation on another matterâbiological control. We are being asked to deal with legislation which gets rid of the effects of the Biological Control Act 1984 because they are no longer appropriate, but we have not yet dealt with those amendments to the environment protection bill. We have this extraordinary situation, this remarkable failure of process by the Democrats. There is not even a Democrat adviser in the place. They have fled altogether to try to work out what this bill is about, because they were not ready for it.

They were depending on the so-called environment protection billâI would call it the environment wreckage billâbeing passed. It has not been passed because they have been outmanoeuvred this afternoon by the people on this side of the chamber. The guillotine was not dropped on debate on that important environment legislation at 5 o'clock because, despite the combined brains of the government and the Democrats, they still did not see what was coming and they were outmanoeuvred. That outmanoeuvring means that the environment protection bill has not gone through. We do not know what the outcome is going to be, but here are the Democrats asking us to abolish the biological control provisions which the Commonwealth currently has in place. They have not replaced them with anything. They talk about how they want biodiversity protected in this country, but they are getting rid of control mechanisms and so far they have put nothing else in their place.

That is why they are such environmental puppies. As I said yesterday, they have rushed around the room barking at everybody and then jumped onto the first lap available. They are political poodles. Of course, the first lap available was Senator Hill's. Last week on the GST it was the Prime Minister's, with room also on Mr Costello's. But the Democrats do not know what they are doing, except for this: they do know that there is an open door at the end of the green carpeted corridor, on the occasions when it suits the government, where they can sit and feel important. And they will trash any policy to keep that door open and they have trashed many a policy in the last few days. We have this extraordinary situation where, having got rid of protection mechanisms which have been developed over recent decades, as of this moment they have nothing to replace them with.

We do not know whether or not the amendments to the environment protection bill are going to go through. We have no way of knowing that. It would be quite irresponsible of us to deal with this so-called consequential bill which abolishes the existing protection for the environment until we know what is going to happen with the major bill, which the Democrats are supporting the government to get through. That is the extraordinary tangle we have got into. Maybe it is worth recalling that time-honoured quote:
Oh what a tangled web we weave when first we practise to deceive.

The Democrats have practised to deceive those people who voted for themâthe environmentalists; a million Australians who thought that they would stand by the environment; people all across this country who thought that the Democrats' record would be good. Can you imagine what would have happened to the Democrats if their sell out over the last fortnight on their social and environmental principles had been known to the electorate last October? They would have been decimated. I have to admit to being one of the millions of Australians who is gobsmacked by the way in which they have dropped every founding principle of the party to get to the table of power. That is what they have done, but I am not going to be one who supports this piece of legislation and leaves a vacuum. There may be a vacuum of Democrat policy; there is now a vacuum of Democrat principle.

There is now a failure to understand the almighty consequences of what they have done by Senator Lees, Senator Stott Despoja, Senator Bourne from New South Wales, Senator Woodley and Senator Bartlett from Queensland, and Senator Murray from Western Australia. There is a vacuum of appreciation of what they have done, but they are sticking with it because they want to be counted as one of the big players. As one of those senators said to a business lunch, as reported in the national media a couple of weeks ago, they are flushed not only with the new sense of power but also with the prospect now of getting some of the kick-backsâthat is, donationsâthat come from the corporate sector when you do the right thing, as far as vested interests are concerned in this place. The Democrats are moving from being a party of the people and the environment to being creatures of the big end of town. That is what this is all about.

However, when such revolutions in process occur, there are glitches and one is occurring right now. I note that Senator Lees has come into the chamber and therefore I expect that we are going to have a clearing of the air by Senator Lees as to what has happened to the Australian Heritage Commission's powers; why there is no replacement; and why she is asking the Senate to effectively abolish the powers of the Australian Heritage Commission and replace them with nothing else at this particular juncture on this Wednesday afternoon in June 1999.

talk.start.para: âWe have just listened for about 20 minutes to an assault on the Australian Democrats by the sole Tasmanian Green in this chamber. The reason that he had to devote all that time to assaulting the Australian Democrats is that it is quite clear he has not read the bill. He has not considered its provisions so he has embarked on an attack of the Democrats. But I would just kindly remind him that, on page 11 of the explanatory memorandum, he might find some of the answers to the questions that he posed in a rhetorical way. If he had spent more time studying the legislation and the explanatory memorandum, he might have been in a position of not having to devote so much of his 20 minutes to a wholesale assault on the Australian Democrats.

speech.para: The bill that we are considering is the Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1998 [1999] . This bill continues the process of Commonwealth environmental legislation. Labor and the Greens used to talk big about the environment, but they failed to deliver. What they cannot abide is the fact that, since the Howard government was elected, there has been a program of environmental reform in this country not witnessed before. Of course, the Natural Heritage Trust is one of the examples of environmental reform in this country. It has delivered millions of dollars for repair to the environmentâa project never thought of by Labor or the Greens but one that we were able to do because we were willing to forgo the public ownership of Telstra to ensure that something more important remained within our grasp; that is, the environment of this country. So the Natural Heritage Trust is part of our environment reform program, as is the Green Corpsâa fantastic program that has delivered environmental repair throughout the breadth of this nation.

But has Senator Brown acknowledged the wonderful work of the Natural Heritage Trust? Does he acknowledge the wonderful work of all those volunteers in the Green Corps, who actually do something for the environment? Absolutely not. Senator Brown locks himself away in his rooms and dreams up these speeches. I have to say that I think the dreaming has lapsed somewhat of late because it is the same speech repeated time and time again. It is becoming a bit boring. All we ever get to hear about is a chainsaw. In fact, he is starting to sound like a chainsawâthat repetitive buzz and the noise do not make much sense, except in Senator Brown's mind; most of his contributions these days are not to build up but to destroy.

We have the Natural Heritage Trust and we have the Green Corps program. What else have we done for the environment? We have the wonderful Regional Forest Agreement that, for the first time in this country's history, has balanced conservation and the needs of the forest communities who get a living from the forests. Let us not forget that what we harvest from the forests is in fact a renewable resource. If you do not have the timber harvesting, what do you have? I suppose you have mining for building products insteadâproducts which are not renewable. So the timber industry is vital.

talk.start.para: âYou still have mining products for building that are not renewable, but you need them.

âSorry, Senator Murphy? You are not making sense againâa bit like your contributions with Premier Jim Bacon. The regional forest agreements have been another wonderful example of this federal government getting to terms with the environmental problems of this nation and making a contribution in a way that will have lasting benefit. On top of that wonderful record, we now have this legislation and the bill that was just before us.

speech.para: This bill has three primary objectives. Firstly, it will provide for the repeal of the five acts to be replaced by the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998 [1999] . Those acts are: the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974; the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975; the Whale Protection Act 1980; the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983; and the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992. It makes sense to have this reform of environmental legislation. Secondly, the bill puts in place savings and arrangements for a smooth transition from the processes that are in place under the existing acts, including environmental assessment and permitting arrangements to the new schemes established under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998 [1999] .

Thirdly, the bill also amends Commonwealth government legislation that is affected either by the repeal of the five acts or by the content of the proposed Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998 [1999] . This bill, together with the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998, provides a new environmental law regime which enables the Commonwealth to join with the states in providing a truly national scheme of environmental protection and biodiversity conservation, recognising our responsibility to not only this but also future generations.

What this legislation is about is trying to ensure that we as a federation cooperate with the states on environmental issues, rather than taking the sledgehammer approach like Senator Brown, who could not win the debates in his home state of Tasmania and therefore had to seek federal intervention to win them. We say that, instead of having that `them and us' approach to environmental issues, it makes a lot more sense to cooperate with the states and ensure that we are able to work in a responsible, user-friendly way to deliver benefits to the environment and, as a result, to future generations.

(445) Page 306 (after line 23), at the end of Part 15, add:
The following is a simplified outline of this Division:
The Governor-General can proclaim a Commonwealth area to be a conservation zone, to protect biodiversity in the area while it is being assessed for inclusion in a Commonwealth reserve.
Regulations can be made to regulate a wide range of activities in a conservation zone.
People who have rights relating to an area that is later included in a conservation zone can continue to exercise those rights in the zone.

A conservation zone can be revoked if the Minister is satisfied the area concerned should not be included in a Commonwealth reserve. It is revoked automatically if it is included in a Commonwealth reserve.

The object of this Division is to provide for the protection of biodiversity, other natural features and heritage in Commonwealth areas while they are being assessed for inclusion in a Commonwealth reserve.
(1) The Governor-General may, by Proclamation, declare a Commonwealth area outside a Commonwealth reserve to be a conservation zone.

(2) Before the Governor-General makes a Proclamation declaring a Commonwealth area to be a conservation zone, the Minister must be satisfied that the area should be assessed to determined whether the biodiversity, other natural features and heritage in the area should be protected by including the area in a Commonwealth reserve.
(1) The regulations may:
(a) regulate or prohibit the pollution of soil, air or water in a manner that is, or is likely to be, harmful to:
(i) people, biodiversity or heritage in conservation zones; or
(ii) the natural features of conservation zones; and
(b) regulate tourism in conservation zones; and
(c) provide for the protection and preservation of conservation zones and property and things in conservation zones; and
(d) provide for the protection and conservation of biodiversity in conservation zones; and
(e) regulate or prohibit access to all or part of a conservation zone by persons or classes of persons; and
(f) provide for the removal of trespassers from conservation zones; and
(g) regulate camping in conservation zones; and
(h) provide for the safety of persons in conservation zones; and
(i) regulate the use of fire in conservation zones; and
(j) regulate the conduct of persons in conservation zones; and
(k) regulate the carrying on of any trade or commerce in a conservation zone; and
(l) regulate the use of vehicles in conservation zones and provide for signs and road markings for those purposes; and
(m) provide for:
(i) the removal of vehicles, aircraft or vessels from places in conservation zones where they have been left in contravention of the regulations or have been abandoned; and
(ii) the impounding of such vehicles, aircraft or vessels; and

(n) provide that the person taken for the purposes of the regulations to be the owner of a motor vehicle involved in a contravention of a provision of the regulations relating to the parking or stopping of vehicles in a conservation zone is, except as provided otherwise, taken to commit an offence against the provision; and

(o) provide for a person to be taken to be the owner of a motor vehicle for the purposes of regulations made under paragraph (n) (including a person in whose name the motor vehicle is registered under the law of a State or Territory); and
(p) regulate the use of vessels in, and the passage of vessels through, conservation zones; and
(q) regulate the landing and use of aircraft in, and the flying of aircraft over, conservation zones; and
(r) regulate or prohibit the taking of animals or plants into or out of conservation zones; and
(s) provide for the impounding, removal, destruction or disposal of animals found straying in conservation zones; and
(t) regulate or prohibit the taking into conservation zones, and the use in conservation zones, of weapons, traps, nets, snares, fishing apparatus and other devices; and
(u) regulate or prohibit the laying of baits and the use of explosives and poisons in conservation zones; and
(v) provide for the collection of specimens and the pursuit of research in conservation zones for scientific purposes; and

(w) provide for the issue of licences, permits and authorities relating to activities in conservation zones, the conditions subject to which they are issued and the charging of fees by the Commonwealth in respect of such licences, permits and authorities; and
(x) provide for any matter incidental to or connected with a matter described in another paragraph.
(2) Regulations relating to conservation zones may also:
(a) regulate the carrying on of mining operations, fishing, pastoral or agricultural activities for commercial purposes; and
(b) regulate the construction or alteration of buildings and structures; and
(c) regulate the construction or establishment of bridges, railways, roads, tracks, port facilities and air-strips and the carrying out of any other works; and
(d) regulate the felling or taking of timber; and

(e) provide for and in relation to the powers to be exercised, and the functions and duties to be performed, in and in relation to conservation zones by wardens, by rangers and by other persons included in specified classes of persons; and

(f) provide for and in relation to the giving of securities for compliance with regulations made for the purposes of this section by persons doing, or proposing to do, anything to which those regulations relate.

(3) Regulations made for the purposes of this section have no effect to the extent that they are inconsistent with the terms and conditions of a right (however described) to explore for minerals, or to mine for or recover minerals, granted under section 124 of the Lands Acquisition Act 1989 .

para.inline: 390F Charges for activities in conservation zones

interjection.para: Subject to the approval of the Minister, the Director may determine and impose charges for using services or facilities provided by the Director in or in connection with a conservation zone.

para.inline: 390G Other laws and regulations made for this Division
Regulations regulating aircraft subject to other Commonwealth laws

interjection.para: (1) A provision of the regulations regulating the flying of aircraft over a conservation zone does not have any effect so far as it is inconsistent with a law of the Commonwealth. For this purpose, a provision is not inconsistent with such a law if it can be complied with without contravention of the law.

(2) A law of a Territory has effect so far as it is not inconsistent with a provision of the regulations made for the purposes of this Division and having effect in that Territory. For this purpose, such a law is not inconsistent with the provision so far as it can operate concurrently with the provision.

para.inline: 390H Prior usage rights relating to conservation zones continue to have effect

interjection.para: (1) None of the following provisions affect a usage right that was held by a person (other than the Commonwealth) in relation to land or seabed immediately before the land or seabed was included in a conservation zone:
(a) provisions of this Division that relate to the zone (whether or not they also relate to another conservation zone);
(b) provisions of the regulations made for the purposes of this Division that relate to the zone (whether or not they also relate to another conservation zone).
(2) None of the provisions covered by subsection (1) affect the application of a law of a State or Territory in relation to the usage right.
(3) The usage right may be renewed or have its term extended only:
(a) with the Minister's written consent; and
(b) subject to any conditions determined by the Minister.
This subsection has effect despite subsections (1) and (2) and any other law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory.

(4) Subsections (1) and (2) apply in relation to a usage right relating to minerals on, in or under land or seabed included in a conservation zone as if the usage right were a usage right relating to the land or seabed.
(5) This section applies to a right arising out of a usage right in the same way as it applies to the usage right.

para.inline: Proclamations to revoke or amend declaring Proclamation

interjection.para: (1) The Governor-General may, by Proclamation, revoke or amend a Proclamation made under section 390D (declaring a Commonwealth area to be a conservation zone).

(2) Before the Governor-General makes a Proclamation under subsection (1) causing a Commonwealth area to cease to be within a conservation zone, the Minister must be satisfied that the area should not be included in a Commonwealth reserve.

para.inline: Declaration of Commonwealth reserve revokes conservation zone

interjection.para: (3) A Commonwealth area ceases to be a conservation zone by force of this subsection if the area becomes or is included in a Commonwealth reserve.

para.inline: Conservation zone ends if it ceases to be in Commonwealth area

interjection.para: (4) If land, waters, seabed or airspace in a conservation zone cease to be a Commonwealth area, the land, waters, seabed or airspace cease to be (or be in) a conservation zone by force of this subsection.

para.inline: Proclamation to reflect cessation of conservation zone

interjection.para: (5) If land, waters, seabed or airspace cease to be a conservation zone by force of subsection (3) or (4), the Governor-General must make a Proclamation revoking or amending the Proclamation that included the land, waters, seabed or airspace in a conservation zone, to reflect the fact that the land, waters, seabed or airspace are no longer part of the conservation zone.
Amendments agreed to.

para.inline: 266C Adding invasive species to the list

subdebate.1.para: The Minister must add an invasive species to the list if the Minister is satisfied that it is necessary to include the species in the list to prevent significant damage to any listed threatened species, ecological community or critical habitat.

para.inline: 266D Minister must consider advice from Scientific Committee

subdebate.1.para: (1) In deciding whether to add an item to, or delete an item from, the list, the Minister must, in accordance with the regulations (if any), obtain and consider advice from the Scientific Committee on the scientific aspects of the addition or deletion of the item concerned.
(2) The Minister must:
(a) decide whether to add an item to, or delete an item from, the list; and
(b) if the Minister decides to add or delete the itemâcause the necessary instrument to be published in the Gazette ;
within 90 days after receiving the Scientific Committee's advice on the addition or deletion of the item.

(3) A member of the Scientific Committee has a duty not to disclose to any other person the advice, or any information relating to the advice, before the end of that period of 90 days unless the disclosure:
(a) is for the official purposes of the Scientific Committee; or
(b) if an instrument is published in the Gazette relating to an addition or deletion to which the advice relatesâoccurred after the publication.

para.inline: 266E Minister to make lists available to the public

subdebate.1.para: The Minister must, in accordance with the regulations (if any), make copies of up-to-date lists available for purchase, for a reasonable price, at a prescribed place in each State and self-governing Territory.

para.inline: 266F Possession etc of listed invasive species

subdebate.1.para: (1) Subject to subsection 266G, a person is guilty of an offence if:
(a) the person has in his or her possession a member of an invasive species; and
(b) the member is a member of a listed invasive species; and
(c) the member has been unlawfully imported.
Note: Chapter 2 of the Criminal Code sets out the general principles of criminal responsibility.
(2) Subject to section 266G, a person is guilty of an offence if:
(a) the person trades, keeps or moves a member of an invasive species; and
(b) the member is a member of a listed invasive species; and
(c) the member has been taken in or on a Commonwealth area.
Note: Chapter 2 of the Criminal Code sets out the general principles of criminal responsibility.
(3) Strict liability applies to paragraphs (1)(c) and (2)(c).
Note: For strict liability , see section 6.1 of the Criminal Code .
(4) An offence against subsection (1) or (2) is punishable on conviction by imprisonment for not more than 2 years or a fine not exceeding 1,000 penalty units, or both.

para.inline: 266G Section 266F does not apply to certain actions

subdebate.1.para: Section 266F does not apply to:
(a) an action authorised by a permit that is in force; or
(b) an action provided for by, and taken in accordance with, a threat abatement plan made under Division 5 and that is in force; or
(c) an action that is reasonably necessary to prevent a risk to human health; or
(d) an action by a Commonwealth agency, or an agency of a State or of a self-governing Territory, that is reasonably necessary for the purposes of law enforcement; or
(e) an action that is reasonably necessary to deal with an emergency involving a serious threat to human life or property; or
(f) an action that occurs as a result of an unavoidable accident, other than an accident caused by negligent or reckless behaviour.
Note: A defendant bears an evidential burden in relation to the matters in this section. See subsection 13.3(3) of the Criminal Code .

(1) Subject to subsection (2), the holder of a permit may give to a person written authority to do for or on behalf of the holder any act authorised by the permit. The authority may be given generally or as otherwise provided by the instrument of authority.
(2) The holder of a permit must not give an authority unless:

(b) the authority is given in accordance with any requirements set out in the condition.

(4) The giving of an authority does not prevent the doing of any act by the holder of the permit.
(5) Except as provided in this section, a permit does not authorise the doing of any act by a person for or on behalf of the holder of the permit.
(6) A person who gives an authority must give to the Minister written notice of it within 14 days after giving the authority.

speech.para: (37) Page 211 (after line 24), after Division 4, insert:

para.inline: 266A Protection of high conservation value native forests

speech.para: A person must not:
(a) take wood or clear vegetation from, or destroy vegetation in, a high conservation value native forest after 1 January 2000; or
(b) trade in, keep, move or process wood harvested after 1 January 2000 from a high conservation value native forest.
Civil penalty:
(a) for an individualâ5,000 penalty units;
(b) for a body corporateâ50,000 penalty units.
Subsection (1) has effect:
(a) in relation to acts done by any person in relation to a high conservation value native forest that:
(i) is or is part of an area identified as a World Heritage Area under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 ; or
(ii) is or is part of a place that the Commonwealth is obliged to protect under the World Heritage Convention; or
(iii) is or is part of a place identified as having world heritage value under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 ; and
(b) for the purpose of giving effect to:
(i) the Convention on Biological Diversity; or
(ii) a prescribed international instrument.
(3) In addition, subsection (1) has effect in relation to acts done by a constitutional corporation.
A person must not export from Australia after 1 January 2000 woodchips obtained or derived from any native forest.
Civil penalty:
(a) for an individualâ5,000 penalty units;
(b) for a body corporateâ50,000 penalty units.
266C What is a high conservation value native forest ?
In this Act:
forest means a vegetation community dominated by trees with a projective foliage cover greater than 30%.
high conservation value native forest means a native forest on public land that satisfies one or more of the following paragraphs:
(a) a native forest growing on land within a subcatchment containing rainforest or within 500 metres of rainforest, whichever is the lesser area;
(b) a native forest place listed on the Register of the National Estate or the Interim Register of the National Estate for their biological values;

(c) a World Heritage Area identified under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 , a place that the Commonwealth is obliged to protect under the World Heritage Convention, or a place identified as having world heritage value;
(d) a subcatchment or area of at least 500 hectares surrounding sites in which any of the following species have been recorded since 1 January 1980:
(i) species listed in Schedule 1 of the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992;
(ii) species listed as endangered or vulnerable in the Nature Conservation (Wildlife) Regulation 1994 of Queensland (for sites in Queensland);
(iii) species listed in Schedule 12 of the National Parks and Wildlife Act 1974 of New South Wales (for sites in New South Wales);
(iv) species listed as threatened in section 13 of the Threatened Species Protection Act 1995 of Tasmania (for sites in Tasmania);
(v) species declared specially protected flora and fauna under paragraph 14(2)(ba) or section 23F of the Wildlife Conservation Act 1950 of Western Australia (for sites in Western Australia);
(vi) species listed in Schedule 1 (for sites in Victoria);
(e) an old growth native forest covering 10 hectares or more;
(f) a wilderness area.

native forest means forest dominated by tree species native to the locality in which it occurs and where natural regeneration processes operate either fully or in part for recovery of canopy structure following natural or artificial disturbance.

old growth native forest means native forest that is ecologically mature (the upper stratum or overstorey is in the late mature to over-mature phases) and has been subjected to negligible unnatural disturbance such as logging, roading and clearing.
plantation means an area of trees planted and managed in an agricultural context for purposes including wood production.
rainforest means native forest which is fire sensitive, has a more or less continuous closed canopy of variable height and has a characteristic diversity of species and life forms, and includes:
(a) transitional and seral communities with sclerophyll emergents that are of similar botanical composition to mature rainforest in which sclerophyll emergents are absent; and
(b) disturbed native forests that can be expected to recover the defined characteristics.
species includes a sub-species.

wilderness means any area larger than 3000 hectares which has a National Wilderness Inventory wilderness quality of 12 or greater, and any area identified as wilderness under the Wilderness Act 1987 of New South Wales.

World Heritage Convention means the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage that has been adopted by the General Conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, being the convention a copy of the English text of which is set out in the Schedule to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 .
The Minister must prepare a strategy by 1 January 2000 to achieve:
(a) recognition of the need for Australia to move from a native forest based wood products industry to a plantation based wood products industry; and
(b) management of that transition; and
(c) the provision of assistance to workers financially disadvantaged by the prohibition on logging in high conservation value native forests or the phase out of the export of woodchips.
(41) Page 306 (after line 23), at the end of Part 15, add:

para.inline: 390A Planning for protection and management of native vegetation

speech.para: (1) The Minister must make and implement a written plan for protecting and managing native vegetation in Australia within one year after the commencement of this Act.
(2) The objectives for protecting and managing native vegetation in the plan must include:
(a) to end large-scale clearing of native vegetation in Australia; and
(b) to end the clearing or conversion of native forests for plantations; and
(c) to protect and conserve native vegetation so as, in particular:
(i) to protect the habitat of flora and fauna; and
(ii) to help to protect ecological processes; and
(iii) to help to maintain the genetic diversity of flora and fauna and their potential for evolutionary development in the wild; and
(iv) to lessen contributions to and adverse impacts of the greenhouse effect; and
(v) to protect soil against erosion, salinisation and other forms of degradation; and
(vi) to minimise adverse effects of groundwater recharge; and
(vii) to protect wetlands, waterways and water resources; and
(viii) to preserve and enhance landscape quality; and
(d) by protecting native vegetation, to promote the sustainable use of land.
(3) The Commonwealth may co-operate with a State, self-governing Territory or local government in preparing and implementing the plan.

para.inline: 390B Implementing the plan to protect and conserve native vegetation

speech.para: (1) A Commonwealth agency must be administered so as to have regard to the plan for conserving and managing native vegetation in Australia.

(2) The Commonwealth or a Commonwealth agency must not make available to a local government, State or self-governing Territory any funds of the following kinds unless that local government, State or self-governing Territory has adopted a law or planning scheme which prohibits or regulates the clearing of native vegetation, and is able to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Minister that the regulations are effective in preventing clearing which contravenes the objectives for conserving and managing native vegetation:
(a) Natural Heritage Trust funds;
(b) funds for tree-planting;
(c) funds for land protection and landcare;
(d) funds for improving water quality.

(3) The Commonwealth or a Commonwealth agency must not make available any funds of the following kinds to a person unless the land where the funds are to be used is subject to a law or planning scheme which prohibits or regulates the clearing of native vegetation and the person is able to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Minister that native vegetation on the land will be protected in accordance with the objectives for conserving and managing native vegetation:
(a) Natural Heritage Trust funds;
(b) funds for tree-planting;
(c) funds for land protection and landcare;
(d) funds for improving water quality.
Note: See section 24D for the meaning of clearing and native vegetation .

talk.start.para: âPursuant to contingent notice and on behalf of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the moving in the committee of the whole of an amendment which is the same in substance as an amendment already negatived by the committee or which is inconsistent with an amendment already agreed to by the committee.

Madam President, I move this procedural motion to avoid any problems which might otherwise result from the application of standing order 118(2). That standing order, as you would know, provides that no new clause or amendment shall be proposed which is substantially the same as one already negatived by the committee or which is inconsistent with one that has been agreed to by the committee unless a recommittal of the bill has intervened. Suspension of this provision will facilitate consideration of amendments which are the same as or substantially similar to amendments previously moved and dealt with by both the government and non-government senators.

talk.start.para: âI rise to oppose the motion just moved by the parliamentary secretary. I think it is an extraordinary motion to propose to the chamber. It is extraordinary on many counts. One of the most outstanding counts is that this is a procedural motion to deal with the repudiation of decisions made by this chamber before now in this debate. This is the debate on the government's tax package, the so-called headline GST package. We do not even have before us at this stage a running sheet for this debate; we have no running sheet whatsoever. The running sheet that we have is the running sheet that was left over when we terminated the debate after the famous speech by Senator Harradine in which he said he could not bring himself to support the government's legislation. That is the running sheet before us.

speech.para: One reads in the press that a deal has been done between the Australian Democrats and the government to alter the tax package considerably. That deal substantially changes the nature of the proposition that we had before us. We did not see the amendments that give legislative voice to that deal until late last night. We saw one of them then and some have dribbled out during the day. We did not receive an explanatory memorandum until quite late in the day. There are 119 of these amendmentsâso it is not an insubstantial numberâand we have no proposal as to how they should be dealt with in this chamber. I would have thought that that was a matter of considerable importance in terms of parliamentary procedure.

Before we move to motions about how we will conduct a parliamentary debate on the Democrat-government GST deal, we are, I am sure, reasonably entitled to have some explanation by either the government or, if they are too afraid of making it, the Australian Democrats as to what the proposition is. We remember the Prime Minister saying, when asked whether he would remove food from the GSTâand these were his wordsâ`No, no, no, no, no.' Apparently, he has agreed to do so, but what explanation has been afforded to this legislative chamber, the Australian Senate, as to what the package is now? There has been no explanation. All we have had is the parliamentary secretary moving a motion about procedure so he can knock off things that this chamber has decided to do previously in this debate. There has been no explanation at all as to the substance of the matter. This is a contemptuous attitude towards the powers of the Senate.

I would be disappointed if the Democrats supported this procedure without there being any explanation to the chamber. If there is one thing the Democrats are famous for it is for insisting, in speech after speech, year in, year out, in every parliamentary sitting that I have sat through for the last 16 years, that this chamber should be afforded the opportunity of greater and proper scrutiny. In fact, Meg Lees's second reading speech to this chamber chided the government for not allowing proper parliamentary scrutiny in the time allotted to this debate in the chamber.

Are the Democrats going to be compliant in ramming a procedural motion down our throat in the absence of any explanation at all? Are they going to repudiate years of so-called Democrat principle that this chamber is entitled to scrutiny and explanation? What sort of complacency do we expect from a government that has done this deal and, in effect, says to us in this chamber, `Read about it in the paper. We just want to move on. And, by the way, we haven't got a running sheet and, by the way, we don't know whether all of the amendments are before us yet and, by the way, we're not going to tell you a damn thing about it'?

talk.start.para: âCalm down.

âNo, you calm down, parliamentary secretary. You are the perpetrator of this. Is that your idea of parliamentary democracy? This motion should be withdrawn by the government. An explanation should be given and we should proceed on this in an orderly fashion. If this is going to be the government's attitude to this debate, it will be a very rancorous debate, because this is an abuse of power. This is a conscription of the Democrats to the will of the executive and a standing over of the rights of this chamber. The motion should be defeated.

âI will not delay the chamber for very long. I cannot anyway: I only get five minutes. Senator Cook is right. I think the Manager of Government Business in the Senate has assumed that everyone knows the reasons for his moving the motion. I think he should have at least outlined them. Apart from an explanation, we probably should have had an apology. What this motion does, in effect, is say, `I'm sorry we have wasted the parliament's time by going through the committee stage for 40 hours or so.' Senator Campbell indicated today, in an earlier burst of rhetoric, that we have spent 40 hours or so on the committee stage of the bill. The effect of this motion is to scrap it all.

speech.para: Technically, this motion is probably required because, in order to consummate the deal between the government and the Democrats, the government virtually have to move the same amendments as the Democrats moved and absorb them as their own, and standing orders do not allow that to occur. Senator Campbell could have explained that to us. He could have said, `I'm sorry for wasting the committee's time for 44Â½ hours. We misjudged our negotiating stance. We put all our eggs in Senator Harradine's basket. The moment that fell through, we had to run and cut a deal with the Democrats and agree to amendments that we had already crushed, defeated, in this chamber.' That is, I believe, the effect of all this.

Senator Cook is right: the manager should have given us a more adequate explanation. What we will see happening over the next four days is the government supporting concepts and amendments that it had previously indicated it would oppose in this chamber. Of course, that is a humiliating backflip for the government. Nevertheless, it is a course it has chosen. I am not sure whether we were given notice of this procedural motion. Maybe when he sums up the debate the manager will indicate whether he notified us of this motion in advance.

talk.start.para: âWe gave notice of it. It is a contingent notice.

âIt is a contingent notice of motion. I had heard that a contingent notice of motion had been put in, Senator Campbell. I admit at this stage that I had not read it. In summary, it is not just an explanation that we require. Senator Campbell should fess up and admit that this is necessary because of the dramatic change of course with the negotiations with the Democrats. We might then be able to proceed to a vote on it. I am not sure the opposition would seek to divide on this matter. I will seek the guidance of others. Nevertheless, a better and more adequate explanation of this matter may have facilitated the time of the chamber.

âI think the points have been made by the opposition in so far as the inadequacies of the explanation given for the proposal that has been put forward by way of a contingent notice of motion. I think we need to appreciate that there may well be a majority in the chamber for this proposition because I would not have expected Senator Campbell to have put it forward, with such obvious slight regard for explanation, if he did not think there were sufficient numbers to support it. Given the events of today and that there has obviously been support given by a majority of senators to the government in proceeding these questions, I do think it is important to get some questions drawn to the attention of the Senate. It was only recently that Senator Lees lectured the Senate on their approach in their relationship with this government.

speech.para: I recall, for instance, that just last year she said that she thought the government's:
. . . contempt for parliament does not stop with the bullying of the Speaker by Messrs Howard and Mr Reith. It runs far deeper than that.
She then indicated that, on the question of the government's approach to parliamentary processes:
The very same bullying tactics adopted by the Prime Minister against his own Speaker are regularly employed to downgrade the status and powers of the Senate.

She went on to indicate a number of examples and particularly indicated her concern about attempts to pre-empt the decisions of the Senate in a number of ways. I think that what has occurred in recent times on this issue highlights the action now being taken up. There are none so zealous as those who have been converted to a position and we will no doubt be able to demonstrate that over the coming four days. I am reminded that it was Senator Lees who said that:

It is no secret that this thuggish governmentâand I stress the word thuggish because that is what it isâhas set it sights on the independence of the Senate, the body described the former Auditor- General John Taylor as the last effective brake on executive government.
She then went on to say that:

This government has shown far greater contempt for this parliament than any government in memory. Democracy and the people of Australia are the losers if this government with its born-to-rule mentality succeeds in avoiding the checks and balances provided by the parliament. Australia will not be served by a parliament that cannot hold the government to account, that does not provide a balanced and fair forum for debate on day-to-day issues, that does not provide a pressure valve for the public to actually have a say to express its views on government proposals that are either plainly wrong or unpopular.

I would have thought those sentiments apply quite directly to the proposition before us today and of course apply in general to the questions that are being raised about the unanswered and unexplained nature of the arrangements entered into between this government and the Australian Democrats on the GST. I think and I would hope that Senator Campbell might have learnt something from the experience of today and would seek to explain to this chamber, in a great deal more depth and clarity, what the government is seeking to achieve and the reasons for it. On the basis of the actions that we have seen, it is quite apparent that this government is most anxious to avoid scrutiny, as are the Democrats.

They are anxious to avoid being held accountable for the arrangements that they have made, which will have far-reaching consequences for many hundreds of thousands of Australians in areas that in past the Democrats were said have represented. I speak specifically of those people with whom I am in close contact, particularly those concerned with educational issues. I say to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate that it would be appropriate to explain what he is intending to do on these measures and it would be appropriate for the Democrats to come clean on the nature of the arrangements that they have made to impose upon this country a most unpopular and unwarranted GST.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI thought that this was a fairly simple proposition. I gave what I thought was a quite clear explanation on it. In plain English, it means that under standing orders 118(2), if the Senate has made a decision about an amendment, you cannot revisit that amendment in the same debate. I think that rule applies generally to most meetings and meeting procedures throughout the world, not only in the Senate. We are seeking to suspend that. I gave notice of it some time ago so that the whole world, including all senators, would know about it. In fact, if those honourable senators who are interested turn to page 28 of today's Notice Paper , they will see that the proposition that we are dealing with is clearly set out on that page.

speech.para: I make this point because I have been asked to go into more detail. I have said in plain English that this effectively means that you can re-put an amendment that has been voted on that is the same or substantially the same and have it voted on again. I am reliably told that the one matter this specifically and definitely applies toâand there are some amendments that are similar and so it may apply to thoseâis an amendment in relation to acupuncture. The whole debate we are having now is potentially related to just one amendment in relation to acupuncture. I suspect those people who find relief from stress in acupuncture could do with a bit after a day like today in the Senate.

I do not know whether that answer will satisfy the opposition or any other senators, but that explains why we are doing it. Quite clearly, we need to revisit the acupuncture amendment and of course some others, and this gives the Senate the power to do that. I do not think that giving a contingent notice, having it published in the Notice Paper to be brought on when the bill comes back on, is any sort of hijacking; it is certainly not meant to be. The reason you give notice of things and bring them on at the appropriate time is so that no ambushes can take place, and I certainly did not seek to do that at all.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI seek to put a question to the parliamentary secretary which might expedite this matter. I would like to also direct it to Senator Murray, representing the Australian Democrats. The question is: does the government or the Australian Democrats, or do both of them conjointly, propose to make an explanation to the Senate as to what they have now done and how they intend to proceed in terms of the changes they have made? I ask the question because these are substantive changes. This is not anything like the same bill we were considering before. In the normal course there would be a second reading speech to at least make an explanation about the global changes that are being made. We would have a chance, at least, to respond to that and have a process that we are well attuned to in order to conduct the proper processes of scrutiny. But just to assume that we resume as if nothing has happened and that we understand everything that occurs off-stage, out of this chamber, through the media is, I think, somewhat contemptuous. I just ask the question: is it intended that an appropriate explanation will be made to the Senate as to why these measures, in which we clothe the Senate with the power to expunge decisions that it has already made, are being sought? What are the government and the Democrats attempting to do?

âby leaveâThere are three points I would make. Firstly, this motion before the chair at the moment does not seek to expunge decisions; it just gives the Senate the power to make a decision. It basically suspends 118(2), which would otherwise not allow us to make a new decision. Secondly, I have in my right hand at least one, if not more, explanatory memoranda, which I will table as soon as we get into committee. I am not allowed to do it before then. There is a detailed explanatory memorandum going around. I think the running sheet has already been distributed. I am not sure if it has got across to that side of the chamber.
âIt looks like the old running sheet, not a new running sheet.
âCan we get a copy of that?

âI will table that. I now formally table the regulation impact statement and supplementary explanatory memorandaâsix of them, I thinkârelating to the government amendments and requests for amendments to be moved to certain bills contained in this package. The regulation impact statement and supplementary explanatory memoranda were, indeed, circulated in the chamber on 22 and 23 June. I am also assured by the Assistant Treasurer, who will have carriage of the billsâI am only carrying these procedural mattersâand whom I trust implicitly and have enormous respect for, that he will give, in his normal style, an eloquent explanation which I am fairly certain will satisfy you. I think Senator Cook is looking for an explanation of what is occurring. I am assured by the Assistant Treasurer that, when we actually do get into the committee stage, he would like to open the batting, kick offâor any other analogyâwith a thorough explanation of what Senator Cook has been looking for. I foreshadow that if Senator Cook is not happy with that explanation, he would cross-examine.

âby leaveâI wish to ask a further question. The Manager of Government Business in the Senate has indicated, in response to an earlier question from Senator Cook, that the issue that you were concerned aboutârecommittalâwas in relation to acupuncture and other matters.
âIt is not recommittal.

âThe issues you said would be affected by this proposition went to the question of acupuncture and other matters. Could I ask what those other matters are so that we can have a list of the issues that actually would be affected by this proposition?

âby leaveâI was quite precise about it. We are certain that 118(2) needs to be suspended to deal with acupuncture because the amendment that is in the new group of amendments tabled last night is identical, I understand, to the amendment moved during the committee stage previously. There are similar amendments in relation to food. Whether or not 118(2) needs to be suspended to deal with the food amendments is a matter of fine judgment, but it is better to suspend 118(2). You could argue for years to figure out whether or not you need to suspend it.

speech.para: Specifically to Senator Carr, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, acupuncture is the matter that we are definitely dealing with and, of course, other amendments dealing with food, where there were similar amendments dealt with in the committee stage. The point can also be madeâand I do not make it frivolouslyâthat, I understand, having read the papers, there may be the Australian Labor Party's proposed tactic to re-put some of the Democrat amendments or to put some of the Democrat amendmentsâ

talk.start.para: âThis is to help us!
âWe never thought of that.

âNo, it is to help the whole Senate. We understand that you would not be able to do that unless we did this. We are not trying to tell you to support this for your own good. We think it would aid the consideration of this legislation in the interests of all senators and, most importantly, in the interests of all of our fellow citizens.

âby leaveâI wish to clarify my earlier question. My question was to the coalition, which the parliamentary secretary has been kind enough to answer. But it was also to the Australian Democrats, and I wonder if they would be kind enough to answer?

âI am sorry, Senator Cook. I was engaged in conversation with one of your colleagues and I missed much of what you said, but I think you were asking me about the proposition that was being put to you. Is that correct?
âNo, I was asking you whether you are going to make some explanation about the changes that are proposed.

âI think our view of that would beâand I think Senator Campbell has given you the signalâthat much of what is being proposed is in line with what has been previously proposed. The Senate is aware and the public at large who voted for the Democrats are aware that the Democrats always had a position that if we could change the bills towards our view of them, then we would support them. For instance, let us start with income tax cuts. We believed in income tax cuts but not in the manner that they were outlined by government. So you are substantially dealing with the same issue; it is just in a different shape. With respect to the goods and services tax, we believed in a goods and services tax but not in the shape laid out by government. What you have is the same policy result but with a different outcome in terms of the items which are taxable and not taxable.

speech.para: If you refer to the social area, we agreed that it was necessary to improve pensions, allowances, social security benefits and so on, but that the improvements were insufficient. Those have been increased, so you are dealing with the same issue but a different set of numbers. On Commonwealth-state financial relations, we believed that those did need to be reformed in the manner that the government intended, but the consequence is that some items have been left in and out. None of these matters that I am outlining to you, Senator Cook, are insubstantialâand I think that is your point. They are substantial and they matter. But they fall within the intent that the government had originally put to the people. I think the clue for youâand I looked up 118(2)âis in the nature of the parliamentary secretary'sâ

talk.start.para: âOrder, Senator Murray. The time for the debate has elapsed.
âMay I take another minute by leave?

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI was going to say that 118(2) says:

speech.para: No new clause or amendment shall be proposed which is substantially the same as one already negatived by the committee . . .

In other words, we agree that most of what is being done with respect to a number of the amendments is substantially the same as what we dealt with before. That is why we believe it is a continuation of the debate.

talk.start.para: âThe question is that the motion moved by the parliament secretary, Senator Campbell, be agreed to.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
