subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 14 May.

talk.start.para: âThe committee is considering government amendments Nos 25 to 27 on sheet FA210 relating to the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Bill 1998 and Democrat amendment No. 1 to amendment No. 27. The question is that the Democrat amendment be agreed to.

âFollowing the debate we have just had, Senator Cook wanted the government to give an overview of where it intends to proceed from here on out. I thought that, prior to getting into the detail of the amendments and concluding the amendment which is now before the chair, I would make a short statement which provided an overview of what is now intended.

speech.para: Following yesterday's final agreement between the government and the Australian Democrats, the government will now move forward with the legislation to reform the Australian tax system. I welcome the involvement of the Democrats in the tax reform, which we believe and which they believe is in Australia's national interest. In contrast, of course, Labor does have a policy vacuum on tax reform. I think that has been well revealed during the debate so far.

I can inform the Senate that the government will be proceeding with all key elements of its tax reform package. A 10 per cent GST will be introduced from 1 July 2000, with basic food to be GST free. Personal income tax cuts targeted at low and middle income earners will be maintained. This means that the government will keep its commitment to ensure that over 80 per cent of taxpayers face a marginal tax rate of only 30 per cent. There will be some paring back of the proposed tax cuts for taxpayers earning over $50,000 per annum, but significant benefits are retained. In addition to the tax cuts, generous compensation for the introduction of the GST through improved family assistance and the social security benefits will be enhanced.

The government has agreed to some changes in the GST and the diesel excise reforms. These have been well publicised over recent days. Reforms to diesel will proceed and legislation was introduced yesterday in the other place to enhance the existing diesel fuel rebate scheme and to establish a new diesel and alternative fuel grants scheme for on-road fuels. As a result of the benefits being delivered through a grants scheme, diesel credits will be taken out of the GST system.

The government has circulated amendments arising out of discussions with the Democrats, clarifying how the GST will apply to food, health, education and the financial services sector. I will not, obviously, in the interests of time go through all of the amendments, as we will have an opportunity to debate them. However, I will point out the following.

As a result of food being GST free, most food items will fall in price. The legislation provides that food for human consumption will be GST free, except for (1) savoury snacks, confectionery, ice-cream, biscuits and certain beverages currently subject to wholesale sales tax; (2) bakery products other than bread; and (3) prepared food, including take-away foods and food supplied by restaurants.

The health amendments include the following. Products on schedule 2 and the standard for the uniform scheduling of drugs and poisons will be GST free, including smaller packs of pain relievers identical to schedule 2 products. Under this amendment, over-the-counter pain relievers will be GST free. The range of health professionals who may provide GST-free health services will be expanded to include appropriately qualified naturopaths, acupuncturists and herbalists. Certain public health goods will also be GST free, by way of ministerial determinationâsubject to the approval of the ministerial council. Initially, the government will seek the inclusion of sunscreens, folate supplements, condoms and personal lubricants as GST-free public health goods.

The education amendments include the following. Adult and community education courses likely to develop employment related skills will be GST free. First-aid or life-saving courses offered by non-profit bodies will be GST free. To address concerns raised concerning compliance costs of school based organisations, school tuckshops will be given an option to be input taxed.

With respect to financial services, the government has agreed to allow partial input tax credits to purchasers of a specified list of services used by enterprises making financial supplies. This measure will particularly benefit smaller organisations in the financial sector, such as credit unions, which operate with a large range of outsourced activities.

Other amendments put in place are increased compensation measures, enhanced family assistance arrangements and changes to the income tax scales. Madam President, that gives a brief summary of the changes which the government proposes, and we believe thatâ

talk.start.para: âOn a point of order, Minister, I am not Madam President.

âOh sorry! I must wear my glasses, Senator. Thank you for drawing your gender to my attention. Chair, can I say that the government welcome the discussions that we had with the Democrats. We believe that they have been conducted in an extremely fair fashion. Obviously in certain areas the government and the Democrats have differed, but we believe now that the package which has emerged from these discussions and resulted from the amendments will deliver real tax reform to the Australian community. We urge the Senate to ensure the speedy passage of the legislation and the bills which are before it.

âI have to say that the opposition participates in this debate under protest. We are being guillotined and required to complete the debate within the hour set by this chamber in a collusion between the Australian Democrats and the coalition. It is the government's bill but a bill which has been substantially altered to suit Democrat convenience, because of the principled position of Senator Harradine.

speech.para: We know that the government sought to persuade Senator Harradine to vote for the original package. It was only after Senator Harradine made what by now must be a famous speechâthe `I cannot' speechâthat the government knew for certain that it did not have the numbers to allow its legislation to pass in this chamber. As a consequence of that, as the opportunists that they have now been revealed to be, the Australian Democrats proceeded to `negotiate with' as they call itâbut by any other standards it would be `sell out to'âthe government on a range of tax measures that we now have fetched up on our shore for debate this evening.

We participate under protest because there is a straitjacket on this debate. We participate under protest because a guillotine has been introduced. We participate under protest because the amendments that give voice to the changes that have been agreed between the Australian Democrats and the government have not been given to us with sufficient notice. I note in passing that the committee stage of this debate was delayed for a day or two so that the Democrats could get ready, even though they had had significant notice, as we had had, of the changes that the government had proposedâsome 218 changes, at that stage.

No such courtesy is extended to us on this occasion. The fact that the Democrats have had prior notice of the amendments and that they and the government circularised the press gallery last night before releasing those amendments to the opposition for scrutiny does indicate not only a degree of concern about news managementâso that proper scrutiny can be avoided and the government's and Democrats' preferred spin can be imparted on these amendmentsâbut also a contempt for this chamber and the processes of this chamber, in that the amendments were given to the press before they were given to honourable senators. They were held back until late in the pieceâand then not all of themâand now there are 119 of them. And now the explanatory memorandum dribbles out late at this stage, so that when this debate kicks off there is not even the dignity of this chamber having a running sheet before it. The running sheet is distributedâ

talk.start.para: âI rise on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. I am sure that Senator Cook is not intentionally misleading the parliament but I should advise you that I only received a copy of the food amendment, which is the one that you were referring to, at 20 past 10 last night and so I certainly did not receive it in advance nor circulate it in advance.
âThat is not a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman, and I hope you will rule it out of order.
âThere is no point of order. It is a point of information.

âLet me then rephrase that to actually get it accurate. What the media in this place was telling us and everyone elseâand they reported it, in fact, this morningâwas that the Democrat party room pored over the amendments and ticked them off finally. Maybe then the formal amendments were generated, and so you are technically right, Senator. But I have to say that you will excuse me if there is a fair degree of cynicism that you did not know what the amendments would contain until 10.20 last night. We certainly did not. I accept your acknowledgment now that you did. And that was indeed my point.

speech.para: The point is: for proper debate and scrutiny in this chamber, polite and reasonable notice should be extended. That is a principle the Democrats have insisted on and it is a principle that we have tried to acknowledge and accommodate, but it is not extended to us on this occasion and that is why, under protest, we participate in the early bringing on of these bills in this manner. I think it is ludicrous to expect that we are in a position to respond properly and appropriately in all of the circumstances, given the shortage of notice, the inadequate supply of information and the conspiracy that has been entered into to put the favourable spin by the government on the legislation.

I am not alone in saying those things. This morning at the Park Hyatt in Melbourne, at a small business breakfast, the Premier of Victoria, Jeffrey Kennett, went on to say how sad it is that this legislation is coming forward and how sad it is that it has changed all the things he believed the coalitionâand he is a leader of a state branch of the principal partyâstood for. He made a very powerful speech which I recommend the Democrats read, because this is the beginning of the Howard alibi.

If these changes are madeâand I suspect they will be, as I apprehend the numbers in the chamber to do soâand if the compliance cost difficulties start to bite, as they will, and if the unintended consequences that always emerge in rushed legislation begin to surface, this government will disown the Australian Democrats at a speed of a million miles an hour. They will hang the albatross of `It is the Democrats' legislation, not ours' around their neck. Jeffrey Kennett started the process this morning by saying, `Blame the Democrats for all of these changes. Blame the Democrats for the increase in compliance costs. Blame the Democrats for the confusion and for not having a wide enough tax base. Blame the Democrats for the problems that we in the states will experience if this legislation goes through.' That only echoes what Mr Howard has said.

But I make that point in passing because the more devastating criticism has been made by Professor Peter Dixon from the Monash Centre of Economic Studies. He put out a paper yesterday in which he made the obvious point: what is the information base upon which this ill-gotten conglomeration of changes is being made? Do we know the economic impact of this new series of changes? Do we know whether it has been modelled? Is that information available? Are we being asked to legislate blindfolded as to the impacts? The Democrats, and I think rightly, take some pride in causing in this chamber a majority viewpoint about an inquiry into the GST. That was a valuable inquiry, and that has been acknowledged by all parties, except by a reluctant government burdened by the penetration of some real insight into the clouded myopia of propaganda that they had spread about their ANTS package. Everyone else welcomed it.

But what do we know about the economic implications of this in the public domain? We have not been told anything. No modelling has been set out. No macro-economic parameters have been published. What is the impact on employment? What is the impact on growth? What is the impact on our trade balance? What is the impact on people on low and middle incomes? Nothing. Silence. Do the Democrats step forward to enlighten us? No, they do not. The big advocates of proper scrutiny are silent on this point, absent without leave from the field.

I make those observations because Professor Dixon goes on to find, on reasonable research available to him and on papers and studies published between now and when the last study was done, that the impact of this set of changes will be adverse to the national economy, unemployment will increase and there will be slower growth.

talk.start.para: âWhat absolute rubbish!
âWhy don't you shut up! You'll get your chance in a moment.
âOrder! Senator Cook, withdraw.
âI withdraw. Mr Chairman, would you bring the minister to order and do your duty in the chair as well. Will you do that, Mr Chairman? If we're going to have a debate on this, let us do it properly.
âOrder, it being 7.20 p.m., I will report progress to the Senate.
âYes. Do your job, Grant. Don't bloody well call me to order!
âOrder! Withdraw that.
âWithdraw what?
âYour comments, your reflection on the chair.
âI withdraw.

interjection.para: Progress reported.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian National Audit Office: Principles of Corporate Governance

talk.start.para: âOn 31 May I received a pack of information from the Australian National Audit Office. The covering letter told me that the pack contained a discussion paper on the principles of corporate governance as they apply to Commonwealth authorities and Commonwealth companies, and it makes very interesting reading. It states that the definitions of corporate governance are many and varied, but there are some key elements and they are: the transparency of corporate structures and operations; the implementation of effective risk management and internal control systems; and the accountability of the board to stakeholders through clear and timely disclosure. And, of course, Commonwealth authorities and companies are accountable to parliament.

speech.para: The ANAO paper also states that `the board can only fulfil its responsibilities if it meets regularly and collectively with clear agendas and records decisions and outcomes'. I might add these are basic rules that one would expect from the local sporting club, let alone a Commonwealth authority or company. One would certainly expect these processes to apply to the board of any statutory authority. The discussion paper specifically goes to the operation of boards. It also states that `the effectiveness of board meetings is dependent on carefully planned agendas and providing board papers and materials to directors sufficiently prior to board meetings' and that `it is important that minutes accurately record outcomes from meetings'. Again, this sounds basic, but it is also very important.
In relation to a corporate code of conducts for boards, the ANAO paper states:
The board and senior management are responsible for promoting high ethics and integrity standards.
It also says:
The language, attitudes and actions of directors and senior management affect the integrity, ethics, values and other aspects of corporate culture.

The reason for my interest in this paper and my heightened interest in corporate governance relates to recent estimates hearings of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committeeâspecifically, the evidence given to that committee by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.

There are two issues flowing from those hearings that I wish to address. They are: the circumstances surrounding the appointment of a member of that board to a senior management position within that organisation; and also the manner in which the Civil Aviation Safety Authority board conducts its business. When both of these matters are considered against the standards outlined by the Auditor-General, Mr Barrett, I believe there is significant reason for concern. In fact, the evidence given during those hearings in relation to both these matters may require further investigation by the Senate and certainly requires urgent action by the minister, Mr Anderson.

Over the past couple of years the structure of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority has gone through a number of changes. The explanation for this probably lies in the instability in both the board and senior management over that period. The current management structure was settled around July last year. It consists of three main units: safety compliance, safety standards, and safety promotion. In addition, there is a corporate services area. These new management arrangements were debated by the board over a period of time. All board members were involved. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority Director, Mr Toller, told the committee on 6 May that no directors absented themselves from this process.

According to the CASA annual report for 1997-98, the board members at that time were Mr Dick Smith, Dr Paul Scully-Power, Mr Bruce Byron, Mr Michael Ryan, Mr Tony Pyne, Mr John Pyke and Mr Laurie Foley. Mr Foley was appointed to the CASA board on 8 May 1997, the same day as Mr Dick Smith was appointed. In fact, Mr Foley was appointed on the basis of Mr Smith's recommenda tion to the then Minister for Transport, Mr Sharp. The board not only was actively involved in the development of this new structure but it also approved a process for recruiting senior staff to fill the newly created positions.

A key player in this process was Mr Wes Willoughby. Mr Willoughby was a regional manager in the Civil Aviation Authority, and he took a redundancy package some time around 1991. Obviously, he worked for that authority until 1991. He came back to this organisation as a consultant, I understand on the recommendation of Mr Dick Smith, on 7 August 1997. His initial work, at a rate of $1,000 a day, was with an American, Mr Brodrick. His contract was then extended by Mr Smith.

In addition to the base rate of $1,000 a day, Mr Willoughby was paid $200 an hour plus expenses to advise Mr Smith. I understand that those expenses included accommodation, travel, weekend fares from Canberra to Melbourne and Melbourne to Canberra for himself and his wife, as well as access to a car. Mr Willoughby, who I understand to be a competent officer, did well from those arrangements. In fact, for the month of July that year he was paid $57,684. I learnt that from an answer to a question from Senator Mackay to Mr Toller, the Chief Executive Officer of CASA, in estimates on 6 May this year. According to Mr Toller, the current structure was formally approved by the CASA board some time prior to May last year. He thought it was around February.

A company trading as Spencer Stuart was engaged to assist with the recruitment process. According to Mr Toller, this company had been engaged by CASA before. Spencer Stuart had a close relationship with Mr Willoughby. On 7 April Mr Willoughby sought board approval to engage a recruitment firm to fill the new executive position. The matter was settled by the board in a closed session on 15 April. There was no tender process but a call for expressions of interest on that same day.

A decision was taken to engage Spencer Stuart on 24 April, just nine days later. I understand that, over a period of time, Mr Foley also had a number of dealings with Spencer Stuart, along with a fellow board member, Mr Bryce Byron. So there appears to have been a close relationship between this company, Mr Willoughby and Mr Foley before it was given the contract to provide candidates for key positions under the new structure. The contract with Spencer Stuart was signed on 5 May, but that company commenced work on the consultancy well before that. Mr Toller told estimates that this was because the company was given verbal advice that it had the job some time between 24 and 28 April.

Mr Foley had advised Spencer Stuart that he was available for work early in 1998. This occurred while he and his fellow board members were developing a new CASA structure and, along with it, a number of new senior positions. Mr Foley participated in the selection process that led to the appointment of that company. He then approved, along with the other members of the CASA board, the engagement of Spencer Stuart, but it appears Mr Foley had not advised the board of that obvious conflict of interest. He continued to be an active participant in the work of the board even though he had a direct and significant personal interest in the outcomes of a number of matters that the board had before it.

Mr Foley met with Spencer Stuart on 5 May to discuss his candidacy for one of the positions that that company was seeking to fillâthat is, he met with the headhunter he had helped to appoint to discuss his interest in one of the positions he had helped to create. Again, he failed to advise his fellow board members of his actions. Two days later Mr Foley told Mr Wheatley from Spencer Stuart that he was a candidate for one of those positions, but again he did not advise the board of his decision.

At a board meeting on 15 May, the process to be followed in interviewing candidates for these jobs and the role of the board in that process was discussed. The process was to involve the establishment of a number of panels with a member of the board sitting on each panel. Mr Foley told the board he was not able to participate in that process, but he did not advise the board members why he was unavailable. I asked Mr Toller, who was present at the 15 May meeting of the board, whether or not Mr Foley told his fellow board members why he would not sit on any selection panels. Mr Toller said Mr Foley gave no reason at that time. There is a lot more to this story and, given that my time is about to elapse, I advise the Senate that I intend to resume this story at the next available opportunity.

talk.start.para: âFew would argue that Australia's long-term social, cultural and economic development are all inextricably linked to the size and make-up of the nation's population. This is a topic which I think deserves greater attention than it gets. As an example, critical mass in the national population is an important although often underresearched issue in identifying a pool of people capable of developing technological skills. Without a critical mass, a talent pool is something that other nations will claim at Australia's expense. The United States has recognised this and has aggressive recruitment programs to encourage young and talented people from other countries to take up opportunities in the United States and even to settle there permanently to build the country's knowledge base. I think it rings alarm bells for us.

speech.para: The forces that change our population are natural increase and migration. A fertility rate of 2.2 children per female would be required for the population to replace itself. The current Australian fertility rate is 1.85 children per female. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has based its population projections on assumed fertility rates, ranging from 1.6 to 1.75 births per woman by 2005-06 and then remaining constant. According to the ABS projections, the rate of population growth in 2051 would be between 0.0 per cent and 0.3 per cent, compared with around 1.2 per cent in 1997. A fertility rate of between 1.65 and 1.8 and net migration of between 60,000 and 100,000 per year would result in a stationary population of between 24 million and 26 million by around 2037.

There have been many expert and, indeed, other opinions, and they are divided on what might be an ideal population target. The reality is that Australia has a below replacement fertility rate and has had for more than 20 years, and there are no signs that this trend will change. The infusion of youth into our population structure has therefore been declining for some time, and I think this is a serious issue for our future economy. The capacity for natural increase to sustain population increase is really collapsing. Moreover, as we have heard so often, our population is ageing. Under current trends, the population aged 65 and over will increase by 100,000 a year in the decades to 2031, and the population aged 65 and over will rise from 12 per cent in 1997 to 22 per cent by the year 2031.

The prospects through to the middle of the next century are for a major escalation in aged dependency for Australia. That is hardly news, but Australia, by default, is drifting towards a position of negligible population growth. By doing that, we risk closing the doors to advances such as those enjoyed in earlier times of spectacular growth in this country.

Any discussion on population inevitably raises the matter of immigration, a topic on which opinions legitimately differ. Some environmental groups, for example, have taken the view that Australia should adopt a policy of zero net overseas migration. Business and industry bodies, on the other hand, have argued the case very strongly for a very substantial increase in the immigration intake in order to increase growth and reduce the impact of the ageing population. Some have talked about population targets of 50 million in 50 years time. I am not arguing for that target, but I think it would be unrealistic not to acknowledge that many Australians have deeply held concerns on a number of migration issues, and we need to address them. Equally, it is difficult, in my view, to find any sustainable arguments against a well-researched and properly thought out population policy that will meet our needs, aspirations and national goals for the next couple of decades. This will mean maintaining the community's confidence in our migration program.

I think it is worth looking back a little bit. It is undeniable that the modern history of Australian society has been built on successive waves of immigration, first from England, then from Europe and more recently from Asia. Each wave has brought with it new and profound social, political and cultural influences. The tide of postwar immigration has transformed Australia into a nation with an open and vibrant economy, a strong services sector and greatly improved health and education facilities. But where do we stand now on the immigration front? There has been a lot of water under the bridge, but immigration rates have been falling since the 1980s. Before that, immigration typically contributed more than one per cent to Australia's population each yearânow it is less than half that. This trend is taking place at the same time as birth rates of the non-immigrant population are declining.

The rather stark reality of our declining population base is ample reason for us to rethink our attitude to migration as being both positive and necessary to maximise Australia's potential. The critical questions are what sort of migration will not only swell our numbers but also make a positive contribution to Australia's productive base, and what policies will encourage migrant settlement outside crowded metropolitan areas where environmental pressures already threaten the fabric of our major cities.

If we are to encourage increased migration to Australiaâand I am certainly in that camp of persons who think we shouldâwe need to give very careful thought to policies that will assist regional development by encouraging a much more balanced distribution of the migrant intake. Until recentlyâand, indeed, to a large extent, this still obtainsâthe settlement patterns of migrants, including skilled and business migrants, has been heavily skewed towards settlement in and around Australia's largest metropolitan centres. The patterns tend to exacerbate Australia's population concentration, particularly in Sydney, which receives about 40 per cent of the migrant intake each year.

The contrast with other cities is very interesting. South Australia, which has some 8.3 per cent of Australia's population, attracts between four and five per cent of Australia's new settlers. Tasmania has some 2.7 per cent of Australia's population but attracts around one per cent of its immigrants. The Northern Territory attracts one per cent. Western Australia, with 9.4 per cent of the population, attracts about 12 per cent, but of course with an overwhelming majority settling in Perth. A similar situation obtains in Queensland, where the great majority settle in the south-east corner of the state.

This raises some very interesting issues for us to think about in relation to the migration program. The government's regional migration initiatives aim to assist regional development by encouraging a more balanced dispersal of Australia's migrant intake. We have introduced a number of initiatives to facilitate this. They cover migration to not only rural and regional areas but also other major urban centres, including Cairns, Townsville, Canberra, Adelaide and Hobart.

Research into patterns of population distribution and the reasons why migrants decide to settle in certain areas of Australia have shown findings which are really not surprising. They show that there are two factors which are of primary importance in making that decision. Of course, the location of family, where applicable, is very important, and the other factor is the availability of employment. The initiatives already in place are designed to be consistent with these findings, and they focus very strongly on the settlement potential of applicants, the skill profile of applicants and, in the case of business skills, an applicant's capacity to both invest in business and create employment.

There have been a number of initiatives that I will not have time to outline to the Senate tonight, such as skill matching, linking up people to available jobs and sponsoring migration to regional areas. There are some very important initiatives. As Australia faces its, no doubt, global future, I think it makes abundant sense to construct a population policy that serves the nation well for the emerging challenges ahead, and the role of rural and regional Australia in this process must receive paramount consideration.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak on education. On a day when the government and the Democrats are working closely together to put a tax on books, it seems curiously apt to be talking on this subject tonight. Education is central to Labor values. Kim Beazley went to the last election promising, if elected, to serve as the `Education Prime Minister'. In this, he is not alone. Bill Clinton in 1996 and Tony Blair in 1997 both went to the polls proclaiming education as their top priority.

speech.para: Education is no longer just one issue among many. Knowledge, skills, education and training are now matters that have moved to the core of the policy debate. In my own shadow portfolio of trade, education is vital. This may seem odd at first, so let me explain why. Labor believes that trade liberalisation is the best solution for Australia. The tariff cuts we put in place under the Hawke and Keating governments made industry more efficient and allowed us to lobby for comparable cuts in the tariffs and quotas of our trading partners. They put an extra $1,000 per year into the pockets of the average Australian family.

However, for some Australians, particularly those in regional Australia, trade liberalisation brought mixed blessings. Over the past two decades, job insecurity has increased throughout the world, and Australia has been no exception. Some of the industries have had difficulty adapting to the removal of the walls of fortress Australia. But the answer is not to keep buttressing the fortress; the answer is to invest in people by ensuring that education and training is available to everyone. Young Australians should be encouraged to finish school and given the opportunity for further education if they want it. The philosophy of lifelong learning needs to become a reality for everyone. The days when a worker needed only one set of skills because they would have only one job during their lifetime are long gone.

Labor also recognises the value of education exports. Education services are Australia's fifth largest export. They are worth around $3.5 billion per year and are responsible for employing nearly 9,000 teachers. Labor regards a successful education exports sector as important in creating a vibrant, outward looking, intellectual Australia. As Kim Beazley pointed out last year:

The great thing about education is that it empowers the individual. It helps them expand themselves. It opens vistas and opportunities they never had before. What better legacy could Australia bequeath to our neighbours in this part of the world than to have provided that sort of key to the future for them. What better legacy for Australia than to have done it in a way that makes us a better nation too.

Labor went to the 1998 election with a range of innovative policies to boost education exports, including cutting the cost of a student visa, boosting funding to promote Australia as a place to study and establishing an education exports roundtable. I am proud that we made education exports a high priority.

I will now say a few words about Western Australia. Universities are not the first thing that people think of when they think of Western Australia. Perhaps they think of mining, deserts, the America's Cup, our precious forests or holidays in Broome. All these are things that people associate immediately with the West. But we need to change that attitude, because universities in my state of Western Australia are rapidly becoming one of our biggest industries.

This was vividly demonstrated last week with the release of a report commissioned by Curtin University, the largest university in Western Australia. The report is entitled Contributing to the Community Through Education and Researchâa comprehensive study quantifying the economic impact of Curtin on the WA Economy. The study team was led by Mr Peter Kenyon and the report was released by the Vice Chancellor, Professor Lance Twomey. It makes some key findings about the importance of Curtin for the local economy. Curtin is the 11th largest business in the state and the 600th largest business in Australia if you include all private and public sector businesses. Curtin employs 2,500 people on campus, and is responsible for generating 1,600 more jobs off campus. Curtin adds about $370 million in human capital to the economy each year. This is measured by the increase in salaries which its graduates get as a result of having a Curtin education.

The flow-on effect of spending by Curtin, its staff and its students makes a total contribution of $434 million to the Western Australian economy. Curtin receives over $25 million per year in research income, which leads to a $65 million benefit to the industry in Western Australia. In relation to international students, the report points out that, of Curtin's 24,500 students, over 3,000âor 12 per centâare overseas students. International fee-paying students and associated family and visitors contribute nearly $70 million per year to the economy. As the report points out, this is over five times the amount contributed to the WA economy by the state's wine industry. As senators would be aware, the Western Australian wine industry is a substantial exporter. All up, the study estimates that the total impact of Curtin University on the economy of Western Australia is in the region of $700 million to $870 million, or 1.5 per cent, of total economic activity in the state.

The potential is there, but this government continues to drag the chain. As Kim Beazley pointed out in his budget reply speech, 37 per cent of our labour force did not finish high school. This compares to 19 per cent in the United Kingdom, 14 per cent in Germany and 11 per cent in the United States. Fifteen per cent of Australians have at least a university level education compared with 26 per cent of Americans. We are starting from behind.

Education needs to become not just a priority for this government but the priority; yet the government continues to slash and burn instead. The 1999-2000 budget delivers $800 million a year less in direct Commonwealth higher education funding than in Labor's last year in office. Taken together, all the Commonwealth support for education, training and both public and private research and development activity has fallen from three per cent of GDP when we were in office to 2.5 per cent in the latest budget.

Let me end on a note of optimism. Education is a powerful force for change. Not only does it provide skills; it also engenders trust. In the long term, the solution to the xenophobic scourge that swept Australia in 1996-98 is to raise education levels. Education is also good business. It is a great export earner for this country and, with the right government policies, it will grow rapidly. When students from other countries come to study in Australia, they enrich our culture. They also take back a little of our fundamental valuesâtolerance, democracy and equality. I would like to commend the work of Curtin University to the Australian Senate. I hope that the government will do more to encourage this sort of evaluation of the contribution of higher education to the national economy in the future.

I note in the presentation of Curtin University's report that they made some reference to similar studies that are being undertaken, or have been completed, by other universities in Australia, including the University of Western Australia. There is now a critical mass of research on the value that universities contribute to society in economic as well as in social terms on the national agenda, from which you could project the total value to Australia of having a vibrant higher education sector. Perhaps the opportunity is there to start to render this in realistic figures in terms of value so that not only can the recipients of higher education appreciate the value to them as individualsâthe
enrichment that it brings to their livesâbut also others can appreciate the addition to our social infrastructure, as well as the economic impacts, that a higher education community can bring.

In weighing those things, I would of course put most value on the social elements. But in recognising that many debates about value in Australia these days centre on the economic contribution, I would not want to overlook that. It is substantial; it is major. It surprises most Australians in terms of the extent of the contribution made to our national economy. It is the reason why industry and other sections of the community should support a stronger commitment to higher education, better training and more accessibility for ordinary Australians to those facilities. Again, I commend the work of Curtin University and the study to the Senate.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: With reference to the Federation Fund program, applications that were made by organisations in the Eden-Monaro electorate for funding for the Queanbeyan indoor swimming pool, Queanbeyan showground, the Batemans Bay spine road, Moruya Heritage Centre and the Eurobodalla shire water and sewerage improvements:

Given the Minister's joint responsibility for this program with the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Hill), where necessary in consultation with Senator Hill, for each of these applications:
(1) When were the applications submitted.
(2) Under what category of the Federation Fund was each application considered.
(3) On what date was a decision made on each application.
(4) On what date or dates were successful applications under the relevant programs publicly announced.
(5) On what date were unsuccessful applicants notified of the decision.
(6) Was the federal member for Eden-Monaro notified of the decisions; if so, on what date did this notification occur.
(7) (a) What criteria were used to make decisions on applications; and (b) how did each application rank against the criteria.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Arts and the Centenary of Federation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Senator West refers to Senator Alston having joint responsibility with Senator Hill for the Federation Fund program. As Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation, I am now responsible for the $29.6m Federation Community Projects Program (FCP) and Senator Hill and I are co-responsible for the $70.4m Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects (FCHP) program. Overall responsibility for administration of the Federation Fund lies with the Prime Minister's Department, although administrative responsibility for all individual major projects already announced has been devolved to a number of Departments, including the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts.
I have not received applications for assistance in relation to the Bateman's Bay spine road or the Eurobodalla shire water and sewerage improvements under the FCHP.

I am advised that applications for assistance from the Federation Fund in relation to the spine road and the extension of the Deep Creek dam were submitted to the government on 22 May and 16 July 1998 respectively. These two projects were not successful and the applicant was advised in writing of the outcome on 4 February 1999. All applications for funding under the Federation Fund have now been finalised and the Fund has been closed.
I provide the following information in respect of applications under the FCHP:
(1) Queanbeyan Indoor Swimming Poolâ24 June 1998; Queanbeyan Showgroundâ26 June 1998; Moruya Heritage Centreâ25 June 1998.
(2) Queanbeyan Indoor Swimming PoolâFCHP; Queanbeyan ShowgroundâFCHP; Moruya Heritage CentreâFCHP.
(3) Queanbeyan Indoor Swimming Poolâ28 August 1998; Queanbeyan Showgroundâ28 August 1998; Moruya Heritage Centreâ28 August 1998.
(4) There were no successful applications under the FCHP in the electorate of Eden-Monaro
(5) Letters to unsuccessful FCHP applicants were dated 13 October 1998.

(6) The Offices of all Federal Senators and Members of Parliament would have received the joint media release on the outcome of the FCHP through the standard fax-streaming of press releases from the offices of Senator Hill and Senator Alston on 15 October 1998.
(7) (a) In considering projects submitted under the FCHP, Ministers took into account the following factors:
* the General and Specific Assessment Criteria published in the FCHP information kit (see Attachment A);
* the assessment of projects undertaken by the Federation Task Group (FTG) (comprised of officials from both responsible departments) against those criteria;
* the assessment of projects by the National Council of the Centenary of Federation;
* the desirability of ensuring an adequate spread of projects in regional and metropolitan areas and between cultural and heritage projects; and
the notional State and Territory spread of funds between States and Territories, prepared by the FTG.
(7) (b) Scores prepared by the FTG on individual projects will not be made publicly available.
ATTACHMENT A
General Assessment Criteria
(a) Significance

Projects must be able to demonstrate regional significance as a minimum and preference will be given to applications which can demonstrate national significance. In considering whether a project has national significance, consideration will be given to the uniqueness of the proposal, its place within Australia's national cultural heritage and its benefits beyond its immediate locality. National significance could be demonstrated for a modest project in a remote locality if it could be shown that the project would contribute to our national cultural heritage as well as having regional benefits
(b) A lasting nature

Support is principally available for capital works projects of a lasting nature, the construction or enhancement of permanent cultural facilities and their collections, or the restoration and conservation of heritage buildings
(c) Appropriate for the Centenary of Federation
Applications must demonstrate the proposed projects capacity to suitably mark the Centenary of Federation. A high priority will be given to projects which demonstrate a capacity to:
enhance community awareness of Federation and its achievements, and
contribute to an enhanced understanding of the achievements of Australians.
(d) Benefits to the broad community
Preference will be given to applications which demonstrate a capacity to provide one or more of the following:
on-going employment or economic benefits; and
opportunities for use by, or availability to, a broad cross-section of the community.
(e) Good management
Applications should provide evidence of:
* realistic budgeting for the project;
* the financial and project management capacity of the applicant;
* well defined work plans with achievable outcomes rather than inputs to it;
* project completion by or during 2001; and
* evidence that arrangements are in place, to ensure the ongoing viability of the project.
(f) Partnerships in funding
Preference will be given to applications that contain financial and other support from the private sector, local community or other sources.
Specific Assessment Criteria

Applicants for some projects will need to complete both the heritage and cultural facility specific criteria, for example, a proposal to construct a new cultural facility in a heritage building or precinct.
(a) Heritage Projects

It will be an advantage for projects to be listed on the Register of the National Estate (or the Register's interim list), by the National Trust, or on a State register. National significance relates to those places which are worth keeping for the nation as a whole.
Projects seeking assistance for the restoration of heritage properties must also demonstrate:
* sound conservation management planning during restoration and for future useâthe involvement of heritage professionals is important;
* interpretative and promotion strategies;
* compliance with all relevant proposals;

* best practice innovative heritage approaches and adaptive re-use of significant heritage buildings (where any new construction is involved, adherence to the National Code of Practice for the Construction Industry should be demonstrated); and
* strategies to encourage partnerships with industry and community groups that promote conservation.
(b) Cultural Facilities Projects
Projects seeking assistance for cultural facilities and/or their collections must also demonstrate that the proposal:
* is part of a cultural plan for the region and/or State/Territory and has the capacity to link with regional cultural networks;
* is financially viable including evidence of feasibility plans; and
* strives to achieve best practice standards, including adherence to the National
Code of Practice for the Construction Industry.

question.para: Has Mr Geoffrey Robertson QC been engaged as a consultant by the Minister or the department since March 1996; if so:

(1) (a) What was the nature of the work Mr Robertson undertook; (b) when was he engaged; (c) when was the work completed; (d) what was the nature of the work; and (e) what was the cost of the consultancy.
(2) Was the contract the subject of a tender process; if not, why not.
(3) Did the final cost vary from the contracted price; if so: (a) what was the magnitude of the cost variation; and (b) what was the cause of the variation.

(4) Have other consultants been engaged to undertake work associated with the Robertson consultancy; if so: (a) who were those consultants; (b) when were they engaged; (c) when was the work completed; (d) what was the nature of the work undertaken by them; and (e) what was the cost of each consultancy.
(5) Did the final cost vary from the contracted price for any of the above consultancies; if so: (a) what was the magnitude of the cost variation; and (b) what was the cause of the variation.
(6) Was each contract the subject of a tender process; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: No.
